headline: Palestinian Civil Society calls for boycott, divestment, and sanctions
summary: More than 170 Palestinian political parties, organizations, trade unions and movements call for boycott, divestment, and sanctions (BDS) against Israel until it complies with international law. The BDS call demands that Israel end its occupation and colonization of all Arab lands and dismantle the wall, provide equal rights for Palestinian citizens of Israel, and uphold the right of return for Palestinian refugees.

headline: Veterans for Peace adopts BDS resolution
summary: Veterans for Peace (VFP), a U.S. pro-peace and anti-militarism educational organization, adopts a resolution in support of the Palestinian call for BDS.

headline: US Green Party announces support for BDS
summary: The Green Party in the US “calls for divestment from and boycott of the State of Israel until such time as the full individual and collective rights of the Palestinian people are realized."

headline: The regional council of the Sør-Trøndelag in Norway adopts boycott
summary: The regional council of the Sør-Trøndelag in Norway, with a population of 270,000, passes a motion calling for a comprehensive boycott on Israeli goods to be followed up with an awareness raising campaign across the region. The motion also mentions that "Sør-Trøndelag was the first [Norwegian] county to boycott South Africa."

headline: Presbyterian Church of Scotland calls on European Union to support boycott
summary: The Church of Scotland General Assembly calls on the European Union to clearly inform consumers by identifying products from Israeli settlements. After a visit to the Occupied Palestinian Territories, the moderator of the assembly calls on the church to pursue divestment and boycotts against companies that profit from the occupation.

headline: Pink Floyd’s Roger Waters moves Tel Aviv show and meets Palestinian artists
summary: Musician Roger Waters of Pink Floyd moves a concert out of Tel Aviv and meets with Palestinian artists, marking the start of Waters becoming an outspoken supporter of BDS.

headline: Canadian Union of Public Employees Ontario votes to support BDS
summary: Delegates to the Canadian Union of Public Employees Ontario convention in Ottawa vote overwhelmingly to support BDS until Israel recognizes Palestinians' right to self-determination. The union represents more than 200,000 Ontario workers.

headline: UK's largest higher education union endorses academic boycott
summary: The UK's National Association of Teachers in Further and Higher Education (NATFHE), representing 67,000 teachers, adopts the 2004 call for academic boycott of Israeli institutions initiated by the Palestinian Campaign for the Academic and Cultural Boycott of Israel (PACBI).

headline: Edinburgh International Film Festival refuses Israeli Embassy sponsorship
summary: The Edinburgh International Film Festival drops Israeli Embassy sponsorship and returns funds following public outcry.

headline: Irish Film Institute drops Embassy of Israel sponsorship
summary: The Irish Film Institute drops the Israeli embassy as a sponsor for a screening of the Israeli film Walk on Water. In a statement, organizers note "the decision is taken in light of the current activities of the Israeli government and prompted by the performance of your ambassador in explaining these acts to the Irish public."

headline: Dublin tram workers decline to train engineers working on settlement rail system
summary: Dublin tram drivers block the Dublin tram system from being used to train Israeli drivers and engineers for a new light rail system in East Jerusalem serving illegal settlements. As a consequence, the local authority cancels its training plan with Connex, the subsidiary of the French multinational company Veolia that will operate the Israeli system.

headline: Locarno Film Festival drops Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs as sponsor
summary: The organizers of the Locarno International Film Festival drop the Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs as a festival sponsor because of Israel's military actions in Lebanon and the Gaza Strip.

headline: Film director Ken Loach announces public support for BDS
summary: British film director Ken Loach publicly expresses his support for a cultural boycott of Israel. He urges others to join Palestinian filmmakers, artists and people of conscience in the boycott of Israeli-sponsored cultural institutions.

headline: 61 Irish academics call on European Union to end support of Israeli academic institutions
summary: 61 Irish academics from a wide variety of disciplines call for a moratorium on European Union support of Israeli academic institutions until Israel abides by United Nations resolutions and ends the occupation of Palestinian territories.

headline: South African Trade Union Congress calls for a comprehensive boycott of Israel
summary: South African Trade Union Congress, representing 1.8 million workers, passes a resolution endorsing a comprehensive boycott of Israel.

headline: University of Michigan-Dearborn students pass divestment resolutions
summary: University of Michigan-Dearborn students adopt two resolutions demanding that the university divest from companies that participate in Israel’s oppression of Palestinians. More than 80 universities in the U.S. and Canada adopted divestment resolutions by 2025.

headline: 123 Palestinian filmmakers and artists call for cultural boycott
summary: Palestinian artists and cultural workers sign a call for cultural boycott that says they "appeal to all artists and filmmakers of good conscience around the world to cancel all exhibitions and other cultural events that are scheduled to occur in Israel...We call upon the International community to join us in the boycott of Israeli film festivals, Israeli public venues, and Israeli institutions supported by the government, and to end all cooperation with these cultural and artistic institutions that to date have refused to take a stand against the Occupation, the root cause for this colonial conflict."

headline: Dutch ASN Bank cuts ties with Veolia
summary: ASN Bank in the Netherlands excludes Veolia, stating “we are of the opinion that Veolia’s activities in Jerusalem are in conflict with UN Resolutions.” Veolia is a French multinational company involved in developing transportation infrastructure that serves Israeli settlements, which are illegal under international law.

headline: 94 international artists sign letter asking their colleagues to join cultural boycott of Israel
summary: Authors, film-makers, musicians, performers and artists, including Brian Eno and Arundhati Roy, sign a boycott letter calling on colleagues not to visit, perform, or exhibit in Israel.

headline: The faculty of the College of Arts and Sciences at Howard University call for divestment
summary: The faculty of the College of Arts and Sciences at Howard University, a historically Black institution, voted 25-2 to ask the University's Board of Trustees to divest from companies that are "offering material support to Israeli Occupation."

headline: The National Union of Journalists in the UK votes for boycott
summary: The National Union of Journalists, representing 38,000 journalists in the UK, votes 66-54 for a boycott of Israeli goods to protest Israel’s war on Lebanon and aggression in the Palestinian territories.

headline: British doctors support Palestinian call for boycott of Israeli Medical Association
summary: 130 British doctors call for a boycott of the Israeli Medical Association and its expulsion from the World Medical Association, expressing "grave concerns as doctors about the health-related impact of Israeli policy on Palestinian society" and saying that "a boycott is an ethical and moral imperative when conventional channels do not function, for otherwise we are merely turning away."

headline: University and College Union in the UK calls for academic boycott of Israeli universities
summary: The newly formed University and College Union, the largest British trade union for academics, teachers, and support staff, votes to boycott Israeli academic institutions and condemns the "complicity of Israeli academia in the occupation."

headline: Northern Ireland Public Service Alliance passes five BDS resolutions
summary: Northern Ireland Public Service Alliance (NIPSA) unanimously passes five motions on Palestinian solidarity discussed at its annual delegate conference, including a BDS motion.

headline: Second largest UK union calls on members to boycott Israel
summary: British Transport and General Workers Union (TGWU), the second largest union in the United Kingdom, calls on its 800,000 members to boycott Israeli-made products based on Israel’s "criminal policies in Palestinian territories."

headline: Irish Congress of Trade Unions calls for boycott and divestment
summary: Irish Congress of Trade Unions, representing trade unions and councils from both the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland, passes two motions to commit to "actively and vigorously" promoting a policy of boycott and of divestment.

headline: Evangelical Lutheran Church of America begins to work towards BDS
summary: The Evangelical Lutheran Church of America, with nearly 5 million members, backs exploring a boycott of Isreali products and of supporting the purchase of Palestinian products in measures adopted by the denomination’s key legislative body.

headline: National Coalition of American Nuns calls for Caterpillar boycott
summary: The National Coalition of American Nuns backs a general boycott of Israeli goods and calls for divestment from Caterpillar. Israel uses Caterpillar bulldozers to destroy Palestinian homes and agricultural land.

headline: Quebec-wide student union L’Association pour une Solidarité Syndicale Étudiante (ASSÉ) passes motion supporting BDS
summary: L’Association pour une Solidarité Syndicale Étudiante (ASSÉ), a Quebec-wide student union representing over 40,000 students, passes a resolution to support BDS at its annual Congress in Montreal.

headline: London School of Economics students vote for divestment from Israel
summary: The London School of Economics Student Union votes to lobby the university to divest from companies that provide military support for the Israeli occupation, facilitate the maintenance of Israel's wall, or operate in illegal settlements.

headline: Canadian Union of Postal Workers votes to endorse BDS
summary: Representing over 50,000 postal workers across Canada, the postal workers' union votes nearly unanimously to adopt a resolution recognizing Israel as an apartheid state and expressing support for boycott and divestment, becoming the first national union in North America to adopt a BDS resolution.

headline: Irish trade union IMPACT endorses BDS
summary: The largest public sector union in the Republic of Ireland, IMPACT, passes two motions calling for a boycott of Israeli goods and services, as well as divestment from companies engaged in or profiting from the occupation.

headline: Jean-Luc Godard declines invitation to a Tel Aviv film festival
summary: French film director Jean-Luc Godard, pioneer of the French New Wave film movement, declines an invitation to attend the Tel Aviv International Student Film Festival. A source close to his office, which declined public comment, cited political pressure as his reason for cancelling the visit.

headline: Snoop Dogg cancels Israel gig
summary: Snoop Dogg cancels a scheduled concert in Israel after Palestinians write an open letter urging him not to cross their picket line.

headline: Dutch Triodos Bank excludes investments in companies that contribute to occupation
summary: Triodos Bank in the Netherlands confirms that it "excludes companies that contribute to the continuation of occupation, like Veolia, Alstom, Motorola, and Caterpillar."

headline: Two Scottish universities cancel Eden Springs contracts
summary: Heriot-Watt University and Stevenson College, Edinburgh in Scotland decide to terminate contracts with Eden Springs, an Israeli water company that extracts water from the Salukia spring and bottles it in the settlement of Katzrin, both located in the illegally occupied Syrian Golan Heights.

headline: Catalan Workers' Union passes BDS resolution
summary: The Catalan Workers' Union, known as the Intersindical Alternativa de Catallunya (IAC), passes a resolution calling for broad boycotts against Israel.

headline: Eden Springs, an Israeli water company, closes factory in Scotland
summary: Israeli water company Eden Springs has closed its East of Scotland depot after losing "hundreds of contracts across Scotland" amidst boycott campaigns. Eden Springs is an Israeli water company that extracts water from the Salukia spring and bottles it in the settlement of Katzrin, both located in the illegally occupied Syrian Golan Heights.

headline: Unilever divests from Israeli factory based in West Bank settlement
summary: Food and soap manufacturing multinational, Unilever, announces it will sell its majority stake in the Beigel & Beigel factory in Ariel settlement, illegally built on land confiscated from Palestinians.

headline: University of Western Sydney Student Association calls for BDS
summary: The University of Western Sydney’s Student Association (UWSSA) decides to formally affiliate with BDS. The resolution commits the association to refrain from participation in any form of academic and cultural cooperation, collaboration or joint projects with Israeli institutions; advocate a comprehensive boycott of Israeli institutions, including suspension of all forms of funding and subsidies to these institutions; and promote divestment and disinvestment from Israel by international academic institutions.

headline: British telecom firm severs ties with Israeli firm
summary: FreedomCall Ltd., a British telecommunications firm, informs Israel’s MobileMax, a provider of international service for cellular phones, that they will no longer do business with the company or any other Israeli company as a result of Israeli attacks on Gaza.

headline: South African trade unions call for increased boycott of Israel
summary: In response to Israel's military assault on the Gaza Strip, the Coalition of South African Trade Unions (COSATU) calls for a national day of action. One of its member groups, a dockworkers union, refuses to unload goods from an Israeli ship.

headline: Ireland's Derry City Council calls for boycott and sanctions
summary: Derry City Council, Ireland, adopts a motion calling for the people of Derry to boycott Israeli goods in solidarity with Palestinians and for Israel to be sanctioned by national governments and the European Union.

headline: Venezuela breaks diplomatic ties with Israel over Gaza attack
summary: Venezuela breaks ties with the Israeli government and expells the Israeli ambassador from Venezuela citing the "inhumane persecution of the Palestinian people carried out by the authorities of Israel" during the most recent offensives in the Gaza Strip.

headline: Author Naomi Klein calls for BDS
summary: Author Noami Klein publishes a piece in the Guardian titled "Enough. It's time for a boycott" in which she makes a case for BDS and describes how she changed her book contracts to comply with the call.

headline: Maritime Union of Australia (Western Australia) calls for boycott of Israeli ships
summary: Western Australian members of the Maritime Union of Australia call for a boycott of Israeli-registered vessels and ships bearing goods arriving from or going to Israel in support of BDS.

headline: Bolivia breaks off diplomatic relations with Israel
summary: Bolivia breaks off diplomatic relations with Israel over its attacks on Gaza, and calls for Israeli leaders to be tried in the International Criminal Court for crimes against humanity.

headline: The Grand Hotel Intercontinental in Paris cancels Israeli Tourism Fair
summary: The management of the Grand Hotel Intercontinental in Paris cancels an Israeli tourism fair, disinviting 50 Israeli exhibitors who had planned to present tourism products in the wake of Israel’s 2008-2009 military assault on the Gaza Strip.

headline: New Zealand Council of Trade Unions calls for cutting ties with Israel
summary: The New Zealand Council of Trade Unions, Te Kauae Kaimahi, calls on the New Zealand Government to "do all it can to stop the inhumane bombing of Gaza by the Israeli government." Actions they demand include cutting diplomatic ties with Israel, ending military cooperation with Israel, and boycotting Israeli goods manufactured in the Occupied Territories.

headline: Napier University calls for cancellation of Eden Springs contract
summary: Napier University, a branch of the Education Institute of Scotland (EIS), passes a motion at its Annual Meeting calling for a cancellation of the university’s contract with Eden Springs, an Israeli water company that extracts water from the Salukia spring and bottles it in the settlement of Katzrin, both located in the illegally occupied Syrian Golan Heights.

headline: Over 300 British intellectuals call for BDS
summary: In a letter published by the Guardian, British academics and intellectuals call on "the British government and the British people to take all feasible steps to oblige Israel to comply with these demands [of the Palestinian peple], starting with a programme of boycott, divestment and sanctions."

headline: Produce importers in Sweden, Norway, Denmark, England, and Jordan boycott Israel
summary: Produce importers in Sweden, Norway, Denmark, England, and Jordan cancel orders for Israeli produce during Israel’s assault on the Gaza Strip.

headline: Largest teachers union in France votes to endorse BDS
summary: La fédération syndicale unitaire (FSU), the largest French public sector union with 162,000 members, passes a motion to endorse BDS after Israel bombed Gaza.

headline: Stockholm drops Veolia from $4.6 billion contract
summary: The Stockholm community council in Sweden announces that Veolia, which has operated its subways for ten years, lost a contract for worth $4.6 billion to continue the operations following a boycott campaign by Swedish civil society. In 2009, Veolia would be excluded from bidding or denied contracts in Ireland, the UK, France, Iran, and Australia.

headline: Irish academics call on European Union to end financial support for Israeli universities
summary: After the 2008–2009 Israeli assault on Gaza, 148 Irish academics call on the EU to impose “a moratorium on the funding of Israeli academic institutions by national and European cultural and research institutions.”

headline: University students stage sit-in movement over Israeli attack on Gaza
summary: Thousands of students participate in sit-ins at over 30 universities in the United Kingdom to protest Israel's 2008–2009 bombardment of Gaza, inspiring a wave of similar protests in other countries. Administrators meet demands ranging from divestment to scholarships for Palestinian students.

headline: Mandate, an Irish trade union, joins BDS
summary: Mandate, a retail, bar, and administrative workers' union representing over 40,000 members across Ireland, commits to BDS. In a statement in the Irish Times, they call on the Irish government to cease the purchase of Israeli military equipment and enforce a military embargo against Israel.

headline: South African dock workers refuse to unload Israeli ship
summary: The South African Transport and Allied Workers Union (SATAWU) announces they will not offload a ship from Israel scheduled to dock in Durban. This act of boycott mirrors a tactic used in South Africa's anti-apartheid movement, when in 1963, dockworkers around the world refused to offload a South African ship as a show of solidarity against apartheid.

headline: Poet Adrienne Rich endorses call for academic and cultural boycott
summary: American feminist poet Adrienne Rich writes a letter explaining how she has come to support BDS based on her experiences organizing against the Israeli occupation as an American Jew, and in particular seeing "the kinds of organized efforts to stifle — in the US and elsewhere — critiques of Israel’s policies" and "condemn any critiques as anti-Semitism."

headline: Strathclyde University cancels Eden Springs contract after student pressure
summary: University of Strathclyde agrees to not place any further orders from Eden Springs after student protests over Israel's bombing of Gaza. Eden Springs is an Israeli water company that extracts water from the Salukia spring and bottles it in the settlement of Katzrin, both located in the illegally occupied Syrian Golan Heights.

headline: Sligo City Council, Ireland, adopts motion against Veolia
summary: The Sligo City Council unanimously adopts a motion calling on the County Manager not to sign or renew any contracts with Veolia because of its activities in the Occupied Palestinian Territory. Veolia is a French multi-national company involved in developing discriminatory infrastructure to serve Israeli settlements.

headline: University of Manchester students pass motion to boycott Israel
summary: The University of Manchester Student Union, the largest in Western Europe, passes a motion to boycott Israel in an emergency general meeting called in response to the crisis in Gaza.

headline: Hampshire College becomes first in the U.S. to divest
summary: Hampshire College in Massachusetts becomes the first in the U.S. to divest from companies on the grounds of their complicity in Israeli human rights violations. Hampshire college was also the first U.S. college to divest from South Africa in 1976 and divested from fossil fuels in 2011.

headline: Branch of Canadian Union of Public Employees votes for academic boycott
summary: The Ontario branch of Canadian Union of Public Employees, which represents 200,000 government and other public sector workers, votes for a motion calling for an academic boycott of Israel at a meeting in Windsor.

headline: St. Andrews University students vote to cancel Eden Springs contract
summary: The St. Andrews University Student Union votes to cancel the university’s contract with Eden Springs, an Israeli water company that extracts water from the Salukia spring and bottles it in the settlement of Katzrin, both located in the illegally occupied Syrian Golan Heights.

headline: SOAS students vote to join academic boycott
summary: The SOAS student union votes to equate Zionism with racism and to affiliate with the Campaign for Academic boycott of Israeli Institutions and the British Committee for the Universities of Palestine (BRICUP).

headline: Mauritania freezes diplomatic ties to Israel in response to Operation Cast Lead
summary: The Mauritanian government freezes diplomatic ties with Israel in response to Operation Cast Lead, Israel's 2008-09 militray assault on the Gaza Strip that killed 1800 Palestinian civilians.  Mauritania later withdraws its ambassador to Israel and asks Israeli staff at Israel's embassy in Mauritania to leave the country.

headline: Veolia denied $1.43 billion contract with the UK's Sandwell Council
summary: Veolia is not shortlisted for a 25-year waste collection and recycling contract with the UK's Sandwell Council worth $1.43 billion following efforts by local activists. Veolia is a French multinational company involved in developing infrastructure to serve Israeli settlements, which are illegal under international law.

headline: Swedish national pension fund AP7 excludes Alstom from investment portfolio
summary: Swedish national pension fund AP7, which manages $15 billion in pension savings, excludes French transportation company Alstrom from its portfolio for ethical reasons, citing human rights abuses stemming from its involvement in the Jerusalem Light Rail project.

headline: Australian academics declare support for BDS
summary: In an open letter, a group of Australian academics announce the establishment of a campaign "focused specifically on a boycott of Israeli academic and cultural institutions", listing five specific actions they plan to pursue. The academics also encourage their colleagues "nationally, regionally, and internationally" to join the call to BDS.

headline: The Swedish AP 1 pension fund divests from Africa Israel Investments
summary: Swedish Pension Fund AP1, once a major investor in Africa Israel Investments, no longer holds shares in the company, but has not publicly commented on the divestment. Africa Israel Investments is an investment company based in Israel whose companies are involved in constructing Israeli settlements and Israel's wall in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, both of which are illegal under international law.

headline: Motorola Israel sells its Government Electronics Department
summary: Motorola Israel Ltd. announces the sale of its Government Electronics Department, which sold bomb fuses, communication devices, and surveillance equipment to the Israeli military. The sale follows protests at multiple US locations where Motorola products were available.

headline: Veolia fails to win $995 million contract in Bordeaux, France
summary: The Greater Bordeaux local government passes on Veolia for a major contract following opposition to the bid by local activists. The local government attributed the decision to commercial factors. Veolia has been involved in the construction of a tramway in Jerusalem, designed to link West Jerusalem with illegal Israeli settlements in the occupied Palestinian territories.

headline: City Coucil of Galway, Ireland votes against renewing Veolia contract
summary: Galway City Council votes overwhelmingly against renewing a water services contract with Veolia. Veolia is a French multinational company involved in developing infrastructure to serve Israeli settlements, which are illegal under international law.

headline: Scottish Trades Union Congress votes for BDS
summary: The Scottish Trades Union Congress, representing every Scottish trade union, votes overwhelmingly to commit to BDS action.

headline: Victoria State Government in Australia drops Veolia subsidiary
summary: Connex, a subsidiary of French multinational company Veolia, loses a contract with the Victorian State Government as train system operator for the city of Melbourne, Australia after a boycott campaign in which activists distributed 100,000 pamphlets. Veolia is involved in developing infrastructure to serve Israeli settlements, which are illegal under international law.

headline: Tehran city council to exclude Veolia from bidding
summary: The City of Tehran in Iran announces that Veolia will be excluded from bidding for key contracts for the city’s transportation services due to its involvement in Israeli settlements, which are illegal under international law.

headline: Dexia financial group stops financing Israeli settlments
summary: The Belgian-French financial group Dexia announces it will no longer finance Israeli settlements, as it had previously been doing through its Israeli branch, Dexia Israel, because such loans violate the bank's code of ethics. The decision comes after a months-long grassroots pressure campaign in Belgium.

headline: Group of Palestinian and Jewish Israeli citizens form "boycott from within"
summary: Jewish and Palestinian citizens of Israel form an organizing body focused on the BDS movement. They state: "We endorse the Palestinian call as is. We stand against all forms of racism and oppression and support and encourage BDS actions as a legitimate political activity and a necessary means of non-violent resistance. We will act inside and outside Israel to promote awareness and support of BDS."

headline: The Yes Men remove their film from the Jerusalem Film Festival in solidarity with BDS
summary: The Yes Men write a letter explaining why they are removing their film "The Yes Men Fix The World" from the Jerusalem Film Festival. They cite their desire to be in solidarity with Palestinians and respect the BDS call, as well as their plans to distribute the film in a way that "people most in need of comic relief, who would never have been able to see it at the Jerusalem Film Festival anyhow, will be able to see it too."

headline: New Zealand's Unite Union passes a resolution of support for the BDS campaign
summary: Unite Union of New Zealand demands the immediate withdrawal of Israel from occupied Palestinian territories. The Union further states its support for BDS, citing the international movement against South African apartheid.

headline: British Fire Brigades Union calls for boycott of Israel
summary: The British Fire Brigades Union, representing 85% of firefighters and support staff in Britain, puts forth motions to the Trades Union Congress of Britain to increase international pressure on Israel. The motions include calls for BDS, affiliation to the Palestine Solidarity Campaign, and severance of ties with Israel's national union.

headline: BlackRock investment bank sells Africa Israel Investments shares
summary: Investement bank BlackRock sells all of its shares in Africa Israel Investments, an investment company based in Israel whose companies are involved in constructing Israeli settlements and the Israeli wall in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, both of which are illegal under international law.

headline: 1,500 filmmakers, artists, and writers sign "The Toronto Declaration: No Celebration of Occupation" in response to Toronto International Film Festival's decision to spotlight Tel Aviv
summary: International filmmakers, artists, and writers, including Jane Fonda, Viggo Mortensen, Danny Glover and Harry Belafonte, sign an open letter in solidarity with Palestinians objecting to the Toronto Film Festival's decision to spotlight the city of Tel Aviv for its inaugural City-to-City program. The decision to celebrate Tel Aviv at one of the world’s top cinematic events follows Israel's lethal attacks on Gaza earlier in the year. The letter highlights a statement from an Israeli official that Toronto would be the test city for the "Brand Israel" propaganda campaign, including via a presence at the 2009 Toronto International Film Festival.

headline: Norwegian government pension fund divests $6 million from Elbit Systems
summary: The Norwegian Government Pension Fund Global, one of the largest pension funds in the world, divests $6 million from Israeli weapons company Elbit Systems. Norway’s Finance Minister says, “we do not wish to fund companies that so directly contribute to violations of international humanitarian law.”

headline: Ken Loach, Rebecca O'Brien, and Paul Laverty pull film from Israeli-sponsored festival in an endorsement of BDS
summary: Filmmakers Rebecca O'Brien, Ken Loach, and Paul Laverty pull their film "Looking for Eric" from the Melbourne International Film festival following their discovery that the festival accepts Israeli government funds.

headline: Norwegian pension fund KLP divests from Elbit Systems
summary: KLP, one of the largest pension funds in Norway, divests from Elbit Systems, Israel's largest weapons company, due to ethical considerations. Elbit Systems is a close partner to the Israeli military and manufacturs weapons and surveillance systems used by Israel to commit grave human rights abuses against Palestinians and marketed globally as "field-proven."

headline: Brazil's Chamber of Deputies proposes not to ratify free trade agreement between Israel and Latin American trading bloc
summary: Brazil’s Chamber of Deputies Committee on Foreign Relations and National Defense recommends to the Congress not to ratify the free trade agreement between Mercosur and Israel until Israel accepts the creation of a Palestinian state. Mercado Common del Sur (Mercosur) is the trading bloc of Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay, and Venezuela.

headline: British Trade Union Congress votes to boycott Israel
summary: The Trade Union Congress (TUC), a group of 58 unions representing over 6.5 million workers in the UK, passes a motion to boycott all goods originating from Israeli settlements in the West Bank.

headline: Spanish government excludes settlement university from architecture competition
summary: The Government of Spain disqualifies the University Center of Ariel in Samaria (AUCS) from "Solar Decathlon-Madrid 2010", the most prestigious competition for sustainable architecture in the world, because the university is located in an Israeli settlement in the occupied West Bank. Israeli settlements are illegal under international law.

headline: Sarah Schulman discusses her support for BDS
summary: American novelist, playwright, activist, and academic Sarah Schulman explains in an interview her decision to support BDS in part to break the silence surrounding the question of Palestine in the LGBTQ community. She explains how her journey into Palestinian advocacy started with the invitation to give a keynote address at the Tel Aviv University Lesbian and Gay Studies Conference in November 2009, and after extensive research she opted to go to Palestine for a solidarity tour instead.

headline: The French national workers' union joins BDS Campaign
summary: The National Work Confederation (Confederation Nationale du Travail, or CNT), an anti-capitalist French union active in struggles for social justice, joins the BDS campaign to end Israeli exploitation and occupation.

headline: Sussex University students vote to boycott Israeli goods
summary: Students at the University of Sussex vote to pass a campus-wide referendum calling for the boycott of Israeli goods, with 56% of students voting in favor of the boycott. The university's student union plans to apply this referendum by no longer stocking goods from Israel in its shops, as well as lobbying the university's administration to observe the boycott.

headline: Danish fund Investeringsforeningen Sydinvest divests from Africa Israel Investments
summary: The Danish fund manager, Investeringsforeningen Sydinvest divests Africa Israel Investments because of the company’s involvement in the illegal Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Palestinian Christians launch Kairos Palestine document calling for BDS
summary: Palestinian Christians launch the Kairos Palestine document. Titled "A Moment of Truth," the document presents "Christian Palestinians’ word to the world about what is happening in Palestine" and calls for BDS, stating "we see boycott and disinvestment as tools of non violence for justice, peace and security for all."

headline: Over 500 US scholars and authors endorse academic and cultural boycotts of Israel
summary: Hundreds of Irish, Australian, Canadian, and U.S. scholars and unions endorse academic boycott in response to Israel’s brutal 2008–2009 assault on Gaza.

headline: Israeli-American Filmmaker Udi Aloni endorses BDS
summary: Udi Aloni, award-winning filmmaker, publishes open letter endorsing BDS as a legitimate means to attain goals of justice, peace, and equality.

headline: Danish Pension Fund PKA divests from Elbit and Magal Security Systems
summary: Danish pension fund PKA, one of the largest pension funds in Denmark, announces that it will no longer consider investments in Elbit Systems, Israel's largest weapons company, and Magal Security Systems, a US company, due to their involvement with Israel's wall.

headline: Pakistanis for Palestine forms, joins BDS campaign
summary: A solidarity campaign with the Palestinian people is launched in Lahore, with members of the labor movement, students, scholars and other professionals. Its first action is to call on Pakistani academic and cultural workers––artists, poets, writers, singers and filmmakers––to join BDS.

headline: Danske Bank excludes Elbit Systems, Magal Security Systems, and Africa Israel
summary: Danske Bank, the biggest financial group in Denmark, excludes Elbit Systems, Magal Security Systems, and Africa Israel from its investment portfolio because of their involvement in providing equipment for Israel's wall and for settlement construction.

headline: Costco stops selling Ahava Products
summary: Costco no longer has Ahava products for sale, following a Stolen Beauty campaign that engaged with the retailer. According to a letter from Costco management, “these items are pending delete in our system and once they have sold they are no longer available.”

headline: The Church of England divests $3.4 million from Caterpillar
summary: The Church of England divests $3.4 million from Caterpillar following advice from its international advisory body to withdraw investments in companies that support the occupation of Palestinian territories. Israel uses Caterpillar bulldozers to destroy Palestinian homes and agricultural land. The church’s ethical investment policy prohibits investment in arms companies or companies making weapons platforms.

headline: Netherlands pension fund ABP divests $2.7 million from Elbit Systems
summary: ABP, the pension fund for government and education employees in the Netherlands, divests $2.7 million from Elbit Systems.

headline: 500 Montreal artists endorse BDS
summary: A broad spectrum of artists in Montreal sign a statement endorsing the BDS campaign, including filmmakers, musicians, dancers, poets, authors, and painters, saying "we commit to fighting against apartheid and call upon all artists and cultural producers across the country and around the world to adopt a similar position in this global struggle."

headline: Belgian Trade Union Federation adopts BDS
summary: The federal congress of Centrale Generale/ABVV Algemene Centrale in Belgium adopts a motion advocating for BDS titled “decent work is impossible under military occupation”. The motion opens by recalling Israel's recent attack on the Gaza Freedom Flotilla, which killed 10 people.

headline: Several Swedish pension funds remove Elbit Systems from their portfolios
summary: Folksam, Sweden's leading asset manager, responds to an inquiry by confirming that they have no holdings in Elbit Systems or Africa Israel because "we have a strict policy regarding activity on occupied land."  A month later, the First, Second, Third and Fourth Swedish National Pension Funds (AP1, AP2, AP3 and AP4) exclude Elbit Systems from their investments.

headline: Artists Against Apartheid, founded to speak out against South African apartheid regime, stands in solidarity with BDS
summary: Artists Against Apartheid, founded by Steven Van Zandt and Arthur Baker in 1985 to protest apartheid in South Africa, speak out against crimes of apartheid in Palestine-Israel and express commitment to the Palestinian call for BDS, saying "we support the call for international artists not to perform or exhibit work in apartheid Israel, unless in solidarity with anti-apartheid events."

headline: Berkeley divestment campaign draws high profile support
summary: Students organizing a divestment campaign at the University of California, Berkeley receive messages of support from Archbishop Desmond Tutu, Noam Chomsky, Naomi Klein, and Nobel Prize winners Shirin Ebadi, Mairead Maguire, Rigoberta Menchu Tum, and Judy Williams. Berkeley professor Judith Butler addresses student activists in a memorable speech titled "You Will Not Be Alone."

headline: Italian Industrial Union joins BDS boycott campaign
summary: FIOM-CGIL, Italy's oldest industrial union representing over 350,000 metal-workers, endorses the BDS call.

headline: Gil Scott-Heron cancels concert in Israel
summary: American poet and musician Gil Scott-Heron cancels a scheduled concert in Israel after a coalition of organizations and artists call on him to boycott. Scott-Heron was also an outspoken supporter of the cultural boycott of apartheid South Africa in the 1980s.

headline: South Africa downgrades diplomatic relations with Israel over flotilla attack
summary: South Africa recalls its ambassador to Israel in response to Israel's attack on the Gaza Freedom Flotilla in international waters, which killed ten activists.

headline: Dublin City Council passes motion against contracts with Veolia
summary: Dublin City Council passes a resolution not to sign or renew any contracts with Veolia, the first of multiple municipalities in Ireland, the UK, and France to adopt measures against Veolia or deny the company contracts in 2010.

headline: Australian Construction Forestry Mining Energy Union (CFMEU) joins BDS
summary: Australia’s Construction Forestry Mining and Energy Union (CFMEU), with 144,000 members, joins BDS. The union executive says the decision stems from Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s expansion of illegal Israeli settlements in occupied Palestinian territory.

headline: Elvis Costello cancels two concerts in Israel in protest of the treatment of Palestinians
summary: Grammy award-winning British singer-songwriter Elvis Costello cancels two planned concerts in Israel to protest the treatment of Palestinians, stating on his website that his decision is "a matter of instinct and conscience" and describing how Israel subjects Palestinian civilians to "intimidation, humiliation or much worse...in the name of national security". He declares "I cannot imagine receiving another invitation to perform in Israel, which is a matter of regret, but I can imagine a better time when I would not be writing this."

headline: Four grocery chains remove Israeli products from their shelves
summary: Two Italian supermarkets chains, chains Coop and Nordiconad, announce that they plan to stop selling all Israeli products as they could not differentiate whether they came from Israel's illegal West Bank settlements or inside the Green Line. Two British supermarkets, Marks and Spencer and Co-operative Group, also decide to stop selling produce from illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: University and College Union in the UK severs links with Histadrut
summary: At its annual congress, the University and College Union (UCU) votes by an overwhelming majority to "sever all relations with Histadrut, and to urge other trade unions and bodies to do likewise" as part of a broader commitment to BDS. Histadrut is Israel's national trade union that has historically supported policies of ethnic cleansing and banned Palestinian workers. During the apartheid era in South Africa, Histadrut-owned industries supplied the apartheid regime in defiance of international law. In 2009, Histadrut issued a statement of support for Israel's actions in Gaza.

headline: Turkey recalls ambassador from Israel after flotilla attack
summary: Turkey recalls its ambassador to Israel after ten Turkish activists were killed when the Israel Navy attacked the Gaza Freedom Flotilla.

headline: Donegal County Council, Ireland, cancels contract renewal with Veolia
summary: Donegal County Council votes not to renew any contracts with the French transnational corporation Veolia in light of its activities in occupied Palestinian territory. Veolia is a French multi-national company involved in developing discriminatory infrastructure to serve Israeli settlements.

headline: Waterford city council, Ireland, votes to back expulsion of Israeli ambassador
summary: In the wake of the attack on the Gaza Freedom Flotilla, Waterford City Council votes in favor of the expulsion of the Israeli ambassador from Ireland.

headline: Newry and Mourne District Council, Ireland, calls for boycott
summary: Newry and Mourne District Council in Ireland adopts a petition "to boycott the use of Israeli services and the purchase or sale of Israeli good or products by Newry & Mourne District Council" following Israel's attack on the Gaza Freedom Flotilla.

headline: Nicaragua downgrades diplomatic relations with Israel over flotilla raid
summary: The government of Nicaragua suspends diplomatic relations with Israel over the Gaza Flotilla raid. Nicaragua reiterates its support for the Palestinian people and urges an end to the blockade on the Gaza Strip.

headline: Two international youth teams cancel football matches in Israel
summary: Turkey's under-19 and Sweden's under-21 football teams refuse to play in Israel following Israel's attack on the Gaza aid flotilla in international waters, which killed ten activists.

headline: Ecuador recalls ambassador after flotilla attack
summary: Ecuador recalls its ambassador to Israel in protest against Israel’s attack on the Gaza Freedom Flotilla.

headline: Brazil recalls ambassador to Israel over Gaza Aid Flotilla attack
summary: Brazil recalls its ambassador to Israel to express "shock and dismay" over Israel's attack on the Gaza Freedom Flotilla in international waters, which killed 10 activists.

headline: Evergreen State College students vote in support of divestment
summary: Students at Evergreen State College vote in favor of two BDS resolutions in a cross-campus ballot. The resolutions, which call for the college to divest from companies that profit from Israel's illegal occupation and for a ban on the use of Caterpillar equipment on campus, passed by a vote of 79.5% and 71.8% respectively. In 2003, Evergreen student Rachel Corrie was killed by a weaponized Caterpillar bulldozer operated by Israeli soldiers while protecting the home of a Palestinian family.

headline: South African Municipal Workers Union pledges support for BDS
summary: At its Central Executive Committee (CEC) meeting, the South African Municipal Workers Union (SAMWU), representing 160,000 workers, unanimously endorses a motion to work towards every municipality in South Africa becoming "an Apartheid Israel free zone."

headline: Pixies cancel concert in Israel
summary: American rock group Pixies cancel their first performance in Israel, citing "events beyond our control". They do not detail the reason for their decision, but human rights advocates had sent letters to the group and event organizers linked the decision to Israel’s attack on the Gaza Freedom Flotilla.

headline: Industrial Workers of the World vote to support Palestinian workers in call for BDS
summary: Members of the Industrial Workers of the World (IWW), an international labor union, vote overwhelming to adopt a resolution to support workers in Palestine by particpating in BDS. In a press release, they explain "by officially supporting this BDS call, the IWW stands shoulder to shoulder with Palestinian workers in a global picket line against Israeli apartheid.”

headline: Swedish Dockworkers Union blockades Israeli cargo to protest flotilla attack
summary: The Swedish Dockworkers Union refuses to handle shipments to and from Israel for two weeks in response to Israel's attack on the Gaza Freedom Flotilla in international water, which killed ten activists. On its website, the union states that the action is a "manifestation of solidarity after the request from the united Palestinian trade union movement" and calls for the end of Israel's blockade on Gaza.

headline: Norway’s largest trade union federation calls on state pension fund to divest from Israeli companies
summary: The Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions, Norway’s largest trade union federation comprising almost one fifth of the Norwegian population, calls on the country's State Pension Fund, the third largest in the world, to divest from all Israeli companies.

headline: Methodist Church of Great Britain votes to boycott Israeli products
summary: The Methodist Church of Great Britain publishes guidelines in support of BDS, stating that the government of Israel “must understand that failure to respond to international concerns over compliance with international law with respect to the occupied territories will come at a cost.”

headline: Gorillaz Sound System cancels concert in Israel
summary: The British band Gorillaz Sound System cancells a performance in Israel in the wake of the deadly Israeli attack on the Gaza Freedom Flotilla.

headline: Stephane Hessel, a French diplomat and Holocaust survivor, calls on global citizens to support BDS
summary: In a piece published by HuffPost, Stephane Hessel, a French diplomat, human rights activist, and Holocaust survivor, praises the Gaza Freedom Flotilla and says Israel's attack on it "rightfully stunned the world." He writes that "the absence of meaningful action from governments to hold Israel accountable to international law leaves open one path for citizens of conscience: to take this responsibility upon themselves, as done against apartheid South Africa...I believe that the BDS initiative is a moral strategy which has demonstrated its potential for success."

headline: Devendra Banhart cancels two concerts in Israel
summary: American folk singer Devendra Banhart cancels two scheduled concerts in Tel Aviv, commenting that "we tried to make it clear that we were coming to share a human and not a political message but it seems that we are being used to support views that are not our own" and said he would return when "our presence is perceived and reported on as a cultural event and not a political one." Banhart has previously performed in Israel.

headline: Swansea City Council in Wales bars future contracts with Veolia
summary: Swansea City Council in Wales opts to discontinue future contracts with Veolia, noting that the company "is a leading partner in a consortium seeking to build a light railway system linking Israel to illegal settlements in occupied East Jerusalem, a project that clearly not only contravenes UN demands but is in contravention of international law."

headline: Turkish Dock Workers Union joins boycott
summary: Turkey's Dock Workers Union refuses to unload Israeli cargo ships and calls for a comprehensive boycott against Israel in the wake of Israel's attack on the Gaza Freedom Flotilla in international water, which killed ten Turkish activists.

headline: Members of the International Longshore Workers Union, a California dockworkers union, refuse to unload Israeli ships
summary: Members of International Longshore Workers Union Local 10 in Oakland, California refuse to unload an Israeli ship at the dock at the request of local citizens protesting Israel’s blockade of Gaza and its recent attack on the Gaza Freedom Flotilla. The dockworkers cite a similar work stoppage they undertook in 1984 to protest South African apartheid.

headline: Abacus toy store in Spain pulls Israeli brand off shelves
summary: Following Israel's deadly attack on the Gaza Freedom Flotilla, the Abacus chain of toy stores in Spain decides to remove Rummikub, a popular game marketed by an Israeli company, from shelves in its 34 branches.

headline: Villanueva de Duero city council, Spain, removes Eden Springs water from government buildings
summary: The City Council of Villanueva de Duero decides to remove Eden-brand water products from government buildings after a campaign by local activists. Eden Springs is an Israeli water company that extracts water from the Salukia spring and bottles it in the settlement of Katzrin, both located in the illegally occupied Syrian Golan Heights.

headline: Actors refuse to attend Jerusalem Film Festival
summary: Organizers of the Jerusalem Film Festival claim that multiple Hollywood actors, such as Meg Ryan and Dustin Hoffman, are declining to participate in the annual Jerusalem Film Festival in the immediate aftermath of Israel’s attack on the Gaza Freedom Flotilla.

headline: Teachers and employees at Quebec colleges and universities endorse BDS
summary: A group of 80 teachers and employees at Quebec colleges and universities sign an open letter of support for BDS, writing "the struggle against apartheid in South Africa was supported through boycotts, divestment, and sanctions. We support a similar strategy against the Israeli state."

headline: Indian trade unions boycott Israeli ships and cargo arriving at the Cochin Port
summary: Trade unions in India boycott Israeli ships and cargo arriving at Cochin Port, one of the largest ports in India, in protest against the Israeli blockade of Gaza.

headline: Basque trade unions commit to BDS manifesto on fifth anniversary
summary: On the fifth anniversary of the Palestinian civil society call for BDS, an alliance of Basque trade unions issues a manifesto of support for BDS, stating that they "join this campaign because it relies on the defense of human rights as universal, indivisible and interdependent...and it is a civil means to change situations of injustice and institutional violence and move toward justice and peace."

headline: 80 Indian scholars and artists call for boycott
summary: Indian scholars and artists form the India Chapter of the Palestinian Campaign for the Academic and Cultural Boycott of Israel.

headline: Olympia Food Co-op boycotts Israeli goods
summary: The board of the Olympia Food Co-op in Washington decides by consensus to start boycotting Israeli goods. The decision falls under its boycott policy stating that "whenever possible, the Olympia Food Co-op should honor nationally recognized boycotts which are called for reasons that are compatible with our goals and mission statement.” The Co-op has also boycotted products made in China, in support of Tibetan human rights; Coca Cola products, due to union busting activities, particularly in South America; Colorado, due to anti-gay legislation passed in the early 90s; and more.

headline: UK electronic musicians Leftfield cancel Israel concert
summary: Leftfield cancels a performance at Heineken Music Conference in Israel, citing production problems. On their Facebook page, however, they post a copy of a letter from activists asking them to boycott.

headline: Queensland Teachers' Union votes in support of BDS
summary: The Queensland Teachers' Union in Australia, representing 46,000 teachers and principals in the Queensland Government's schools, passes a BDS resolution stating their willingness to "work towards building national support for the [BDS] campaign."

headline: 140 Irish artists pledge to boycott Israel
summary: In response to the call from Palestinian civil society for a cultural boycott of Israel, 140 Irish creative and performing artists pledge not to perform or exhibit in Israel, nor to accept any funding from Israeli institutions, until Israel comes into compliance with international law and universal principles of human rights.

headline: British group Faithless cancels Israel appearance
summary: UK electronic group Faithless cancels a planned performance in Israel and explains that the decision was for ethical reasons. Frontman Maxi Jazz says "while human beings are being willfully denied not just their rights but their NEEDS for their children and grandparents and themselves, I feel deeply that I should not be sending even tacit signals that this is either 'normal' or 'ok'."

headline: Norwegian government pension fund excludes Israeli companies
summary: The Norwegian Government Pension Fund Global divests from two Israeli companies, Africa Israel Investments and Danya Cebus, over their involvement in construction of illegal settlements in the West Bank.

headline: Cynthia Nixon, Mandy Patinkin, and Wallace Shawn among 150 US artists supporting boycott of settlement theatre
summary: More than 150 American actors, writers, directors and other artists sign a letter of support for a petition released by Israeli actors stating they would not perform at the new cultural center in the illegal settlement of Ariel in the West Bank. This includes prominent actors such as Cynthia Nixon, Mandy Patinkin, and Wallace Shawn.

headline: British filmmaker Mike Leigh cancels visit to Israel
summary: British film and theatre director Mike Leigh cancels a teaching trip to Israel, explaining that Israeli injustices gave him "serious misgivings about coming." He specifically mentions Israel's attack on the Gaza Freedom Flotilla, settlement expansion in the West Bank, and a loyalty oath bill that requires non-Jews seeking Israeli citizenship to pledge allegiance to Israel as a "Jewish and democratic state".

headline: Wave of Australian unions endorse BDS
summary: Australian unions and labour groups issue statements to endorse BDS after Israel's attack on the Gaza Freedom Flotilla. These unions include multiple Trades Hall and Labour Councils, Australian Health & Community Services Union, Australian Education Union, the Electrical Trades Union, the Australian Manufacturing Workers Union, the Construction Forestry Mining and Energy Union, the Finance Sector Union, the Australian Services Union, the Construction Forestry Mining Energy Union, and the Postal & Telecommunications Victorian Branch of the Communications Union of Australia (CEPU).

headline: Cork City Council votes not to sign or renew Veolia contracts
summary: Cork City Council in Ireland passes a motion to not sign or renew contracts with French multninational company Veolia due to its involvement in developing discriminatory railway infrastructure in Jerusalem to serve Israeli settlements.

headline: Rehabilitation and Research Centre for Torture Victims ends contract with G4S
summary: The Rehabilitation and Research Centre for Torture Victims (RCT) in Denmark ends its contract with G4S, the largest security company in the world, over its complicity in the Israeli prison system, explaining that “G4S as a company is helping to facilitate torture.”

headline: World Association of Community Radio Broadcasters (AMARC) endorses BDS at global conference
summary: The World Association of Community Radio Broadcasters (AMARC) passes a motion to support and participate in BDS at the AMARC global conference in La Plata, Argentina, which involved over 500 broadcasters from 87 countries.

headline: Major Dutch pension fund Pensioenfonds Zorg en Welzijn divests from Israeli companies
summary: Dutch pension fund Pensioenfonds Zorg en Welzijn (PFZW) divests from nearly all the Israeli companies in its portfolio following the adoption of new guidelines for socially responsible investment in companies operating in conflict zones.

headline: Malaysia Council of Churches endorses BDS call
summary: The Malaysia Council of Churches endorses the Kairos Palestine document issued by Palestinian Christians which calls for an end to the Israeli occupation of Palestinian land and endorses the use of BDS tactics, among other nonviolent means, to achieve that goal.

headline: Queensland Council of Unions votes to support BDS movement
summary: Queensland Council of Unions, with 26 affiliated unions, 13 regional branches, and 350,000 members in Australia, adopts a motion that includes support for BDS.

headline: Caerphilly Council in Wales passes motion to exclude Veolia from future contacts
summary: The Caerphilly County Borough Council in Wales passes a motion to exclude Veolia from any future contracts and not to renew existing contracts with the company because of its breaches of international law. Veolia is a French multi-national company involved in developing discriminatory infrastructure to serve Israeli settlements.

headline: Tindersticks cancel show in Israel
summary: English alternative rock band Tindersticks cancel concert in Israel, acknowledging that pressure from activists played a role and stating that "it is difficult to defy a rapidly growing movement."

headline: Veolia loses out on contract in Lille, France
summary: Veolia loses a bid to operate the metro, bus and tramlines in Lille, France amid a local BDS campaign against the company. A Veolia spokesperson admitted that BDS has damaged the image of Veolia.

headline: Edinburgh City Council rejects Veolia bid for environmental services contract
summary: Edinburgh City Councel removes Veolia from list of companies being considered for environmental services contracts, including refuse collection and street cleaning, following a campaign by local activists. Veolia is a French multi-national company involved in developing discriminatory infrastructure to serve Israeli settlements.

headline: Major UK retailer John Lewis drops settlements-based Israeli cosmetics company, Ahava, from its stores
summary: British retail chain John Lewis publicly announces that it has stopped stocking and selling Ahava products in an effort to become a more socially responsible company. Ahava cosmetics are produced in Israeli settlements in the West Bank, in violation of international law.

headline: Canadian retail chain, The Hudson Bay Company, drops Ahava from its stores
summary: Canadian retailer The Hudson Bay agrees to no longer stock Ahava products. Ahava is a cosmetics company located in the illegal Mitzpe Shalem settlement in the occupied West Bank, where it extracts minerals from the occupied shores of the Dead Sea without Palestinian permission or compensation, while labelling its products as products of Israel.

headline: Brazil's largest trade union joins BDS movement
summary: Central Única dos Trabalhadores (CUT), Brazil's largest trade union with 7.5 million members,  pledges to take concrete steps to work towards the overall success of the BDS movement.

headline: Vanessa Paradis cancels Israel concert following calls from fans and Palestine solidarity organizers
summary: French pop icon, Vanessa Paradis, cancels an upcoming concert in Tel Aviv. The decision follows multiple calls from BDS and humans rights campaigners, as well as pressure from fans.

headline: Five Norwegian PR firms reject offer to help "rebrand" Israel
summary: Five of Norway's top public relations companies, Geelmuyden.Keise, Gambit H&K, Apeland Informasjon, First House, and Kreab decline to be involved in project to "rebrand" Israel's global image.

headline: London council votes to sever ties with Veolia
summary: The council of Tower Hamlets, a borough in London, passes a motion to exclude Veolia from local procurement contracts  because of the company's involvement in Israeli violations of international law. Veolia is the target of global boycott campaigns because of its involvement with the Jerusalem Light Rail project, which connects West Jerusalem with illegal Israeli settlements in East Jerusalem and elsewhere in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Veolia loses out on Richmond council contract
summary: The council of Richmond upon Thames, a borough in London, votes not to renew a contract with Veolia. Veolia is the target of global boycott campaigns because of its involvement with the Jerusalem Light Rail project, which connects West Jerusalem with illegal Israeli settlements in East Jerusalem and elsewhere in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Norway's Electrician’s Union and Information Technology Union vote for BDS
summary: Norway’s consolidated Electrician’s Union and Information Technology Union, representing together about 30,000 electrical and IT workers in Norway, publishes a statement declaring that the Norwegian umbrella union organization should cut ties with the Histadrut (Israeli trade union group), and advocating a consumer boycott and Norwegian government sanctions.

headline: Pete Seeger joins BDS campaign
summary: Pete Seeger, considered one of the fathers of American folk music, endorses the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions (BDS) movement and contributes half the royalties from his song "Turn,Turn,Turn" to the Israeli Committee against House Demolitions.

headline: Triodos Bank excludes Dexia from investment portfolio
summary: Tridos Bank, which focuses on providing ethical and sustainable financial services, excludes Dexia bank from its ethical investment fund. Dexia Group is Franco-Belgian financial institution. Through its Israeli subsidiary, Dexia Israel, Dexia operates in Israeli settlements in the Occupied Palestinian Territories. Israel’s construction of settlements in the occupied West Bank, including East Jerusalem, is a war crime.

headline: Roger Waters of Pink Floyd calls for cultural boycott of Israel
summary: Roger Waters, member of the English rock band Pink Floyd, writes an opinion piece published  by the Guardian calling for the cultural boycott of Israel. He writes, “where governments refuse to act people must, with whatever peaceful means are at their disposal...for me this means declaring an intention to stand in solidarity, not only with the people of Palestine but also with the many thousands of Israelis who disagree with their government's policies, by joining the campaign of Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions against Israel.”

headline: Veolia loses out on £20 million contract in Portsmouth
summary: Portsmouth City Council chooses another bidder over Veolia for its garbage collection contract. A long-running campaign by local activists highlighted the company's complicity in Israel’s violations of international law via its involvement with the Jerusalem Light Rail project, which connects West Jerusalem with illegal Israeli settlements in East Jerusalem and elsewhere in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Edinburgh University students votes for boycott of Israeli products by “landslide”
summary: The Edinburgh University Students Association (EUSA) overwhelmingly passes a motion to support the boycott of Israeli good on campus.

headline: Electricians and IT Workers Union based in Norway (EL & IT) endorse BDS movement
summary: Electricians and IT Workers Union (EL & IT) fin Norway endorse BDS and vote for further action to divest

headline: Episcopal Church's National Cathedral removes Ahava products
summary: The Episcopal Church's National Cathedral gift shop decides to drop Ahava products from its shelves after receiving complaints about Ahava and its practices. Ahava is a target of global boycott campaigns because it obtains resources for its products from the Dead Sea in the West Bank and produces these products in an illegal settlement, also located in the West Bank.

headline: The London School of Economics decides not to renew Eden Springs contract
summary: The London School of Economics decides not to renew a contract with Eden Springs following a campaign by the Palestine Society of the London School of Economics' Student Union. Eden Springs sources and bottles its water in the occupied Golan Heights.

headline: University of Johannesburg ends relationship with Israeli university
summary: The Senate of the University of Johannesburg votes to cut ties with Ben-Gurion University following a petition that gained 400 signatures by scholars across South Africa. Archbishop Desmond Tutu says "Israeli Universities are an intimate part of the Israeli regime, by active choice."

headline: Protests push Ahava out of London's Covent Garden
summary: Shaftesbury PLC, a company that owns some properties on Covent Garden, announces that it will not renew Ahava's lease on their property following campaigns by local activists. Ahava is a target of global boycott campaigns because it obtains resources for its products from the Dead Sea in the occupied West Bank and produces these products in an illegal settlement, also located in the West Bank.

headline: Veolia fails to win $1.6 billion contract in South London
summary: Veolia is dropped from consideration for a $1.6 billion (£1 billion) garbage collection contract in South London amidst a vocal campaign by local activists focused on its role in human rights abuses against Palestinians. Veolia is involved with the Jerusalem Light Railway project, which connects West Jerusalem with illegal Israeli settlements in East Jerusalem and elsewhere in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Brazilian Labor Federation Central Sindical e Popular Conlutas endorses BDS call
summary: In an open letter to the Palestinian BDS National Committee, Labor Federation CSP-Conlutas states that it voted to endorse BDS in its national coordination meeting. CSP-Conlutas has protested the 2008-2009 Israeli War on Gaza and sent representatives to Palestine and Beirut as a show of solidarity in the past. CSP-Conlutas is working with the BDS campaign against the Free Trade Agreement between Israel and Brazil and against the operation of Israeli companies Elbit Systems and Strauss Coffee in Brazil.

headline: South African Christians support the Palestine Kairos call
summary: Kairos South Africa states, "[we] stand in solidarity with Palestinians in their commitment towards non-violent resistance against the occupation [and] support the call towards boycotts, divestments and sanctions (BDS) against the Israeli government." Kairos South Africa also commits to promoting ethical pilgrimages and tours of the Holy Land while denouncing Christian support for Zionism.

headline: Swedish Pension Funds call on Motorola, Alstom, and Veolia to pull out of occupied West Bank
summary: The Ethical Council of the four Swedish pension funds call on Veolia to withdraw from the Jerusalem light rail project. Veolia continues to lose billions of dollars in contracts in the United Kingdom throughout 2011. The pension funds also calls on Motorola and Alstom to end business activities in the occupied West Bank.

headline: 51 filmmakers protest Hot Docs' partnership with Israel
summary: After Hot Docs announces its decision to partner with the Israeli organization CoPro Documentary Marketing Foundation, 51 Canadian filmmakers collectively write a letter to the co-chairs of the board of directors of Hot Docs protesting the decision to support the foundation, stating that by partnering with CoPro, Hot Docs would be complicit in the ongoing oppression of Palestinians.

headline: Deutsche Bahn pulls out of Israeli rail project
summary: Deutsche Bahn, the state-owned German railway operator, confirms that it has dropped out of an Israeli high speed rail project that connects Tel Aviv to Jerusalem and cuts through the occupied West Bank. Germany’s ministry for transport states in a letter to a member of parliament that the project is "problematic from a foreign policy point of view" and "potentially breaches international law."

headline: Cornel West endorses BDS
summary: In a statement endorsing the BDS movement, Cornel West describes BDS tactics as an effective and nonviolent means of creating political and economic pressure powerful enough to challenge injustices ranging from racial segregation and foreign occupation to illegal expropriation of land.

headline: Largest student union in Europe endorses BDS
summary: The University of London Union, the largest student union in Europe with over 120,000 members, votes to endorse and institute BDS.

headline: Dexia Bank announces sale of Israeli subsidiary
summary: The French-Belgian Dexia Bank Group sells off its 65% stake in Dexia-Israel following a sustained international campaign. Through its Israeli subsidiary, Dexia Israel, Dexia operates in Israeli settlements in the Occupied Palestinian Territories. Israel’s construction of settlements in the occupied West Bank, including East Jerusalem, is a war crime.

headline: Veolia loses out on £30 million contract in southern England
summary: Veolia loses out on a joint garbage collection contrcat from East Hampshire and Winchester City worth £30 million. Veolia is the target of global boycott campaigns because of its involvement with the Jerusalem Light Rail project, which connects West Jerusalem with illegal Israeli settlements in East Jerusalem and elsewhere in the occupied West Bank.

headline: DePaul students vote to boycott Sabra hummus
summary: DePaul University’s Student Government Association votes to remove Sabra hummus from campus dining halls. Strauss Group Ltd., the parent company of Sabra Dipping Company, LLC, provides financial support and supplies to the Israeli army, which is responsible for enforcing Israel’s illegal military occupation of Palestinian land.

headline: UK transport union demands no new contracts with Veolia
summary: The Transport and Salaried Staff Association, a union of 17,000 transportation workers in the UK, passes a motion at its 2011 Annual Conference demanding no new contracts with Veolia.

headline: Basketball legend Kareem Abdul-Jarrar decides not to visit Israel
summary: Basketball star and actor Kareem Abdul-Jabbar decides not to visit Israel to attend the Jerusalem Film Festival citing “concerns arising from Nakba day violence.”

headline: Egyptian Independent Union Federation endorses BDS
summary: The Egyptian Independent Union Federation endorses the BDS movement and calls on global trade unions to also support the movement.

headline: Angela Davis and other feminists endorse BDS
summary: The prominent activist-scholar Angela Davis and ten other leading feminists declare their "unequivocal support" for the BDS movement after being "shocked" at what they saw during a visit to Palestine.

headline: International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer & Intersex Youth and Student Organization (IGLYO) moves conference from Tel Aviv
summary: The International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer & Intersex Youth and Student Organization (IGLYO) withdraws their plans to host their annual General Assembly conference in Tel Aviv following a campaign by Palestinian queer groups.

headline: Veolia loses out on $490 million West London contract
summary: Councilors in Ealing, a town in the west of London, choose not to select Veolia for a $490 million (£300 million), 15 year contract following engagement with local activists. Veolia is the target of global boycott campaign because of its involvement with the Jerusalem Light Rail project, which connects West Jerusalem with illegal Israeli settlements in East Jerusalem and elsewhere in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Jazz and blues band Tuba Skinny cancels show in Israel
summary: Tuba Skinny, a jazz and blues band from New Orleans, cancels their show at a jazz festival in Eilat, Israel after receiving an open letter from the Palestinian Call for the Academic and Cultural Boycott of Israel.

headline: Pianists Eddie Palmieri and Jason Moran cancel shows in Israel
summary: Grammy Award-winning pianist Eddie Palmieri and jazz musician Jason Moran cancel their appearances at the Red Sea International Jazz festival following calls for boycott.

headline: Turkey removes Israeli ambassador and cuts military ties to Israel over Gaza flotilla row
summary: Turkey's foreign minister says that the Israeli ambassador will leave the country within days and that miltary ties to Israel will be cut. These decisions were made after Israel refused to apologize for its 2010 deadly raid on the Gaza Freedom Flotilla.

headline: Singer Denise Jannah regrets recent tour in Israel and endorses BDS
summary: Dutch jazz soloist Denise Jannah openly states that she regrets going on tour in Israel, supports the Palestinian people, and endorses BDS.

headline: Agrexco, an Israeli agricultural produce company, ordered to liquidate
summary: Agrexco, an Israeli agricultural company partially owned by the state, is ordered to liquidate after defaulting on its debts. Argrexco faced a campaign of boycotts, demonstrations, lobbying, and legal action in more than 13 countries across Europe due to its role in subsidizing and exporting agricultural products produced in illegal Israeli settlements in the occupied Palestinian territory.

headline: Singer Natacha Atlas cancels concert in Israel and joins boycott
summary: Internationally-acclaimed artist Natacha Atlas cancels her concert in Israel, saying that she hopes her decision is an effective statement against the Israeli regime. She further announces support for boycott, writing that she will "not go to Israel until this systemised apartheid is abolished once and for all."

headline: More than 200 Swedish scholars call for an academic boycott of Israel
summary: A group of more than 200 students, professors, and lecturers in Sweden demand that Swedish universities cease academic cooperation with Israeli institutions. They also reiterate previous calls from Irish academics in 2006 and 2009 for the European Union to stop treating Israel as a European State for the purposes of research funding.

headline: Screenwriter and film director John Michael McDonagh cancels attendance at Haifa International Film Festival
summary: John Michael McDonagh cancels his planned appearance at the Haifa International Film Festival following calls for boycott from the Palestinian Campaign for the Academic and Cultural Boycott of Israel. He states that the political situation in Israel led to his decision.

headline: Kings College London students vote to condemn Ahava project
summary: The student union at Kings College London votes to condemn the involvement of the university in an EU-funded research project partnering with Ahava, an Israeli cosmetics company operating in an illegal Israeli settlement and extracting resources from occupied territory.

headline: Musician Hosam Hayek cancels appearance at Jerusalem Oud Festival
summary: Hosam Hayek cancels his performance at the Jerusalem Oud Festival. In an open letter to his fans, he states that his decision is linked to ethics and that his red lines are clear.

headline: Edinburgh University Student Association votes to drop G4S
summary: The Edinburgh University Student Association (EUSA) votes overwhelmingly for a motion to cancel its contract with G4S.

headline: Yardbirds cancel concert in Israel
summary: The Yardbirds cancel their concert in Israel after being approached by activists and fans. One letter, written by a group of intellectuals in London, appeals to the Yardbirds by referencing their opposition to South African apartheid.

headline: Cambridge University students call on university to end contract with Veolia
summary: Students at Cambridge University in the UK vote to call on the University to cut ties with Veolia over its business activities tied to illegal Israeli settlements. Veolia is contracted by the university for waste disposal.

headline: Edinburgh University students vote to ban G4S
summary: The Edinburgh University Students Association adopts a motion to ban G4S from its campus. G4S is the target of international boycott campaigns because it provides security services to illegal Israeli settlements, checkpoints and Israeli prisons where Palestinians are detained.

headline: Alstom loses Saudi Haramain Railway contract worth $10 billion
summary: Alstom loses the bid for the second phase of the Saudi Haramain Railway project, worth $10 billion after pressure from the BDS campaign. Alstom, a French transport company, is the target of global boycott campaigns because of its involvement with the Jerusalem Light Rail project, which connects West Jerusalem to illegal Israeli settlements in occupied East Jerusalem and elsewhere in the West Bank.

headline: Martha Frintzila cancels participation at Jerusalem Oud Festival
summary: After pressure from activist groups in Greece and her fans, Greek actress and singer Martha Frintzila cancels her show at the Jerusalem Oud Festival for conscientious and political reasons.

headline: Glasgow Caledonian University students vote to cancel Eden Springs contract
summary: Glasgow Caledonian University Students Parliament (students representative council) vote to cancel the university’s Eden Springs contract––with no votes against––due to the company's operations on Israeli-occupied land in the Golan Heights.

headline: Rho City Council passes resolution construction company involved in settlement project
summary: The City Council of Rho, in the province of Milan, approves a resolution expressing “moral and political condemnation of Pizzarotti for its participation in the project for the construction of the A1 Jerusalem – Tel Aviv railway”. Pizzarotti is an Italian construction company that is involved with the Jerusalem Light Rail project, which connects West Jerusalem with illegal Israeli settlements in East Jerusalem and elsewhere in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Veolia excluded from $760 million West London contract
