summary: The West London Waste Authority excludes Veolia from a $760 million (£485 million) waste contract covering 1.4 million inhabitants of the London boroughs of Brent, Ealing, Harrow, Hillingdon, Hounslow and Richmond-upon-Thames, following campaigning by activists. Veolia is the target of global boycott campaigns because of its involvement with the Jerusalem Light Rail project, which connects West Jerusalem with illegal Israeli settlements in East Jerusalem and elsewhere in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Amnesty International Denmark terminates G4S contract
summary: Amnesty International Denmark terminates its contract with G4S “because the company’s global activities do not live up to Amnesty International’s requirements for corporate action in relation to human rights”.

headline: Noted French theorist Jacques Rancière cancels Israel lecture
summary: Noted French philosopher and political theorist Jacques Rancière cancels a visit to Israel after an appeal by the Palestinian Campaign for the Academic and Cultural Boycott of Israel (PACBI).

headline: Swedish Mul-T-Lock manufacturer Assa Abloy withdraws from illegal Israeli settlement
summary: Giant Swedish Mul-T-Lock manufacturer Assa Abloy closes its factory in the illegal Israeli settlement of Barkan after pressure from human rights organizations and the Church of Sweden.

headline: American musician Cat Power cancels Israel show
summary: The award-winning singer-songwriter Cat Power cancels her show in Tel Aviv, tweeting, “music is healing and it is not humane if all cannot have the choice, the right, to attend."

headline: University of Regina Students' Union passes motion supporting the BDS movement
summary: The University of Regina Students' Union passes a motion to support the Boycott, Divestment, Sanctions (BDS) movement on campus “as a means of pressuring Israel to comply with international and human rights law.”

headline: Singer Cassandra Wilson cancels Israel show
summary: American jazz vocalist Cassandra Wilson cancels her appearance at a festival in Israel following pressure from BDS activists.

headline: DaitoCrea Japan stops carrying Ahava products
summary: DaitoCrea Japan, the general agent in Japan for Ahava Dead Sea Laboratories, announces that they will no longer distribute Ahava products following engagement with local organizers. Ahava obtains resources for its products from the Dead Sea in the occupied West Bank and produces products in an illegal Israeli settlement.

headline: Judge throws out Israeli-backed lawsuit against Olympia Food Co-op
summary: Washington Superior Court Judge Thomas McPhee dismisses a lawsuit designed to force the Olympia Food Co-op to rescind its boycott of Israeli goods.The judge rules that the lawsuit, brought by boycott opponents with connections to the pro-Israel group StandWithUs, violated a Washington State law designed to prevent abusive lawsuits aimed at suppressing lawful public participation. The judge also upheld the constitutionality of the law in question: Washington State's anti-SLAPP (Strategic Litigation Against Public Participation) statute.

headline: Slumdog Millionaire author Vikas Swarup cancels Israel appearance
summary: Slumdog Millionaire author Vikas Swarup cancels his appearance at the International Writers Festival in Israel after being contacted by the Indian Campaign for the Academic & Cultural Boycott of Israel.

headline: Glasgow University drops Eden Springs
summary: Glasgow University cancels its contract with Eden Springs and commits to refraining from giving the company contracts in the future. This move follows a campaign by the Glasgow University Palestine Society to pressure the university to cancel its contract with the company. Eden Springs sources and bottles its water in the occupied Golan Heights.

headline: Blue Planet endorses BDS movement
summary: Blue Planet, a global water justice group, endorses the BDS movement. This move follows the release of a report that Blue Planet co-authored with the LifeSource, a grassroots Palestinian collective focusing upon water rights under Israeli occupation. Both groups cite the following rationale: "Israel is demolishing Palestinian water and sanitation infrastructure, cutting water to Palestinian communities and using military force to prevent Palestinians from drilling wells and accessing their fair share of transboundary water resources."

headline: Seattle LGBT Commission cancels event sponsored by Israeli Consulate
summary: The Seattle LGBT Commission votes to cancel an event, scheduled to be held at Seattle City Hall, sponsored by the Israeli Consulate and the Israeli right wing group StandWithUS. The vote to cancel reflected concerns that the planned event was part of an effort to "pinkwash" the ongoing Israeli occupation and Israeli human rights violations.

headline: University of Birmingham student union votes to join broader national student campaign to divest from Veolia and Eden Springs
summary: The University of Birmingham student union votes to join the National Union of Students (NUS) campaign to divest from Eden Springs and Veolia, due to their human rights abuses in the Israeli occupied West Bank and Golan Heights, and to lobby the university not to renew its contract with Veolia when that contract expires. Eden Springs sources and bottles its water in the occupied Golan Heights. Veolia is involved in the Jerusalem Light Railway project, servicing illegal Israeli settlements in the West Bank.

headline: Carleton University students pass divestment resolution
summary: The Carleton University Graduate Students' Association votes overwhelmingly in support of a resolution that Carleton University divest from companies which profit from illegal Israeli occupation and Israeli human rights abuses.

headline: Major Norwegian retail chain drops Ahava
summary: Norwegian retail chain VITA announces it will stop all sales of products originating from settlements in the occupied Palestinian territories, including products from the cosmetics brand Ahava. Ahava products are sourced and produced in illegal settlements in the West Bank.

headline: Veolia loses contract in East Sussex
summary: The joint waste project manager of East Sussex in the United Kingdom confirms that Veolia are no longer involved in the procurement process for the joint waste collection, amid a vigorous campaign by local activists to exclude the company.

headline: M.E.Ch.A., a large U.S. Latin@ youth association, endorses Palestinian call for BDS
summary: The largest association of Latin@ youth in the United States, M.E.Ch.A. (Movímíento Estudíantíl Chícan@ de Aztlán), votes overwhelmingly to endorse the Palestinian call for BDS action. The announcement comes on Palestinian Land Day, a day commemorating Palestinians who lost their lives when protesting land confiscations by Israel in 1976.

headline: Columbia University professor Katherine Franke joins academic boycott of conference sponsored by Israeli government
summary: Professor Katherine Franke, director of the Center for Gender & Sexuality Law at Columbia University, declares that she will boycott the annual Global LGBT Summit due to Israeli government sponsorship. Professor Franke explains that the Summit's organizer, the Equality Forum, is allowing itself "to be used as a part of Israel’s larger efforts to deflect criticisms of its human rights record.”

headline: Palestinians launch Stop G4S campaign
summary: Palestinian organizations formally launch the Stop G4S campaign, targeting the largest security company in the world, as Palestinian political prisoners begin a historic hunger strike. In 2005, G4S signed a contract with the Israeli Prison Service to provide services and supply and maintain equipment at Israeli prisons, where Palestinians are held without charge, tried in military courts, and tortured. G4S also provides services to the Israeli military and illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: European Union drops G4S
summary: The European Union decides not to renew its contract with G4S, due in part to the company’s complicity with Israeli violations of international law and Palestinian human rights.

headline: Moroccan authorities cancel Israeli bellydance festival in Marrakesh
summary: Following pressure from Moroccan activists, Moroccan authorities cancel the second Mediterranean Delight International Belly Dance Festival, which was to take place in Marrakesh. The festival was created by Israeli producers and is partly sponsored by the Israeli business Sea of Spa, which has ties to the cosmetics company Ahava. Ahava operates in an illegal settlement in the West Bank.

headline: University of Massachusetts Undergraduate Student Government passes divestment resolution
summary: The University of Massachusetts Boston Undergraduate Student Government unanimously passes a bill demanding that the UMass Foundation, the university's investment fund, divest from Boeing and other companies profiting from war crimes and/or human rights violations. The bill specifically highlights Boeing's connection to Operation Cast Lead, Israel’s 3-week military onslaught against the Gaza Strip in 2008-09.

headline: Egyptian Football Association decides to boycott Adidas
summary: The Egyptian Football Association decides to boycott Adidas due to the latter's sponsorship of the Jerusalem Marathon, an event organized in conjunction with the Israeli Jerusalem Municipality, which is a key perpetrator of systematic policies of ethnic cleansing, colonisation, and apartheid in Jerusalem.

headline: UK supermarket chain boycotts settlement companies
summary: The Co-operative Group supermarket chain announces that it will end trade with a group of companies that source products from Israel’s illegal colonies built on occupied Palestinian land. The group is the first major supermarket in Europe to introduce measures to end trade with all companies that operate in or export from illegal Israeli settlements in occupied Palestinian territory.

headline: Irish band Dervish pulls out of Israel concerts
summary: Dervish, an Irish band, announces that they will pull out of concerts in Israel. The band explains that, prior to agreeing to perform, they were unaware of the cultural boycott. Dervish's decision comes after the band received a letter from the Ireland Palestine Solidarity Committee, asking that it reconsider proceeding with the performances.

headline: Famed musician Zakir Hussain calls off Israel visit
summary: Tabla maestro Zakir Hussain calls off a series of scheduled performances in Israel, following an appeal made by 85 artists, writers and activists.

headline: Quaker Friends Fiduciary Corporation divests from Caterpillar
summary: The Quaker Friends Fiduciary Corporation (FFC) divests its $900,000 shares of Caterpillar stock. Caterpillar produces and sells to Israel weaponized bulldozers used to violate Palestinian rights and to destroy Palestinian homes, schools, hospitals, and olive groves.

headline: South Africa and Denmark rule that products made in illegal settlements may not be labelled as products of Israel
summary: South Africa and Denmark require that products originating from illegal Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank be labelled as such.

headline: Veolia loses out on public transportation contract in The Hague
summary: The Dutch local authority for the urban district Haaglanden, where the Hague is located, decides not to award Veolia's Dutch subsidiary the public transport contract for all bus transportation in The Hague’s city district. The move follows objections by Palestinian activist groups to inclusion of the Veolia subsidiary in the bidding process. Veolia, a French multinational, is the target of global boycott campaigns because of its involvement with the Jerusalem Light Railway project, which connects West Jerusalem to illegal Jewish settlements in occupied East Jerusalem and elsewhere in the West Bank.

headline: Swedish Trade Union Confederation boycotts settlement goods
summary: The Swedish Trade Union Confederation, the central organization for 14 affiliates which organize workers in both the private and public sectors, votes to support the boycott of Israeli goods from occupied territories. The Confederation also votes to work to ensure that capital over which it has control is not invested in Israeli securities.

headline: Swiss supermarket chain blocks false labelling of products made in illegal settlements
summary: The Swiss supermarket chain, Migros, blocks use of the label "Made in Israel" on all products that are made in illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: Evergreen State College's student-run café, The Flaming Eggplant Café, votes to boycott Israeli goods
summary: The student-run collective The Flaming Eggplant Café, at Evergreen State College in Olympia, Washington, announces its decision to boycott Israeli goods and its support of the BDS movement. This action follows the 2010 passage by the Evergreen student body of a resolution barring use of Caterpillar, Inc. equipment on campus. Evergreen student Rachel Corrie was killed in 2003 by a weaponized Caterpillar bulldozer, operated by the Israeli military, as she defended Palestinan homes against illegal demolition.

headline: Arizona State University students vote to demand university divest from companies supplying weapons to Israel
summary: The undergraduate student government at Arizona State University (ASU) unanimously passes a bill demanding that ASU divest from and blacklist companies that continue to provide the Israeli Defense Forces with weapons and militarized equipment or are complicit with the genocidal regime in Darfur.

headline: Norway's finance ministry excludes Israeli firm from pension fund portfolio
summary: Norway's finance ministry excludes Shikun & Binui from the portfolio of the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG), the largest pension fund in Europe. Shikun & Binui is considered Israel's largest real estate company and has been involved in constructing illegal settlements in East Jerusalem.

headline: US pension fund giant divests from Caterpillar
summary: TIAA, a U.S. pension giant, removes Caterpillar from its Social Choice Funds portfolio, divesting $72 million in shares from the company. Caterpillar supplies bulldozers to Israel, which uses them to demolish Palestinian civilian homes, destroy crops and agricultural land in the occupied territories, and build illegal, Jewish-only settlements on Palestinian land.

headline: Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) drops Caterpillar from list of responsible companies
summary: Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI), a leading provider of socially responsible investing indices that funds use to monitor and determine their investments, removes Caterpillar from its Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) indices following its decision to downgrade the company's ESG rating. MSCI cites several reasons for this decision, one of them being the "ongoing controversy associated with use of the company’s equipment in the occupied Palestinian territories."

headline: Presbyterian Church (USA) votes to boycott Israeli settlement products
summary: The Presbyterian Church (USA) passes a resolution calling for the boycott of all products from Israeli colonial settlements in the occupied Palestinian territory. The resolution also calls upon all countries to ban the import of such products until Palestinians are able to realize their rights and achieve independence.

headline: Abigail Disney divests from Ahava
summary: Abigail Disney, the granddaughter of Roy O. Disney, who co-founded The Walt Disney Company with his brother Walt, announces she is disclaiming her share of investments in the cosmetics company Ahava, due to Ahava's location in an Israeli settement in the occupied West Bank.  Disney says she will donate the profits and a sum equal to the worth of her shares to "organizations working to end this illegal exploitation."

headline: Danish Church Aid cuts ties with G4S
summary: Danish Church Aid announces that it will not renew its contract with G4S due to the company's involvement with illegal Israeli settlements, following action by Amnesty International Denmark to cut ties with G4S in January.

headline: British energy firm severs ties with G4S
summary: British firm Good Energy announces that it will sever its business relationship with G4S. The move follows protests and pressure from local activists. G4S is a multinational security company that provides equipment and services to Israeli prisons and checkpoints in the occupied West Bank.

headline: The United Church of Canada votes to pursue boycott of Israeli settlement products
summary: The United Church of Canada votes to affirm a resolution to boycott products produced in illegal Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank.

headline: University of Witwatersrand students join academic and cultural boycott of Israel
summary: The University of Witwatersrand Student Representative Council unanimously passes a resolution to join the academic and cultural boycott of Israeli academic and cultural institutions, responding to the call by Palestinian civil society for BDS.

headline: Mashrou' Leila cancels opening performance after Red Hot Chili Peppers rejects BDS call
summary: Mashrou' Leila, a Lebanese band, cancels its opening act for Red Hot Chili Peppers after the latter group openly rejects a call from Palestinian activists to join the BDS movement and to cancel their scheduled performance in Tel Aviv.

headline: Earlham College dining services boycotts Sabra products
summary: The dining service at Earlham College decides to stop selling Sabra Hummus in the school's coffee shop. The move comes after students and faculty request removal of Sabra products, due to Sabra's involvement with Israeli human rights violations. Strauss Group Ltd., the parent company of Sabra Dipping Company, LLC, provides financial support and supplies to the Israeli army, which is responsible for enforcing Israel’s illegal military occupation of Palestinian land.

headline: University of California Student Association condemns anti-BDS bill introduced in California Assembly
summary: The University of California Student Association (Association) approves a landmark resolution opposing California Assembly Bill HR 35, which seeks to stifle Palestinian solidarity activism on University of California (UC) campuses under the guise of combating anti-Semitism. The resolution includes the Association's affirmation of the legitimacy of boycotts and divestments as important social movement tools and encourages divestment from companies profiting from violations of international human rights law.

headline: The Norwegian Ministry of Finance bans tax deductions for donations to Israeli settlements
summary: The Norwegian Ministry of Finance announces that it will ban tax deductions for organizations that send donations that benefit illegal Israeli settlements. The move follows pressure from both Norwegian People’s Aid and the Norwegian Union of Municipal and General Employees.

headline: Danish Merkur Bank ends G4S contracts
summary: Merkur, a Danish bank with an ethical profile, ends their G4S contracts, citing the company's “involvement in the Israeli occupation of Palestine”

headline: Quaker Friends Fiduciary Corporation divests from Veolia and Hewlett Packard
summary: The Quaker Friends Fiduciary Corporation (FFC) divests its $390,000 in shares of both Hewlett Packard and Veolia Environment. FFC notes that Hewlett Packard provides information consulting services to the Israeli Navy. Veolia Environment, the world's largest water privatization company, provides segregated water services to Israeli settlers in the occupied Palestinian territories and runs a large landfill in the occupied Jordan River valley.

headline: Palestine footballer rejects invite by FC Barcelona to attend match, citing Barcelona's official invite to Israeli soldier
summary: Palestinian footballer Mahmoud Sarsak, who was held in Israeli detention for 3 years, refuses an invitation from FC Barcelona to attend a match with Real Madrid, citing FC Barcelona's decision to also extend an invitation to Galid Shalit, an Israeli soldier. Sarsak states he refuses "to be used as a fig-leaf by FC Barcelona, a club that I deeply admire."

headline: Several musicians pull out of Creative Time Summit, citing summit's link to institution funded by Israeli government
summary: Hip Hop duo Rebel Diaz, hip hop artist The Narcicyst (Yassin Alsalman) and the Egyptian media collective Mosireen cancel their participation in the Creative Time Summit, a festival of public art, speeches and forums, citing the summit's partnership with an institution funded by the Israeli government.

headline: Artists pull out of Israeli embassy-sponsored Salam.Orient festival
summary: Palestinian MC Boikutt, Syrian singer Lena Chamamyan, Lebanese MC Malikah (Lynn Fattouh), Palestine's MC DJ Sotusura and Palestinian oud player Marwan Abado cancel their participation in Austria's Salam.Orient music festival, citing the Israeli Embassy's co-sponsorship of the event as the reason for their boycott.

headline: Over 60 artists protest Israeli Philharmonic Orchestra invite
summary: Palestinian spoken word artist Remi Kenazi and Pink Floyd’s Roger Waters join dozens of other cultural figures, including Pulitzer Prize - winning author Alice Walker, calling upon New York's Carnegie Hall to cancel the scheduled performance of the Israeli Philharmonic Orchestra (IPO). The artists' call points out that the IPO whitewashes Israel’s ethnic cleansing of indigenous Palestinians.

headline: Dutch council rejects Veolia bid for transportation contract
summary: The Utrecht Regional Council rejects a bid by Veolia for a transportation contract following pressure from local activists. Veolia is the target of global boycott campaigns because of its involvement with the Jerusalem Light Railway project, which connects West Jerusalem with illegal Israeli settlements in East Jerusalem and elsewhere in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Sheffield University students vote to support BDS
summary: The Sheffield University Students' Union passes a motion to join the global BDS movement against Israel.

headline: Canterbury City Council rejects $63.5 million Veolia contract bid
summary: The Canterbury City Council rejects a bid from Veolia Environment for a $63.5 million waste management contract, opting instead to grant the contract to Serco. The move comes after local activists campaigned to draw attention to Veolia's ties to the Israeli occupation of Palestine.

headline: Technical University of Denmark drops out of collaboration with Ariel University
summary: The Technical University of Denmark halts collaboration with Ariel University, which is based in an illegal Israeli settlement in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Univ. of Calif. Irvine students vote to call for divestment from companies assisting Israeli occupation
summary: The Associated Students of University of California Irvine vote unanimously to call for divestment from companies that assist or directly profit from Israeli occupation and human rights abuses.

headline: York University graduate students vote to endorse BDS
summary: The Graduate Students’ Association at York University, Canada's third largest university, votes in favour of a resolution supporting the BDS movement.

headline: Stevie Wonder cancels benefit concert for Israeli military
summary: Stevie Wonder cancels a performance at a Los Angeles fundraiser for Friends of the IDF (FIDF), an organization that raises money for the Israeli army, following pressure from pro-Palestinian activists. An FIDF press release noted "representatives of the performer cited a recommendation from the United Nations to withdraw his participation."

headline: Prominent footballers call on European football federation to withdraw Under 21 tournament in Israel
summary: Prominent footballers, many from English Premier League and first division teams in Europe, sign a letter condemining Israel's attacks on Gaza and opposing the European football federation (UEFA)'s decision to host the Under-21 European Championship in Israel. Among the signatories are Demba Ba and four other players from Newcastle United, Eden Hazard of Chelsea as well as players from Arsenal, Queens Park Rangers and West Ham United, all Premier League clubs.

headline: Global trade union Public Services International joins BDS movement
summary: The Public Services International, one of the the world's largest global trade unions, votes at its World Congress to fully support and advance the BDS campaign and to adopt a resolution to promote and participate in the annual Israel Apartheid Week initiative.

headline: University of Oslo ends its contract with G4S
summary: Following pressure from student activists with the Palestine Committee at the University of Oslo, the university decides not to renew its contract with G4S. G4S is a private security company that provides equipment and services to Israeli prisons where Palestinian political prisoners, including child prisoners, are detained and mistreated. G4S also provides equipment and services to checkpoints, illegal settlements and businesses in settlements.

headline: Elbit Systems and Israel Aerospace Industries pull out of industry convention
summary: Elbit Systems and Israel Aerospace Industries (IAI) are forced to pull out of a major international aerospace industry convention in France, following pressure from local BDS activists. Elbit Systems and IAI are Israeli arms companies that supply drones to the Israeli military and have assisted in the building of the apartheid wall.

headline: University of Toronto graduate students endorse BDS
summary: The University of Toronto's Graduate Student Union, with a 97% vote, passes a resolution supporting the BDS campaign. The resolution calls upon the university to refrain from investing in any company that profits from the illegal occupation of Palestinian land, directly benefits from the construction of the wall and Israeli settlements, is economically active in settlements, and/or profits from the collective punishment of Palestinians.

headline: New Zealand national pension fund divests from four Israeli companies
summary: The New Zealand Superannuation Fund, New Zealand's $20 billion national pension fund, divests from Elbit Systems, Africa Israel, and Shikun & Binui because of their involvement in Israeli human rights abuses in the occupied Palestinian territory.

headline: African National Congress International Solidarity Conference declares support of BDS actions against Israel
summary: The International Solidarity Conference of the African National Congress (ANC), the ruling party in South Africa, announces its support for the BDS campaign against Israel.

headline: Veolia Water North America withdraws as prospective bidder for $325 million contract in California
summary: Veolia Water North America withdraws as a prospective bidder on a $325 million project to provide treated water from the Sacramento River to residents of Woodland and Davis in Yolo County, California. Veolia's withdrawal follows efforts by citizens of Yolo County to prevent Veolia from bidding due to the company's involvement in the Jerusalem Light Railway project, servicing illegal Israeli settlements, its operation of settler-only buses on segregated roads in the occupied West Bank, and its operation of a landfill on land confiscated from Palestinians.

headline: Veolia abandons North London contract bid
summary: Veolia withdraws its bid for a $7 billion North London Waste Authority project as local activists petitioned against the selection of Veolia, one day after withdrawing a bid from a $325 million project in Yolo County, California.

headline: Two Dutch charities drop G4S
summary: Two Dutch charities, the Food Bank in Utrecht and Jantje Beton, which promotes free outdoor play for children, announce that they will no longer cooperate with or accept donations from G4S over the company's role in human rights abuses against Palestinian children.

headline: Five main Unions in Galicia in Spanish state adopt BDS
summary: Five major trade unions in the Galicia region of the Spanish state release a manifesto announcing their support for BDS "as the most effective means of ending the colonial occupation and apartheid in Palestine and holding Israel accountable to international law in order to restore peace."

headline: American jazz guitarist Stanley Jordan cancels appearance at Israeli jazz fest
summary: Grammy-nominated American jazz artist Stanley Jordan drops out of Israel’s Red Sea Jazz Festival, where he was slated to be a headliner. Leading up to the cancellation, Jordan acknowledged  "I've received several messages from people requesting I cancel cancel my performance" and invited dialogue with fans. He said the discussion "revealed a crisis whose depth was even far greater than I had known."

headline: German band Kreator cancels Israel Show in Tel Aviv
summary: Kreator, a thrash metal band from Essen, Germany, cancels a show in Tel Aviv following boycott pressure. The band says the cancellation is due to "medical conditions of one of the musicians", but other dates on the tour have not been cancelled.

headline: Umeå section of the Church of Sweden cuts ties with G4S
summary: The Umeå section of the Church of Sweden announces that it will no longer hire G4S due to its role in the occupation and Israeli prisons.

headline: Concordia Graduate Students’ Association endorses BDS
summary: The General Assembly of the Concordia Graduate Students’ Association (GSA) votes overwhelmingly in favour of a resolution to endorse, promote, and participate in BDS against the state of Israel "until it respects international law and ends its apartheid system."

headline: Rennes City Council cuts ties with Veolia
summary: Rennes City Council in France decides not to renew its contract with Veolia for the city's water management. BDS activists participated in public meetings and contacted municipal councillors about Veolia's role in Israeli human rights violations.

headline: Major South African agricultural company cuts ties with Israeli date grower cooperative
summary: Karsten Farms, a leading South African agricultural company backed by one of South Africa's primary finance bodies, severs ties with Hadiklaim, an Israeli date grower cooperative. Karsten Farms also says it "will not enter into any future relations with any Israeli entity complicit in the illegal Israeli Occupation of Palestine."

headline: South African toy company ends support for Jewish National Fund
summary: Reggies Toy Stores, a South African toy company, confirms that it no longer has a relationship with the Jewish National Fund, following nationwide protests. As a land development organization, the JNF is involved in barring Palestinian citizens of Israel from owning or leasing around 93% of the lands in Israel, displacing Bedoin communities, and promoting Israeli settlement on Palestinian land.

headline: Queen Mary, University of London students union votes to boycott G4S and Veolia
summary: The Students’ Union at the Queen Mary, University of London approves a motion to boycott both British-Danish security company G4S and French multinational corporation Veolia, saying "corporate complicity in the denial of human rights must not be tolerated on our campuses.”

headline: Hundreds of Palestinian farmers in Gaza call for boycott of Israeli agricultural companies
summary: More than 300 Palestinian farmers, fishers, and activists march in Gaza to call for a boycott of Israeli agricultural companies in a day of action that extended to more than 40 European cities. In Europe, demonstrations call for governments and supermarkets to end trade with Israeli agricultural export companies over their role in the destruction of Palestinian agriculture.

headline: UN Fact Finding Mission calls for sanctions on Israel due to settlement activity
summary: The United Nations Finding Mission on the Israeli Settlement in the Occupied Palestinian Territory publishes a report concluding that Israel's settlements are a "creeping annexation" and "are established for the exclusive benefit of Israeli Jews...through a system of total segregation." The report calls on member states "to assume their responsibilities in their relations with a State breaching peremptory norms of international law", which would entail a ban on settlement trade and sanctions on Israel.

headline: Dundee University student association votes to cut ties with G4S
summary: Students of the Dundee University Students’ Association (DUSA) overwhelmingly vote to cut ties with security firm G4S at their general meeting. The vote comes three days after Palestinian political prisoner Arafat Jaradat was tortured to death in a G4S-equipped Israeli prison. G4S is the largest security firm in the world and provides security services and equipment to Israeli prisons and checkpoints, which routinely violate Palestinian human rights.

headline: American singer-songwriter Shuggie Otis cancels concert in Israel
summary: Shuggie Otis, American funk, rock, jazz, and blues artist, cancels a planned concert in Israel. Otis does not make a statement on the reason for his decision, but fans had called on him to respect the Palestinian picket line.

headline: La Trobe University student union removes SodaStream prize from camppus competition
summary: The La Trobe University student union removes SodaStream as a prize for a campus competition, one year after passing a BDS motion on campus.

headline: Students at UC San Diego pass divestment resolution
summary: The Associated Student Council at the University of California, San Diego passes a divestment resolution calling on the university to divest from companies that "profit from Israel’s military occupation and violence against Palestinians in violation of international law and human rights." The motion specifically names Boeing, General Dynamics Corporation, Hewlett Packard, Ingersoll-Rand and Raytheon. Similar resolutions were recently passed at UC Irvine and UC Riverside.

headline: Clackmannanshire Council becomes third local Scottish government to support boycott of Israel
summary: Clackmannanshire Council vows to "resist, insofar as legislative considerations permit, any action that gives political or economic support to the State of Israel" , becoming the third Scottish local government, after W. Dunbartonshire and Stirling to support BDS.

headline: Largest students' union in Canada passes divestment resolution
summary: The York Federation of Students (YFS), the largest student union in Canada representing 50,000 students, passes a resolution to endorse the BDS movement and calls on the university to divest from Northrop Grumman, BAE Systems, Amphenol, and other companies that are selling weapons and military equipment to Israel.

headline: UK Employment Tribunal throws out anti-boycott lawsuit
summary: In a landmark ruling, an Employment Tribunal judge throws out ten claims against the University and College Union (UCU) over its support for BDS, in a lawsuit supported by Israeli lobby groups. The judgement describes the claims as "an impermissible attempt to achieve a political end by litigious means." UCU represents 120,000 academic and academic-related staff in the UK.

headline: Teachers Union of Ireland calls for academic boycott
summary: In a unanimous vote at its Annual Congress, the Teachers’ Union of Ireland endorses the Palestinian call for an academic boycott of Israel.

headline: University of Toronto Scarborough Students' Union (SCSU) becomes ninth Canadian student union to endorse BDS
summary: University of Toronto Scarborough Students' Union (SCSU), representing 10,000 undergraduate students, endorses the Palestinian call for BDS, joining a wave of Canadian student unions to take action.

headline: University of Sydney students pass resolution in support of professor's boycott
summary: The Student Representative Council (SRC) at the University of Sydney passes a motion endorsing a professor's academic boycott of Technion, an Israeli university involved in manufacturing remotely piloted aerial vehicles and other equipment used by Israel to maintain its military occupation.

headline: Activists in 11 countries protest G4S
summary: Activists in 11 countries protest against G4S, including Morocco, Egypt, Lebanon, Jordan, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Norway, Denmark, Luxembourg, Poland, and South Africa. Protesters highlight the recent death of Arafat Jaradatin in Israel’s Meggido prison after being subjected to torture.

headline: Sussex University students pass two BDS referendums
summary: In a campus-wide referendum, Sussex University students passed two BDS resolutions. The first, passed with 76% of the vote, calls on the university to end a contract with Veolia. The second, a renewal of an existing policy that passed with 72% of the vote, calls for a boycott of Israeli goods. Veolia is a French multi-national company involved in developing discriminatory infrastructure to serve Israeli settlements.

headline: The Association for Asian American Studies adopts academic boycott
summary: The Association for Asian American Studies becomes the first U.S. scholarly organization to endorse an academic boycott against complicit Israeli institutions via a unanimous vote by its general membership. The American Studies Association follows suit in December 2013.

headline: Federation of 100,000 students in Belgium calls for academic boycott of Israel
summary: The Belgian French-speaking Students Association, a federation of 100,000 Belgian students in higher education, calls on French "to re-evaluate the existing cooperation agreements between Belgian French-Community universities and Israeli universities" due to "the discriminatory and colonialist policy of the State of Israel."

headline: Stephen Hawking joins academic boycott of Israel
summary: Physicist Stephen Hawking pulls out of a conference hosted by former Israeli president Shimon Peres in Jerusalem. A statement published with Hawking's approval said it is "his independent decision to respect the boycott, based upon his knowledge of Palestine, and on the unanimous advice of his own academic contacts there."

headline: Sheffield University decides not to renew Veolia contract
summary: The University of Sheffield decides not to renew its waste collection contract with multinational corporation Veolia following a campaign initiated by the campus Palestine Society and supported by the student union. Veolia is a French multi-national company involved in developing discriminatory infrastructure to serve Israeli settlements.

headline: UK Charity Commission says it will open investigation into the Jewish National Fund
summary: UK Charity Commission responds to a request to review the status of the Jewish National Fund based on systematic racist discrimination. While the Charity Commission declines to revoke the JNF's charitable status, it will open an investigation into discrimination claims. The JNF is a para-statal organization involved in the administration of 93% of land in Israel, directly controlling 13%. The JNF openly discriminates against Palestinians, saying "The JNF...does not have a duty to practice equality towards all citizens of the state."

headline: United Church of Canada launches settlement boycott campaign
summary: The United Church of Canada, representing 2 million members, launches a new campaign to encourage economic action against several settlement products, including Keter Plastic, SodaStream, and Ahava. The campaign comes less than one year after the church voted to endorse boycotts of settlement products.

headline: South African diplomat Ismail Coovadia rejects JNF honor
summary: Ismail Coovadia, a former South African ambassador to Israel, says he’ll be returning a certificate informing him that 18 trees had been planted in his honour in an Israeli forest by the Jewish National Fund (JNF) and the Israeli ministry of foreign affairs. In a statement, he says "regrettably, my permission was not sought to plant a tree in my or the name of a South African ambassador on usurped land, the rightful land of the Palestinians and Bedouins. … I was not a party to, and never will be, to the planting of '18 trees', in my 'honour' on expropriated and stolen land."

headline: 150 organizations speak up in solidarity with BDS French activists
summary: As a group of French activists face charges over their support for BDS, 150 organizations from around the world sign an open letter of support, pledging to work with BDS France to overcome repression and build the BDS movement.

headline: Major US pension fund divests from SodaStream
summary: TIAA, a major U.S. pension fund, divests SodaStream shares valued at $9.4 million. SodaStream operates its main production facility in an illegal Israeli settlement on Palestinian land in the West Bank. They do not comment on the reason for their decision.

headline: European Investment Bank will not invest in most Israeli businesses
summary: New leaked guidelines from the European Investment Bank indicate that it will exclude any Israeli entity with activity in occupied Palestinian territory from participating in EU financial instruments such as loans. The guidelines state "The EU does not recognise Israel’s sovereignty over [the Occupied territories]."

headline: Film director Mira Nair joins cultural boycott
summary: Award-winning Indian-American filmmaker Mira Nair rejects an invitation to be a guest of honor at theHaifa International Film Festival, saying "I will not be going to Israel at this time. I will go to Israel when the walls come down. I will go to Israel when occupation is gone."

headline: Two Dutch grocery chains remove settlement products
summary: Aldi and Hoogvlit, two major Dutch grocery chains, confirm that they have stopped selling goods produced in Israeli settlements.

headline: Rock band The Killers cancel Israel appearance
summary: The Killers cancel a planned show in Tel Aviv. Although they do not offer a reason for the cancellation, BDS activists had worked to publicly engage with the band.

headline: Jazz musicians withdraw from Red Sea Jazz Festival
summary: US jazz artists Chris Daddy Dave and Matt Schofield and his band, The Matt Schofield Trio quietly pull out of performing in Israeli music festival.

headline: Nordea Bank excludes Cemex from portfolio
summary: Nordea, a major Nordic bank, excludes Cemex from its investment porfolio due to its extraction of Palestinian natural resources. Cemex is the second largest building materials company in the world. Through its Israeli subsidiary Ready-Mix, Cemex has factories in illegal Israeli settlements. It also supplies Israel with cement and concrete for the construction of its wall, military checkpoints and illegal settlements in the Occupied Palestinian Territory.

headline: Regional Quaker organization endorses BDS
summary: Lake Erie Yearly Meeting, a regional Quaker organization encompassing Ohio, Michigan, and Western Pennsylvania, becomes the first Quaker Yearly Meeting to officially endorse boycott and divestment targeting companies complicit in the Israeli occupation.

headline: Dutch firm pulls out of project in East Jerusalem
summary: Royal HaskoningDHV, a Dutch engineering firm, announces it will withdraw from a sewage treatment project in occupied East Jerusalem. In a statement, the company says, "after due consultation with various stakeholders, the company came to understand that future involvement in the project could be in violation of international law." While israel develops infrastructure to serve illegal settlements, it has refused to approve vital santitation and environmental projects for Palestinians.

headline: Veolia terminates Israel bus operation
summary: Veolia announces the sale of its Israeli bus service, which operated a number of routes serving illegal Israeli settlements, but continues to be involved in other discriminatory Israeli infrastructure projects.

headline: Major Norweigian trade union drops G4S
summary: Industri Energi, a Norweigian trade union representing 58,000 workers, announces it is terminating a contract with G4S as “an act of solidarity with the struggle of the Palestinian people.”

headline: Veolia drops out of bid for St. Louis water project
summary: The St. Louis mayor's office announces that Veolia has withdrawn itself from consideration for a consultancy contract with the St. Louis Water Division. The news follows over a year of action by St. Louis citizens who formed a "Dump Veolia" coalition.

headline: UN expert urges companies to cut ties with Israeli settlements
summary: Richard Falk, the UN Special Rapporteur on human rights in the occupied Palestinian territories, says his office is trying to reach out to companies to warn them that their activities in Israeli settlements could be "problematic" and urging them to withdraw. Israeli settlements are illegal according to the Fourth Geneva Convention.

headline: Organizers call off an Israeli rock festivall after multiple artists boycott
summary: Organizers of Progstage, an Israeli rock festival, call off the event due to multiple cancellations by international artists. Circus Maximus (Norway), Haken (UK), and Bumblefoot (USA) were among the bands that chose to drop out following discussions with activists.

headline: University of Bergen in Norway avoids contracting G4S
summary: The University of Bergen in Norway says it will not use G4S as its security contractor due to the firm’s role in the Israeli prison system and illegal Israeli settlements. University board member Oddny Miljeteig explains, “it is clear that large parts of the intellectual and academic communities in Bergen would have been outraged if the university hired G4S.”

headline: Renowned Cape Town Trauma Center terminates G4S contract
summary: The renowned Cape Town Trauma Center terminates its contract with G4S, explaining they “note with great concern the serious allegations levelled against the security company G4S of complicity in the illegal incarceration and torture of Palestinians."

headline: Two UK universities avoid contracting G4S
summary: King’s College London and the University of Southampton both opt not to contract G4S amidst campus protest. G4S is the largest security firm in the world and provides security services and equipment to Israeli prisons and checkpoints, which routinely violate Palestinian human rights.

headline: French Left Party endorses BDS
summary: Parti de Gauche, the French Left Party, endorses BDS as the French president visits Israel. In a statement, the party says "it is high time to move forward to go from speeches and declarations to action. This can only be done by imposing real sanctions on the Israeli government."

headline: Major US pension fund divests from Veolia
summary: TIAA, a major U.S. pension fund, removes Veolia from its Social Choice Fund, divesting $1.2 million in shares. The fund previously divested $9.4 million from SodaStream in 2013 and $72 million from Caterpillar in 2012. All three companies are the target of BDS campaigns over their connection to illegal Israeli settlements and other Israeli violations of international law.

headline: UK government guide warns against business in illegal Israeli settlements
summary: In its Overseas Business Risk report, the UK government warning businesses about the problems and risks associated with doing business with illegal Israeli settlements, including "reputational implications."

headline: Romania stops sending construction workers to Israel over settlements
summary: The Romanian government announces it will stop sending construction workers to Israel if the Israeli government does not pledge they won’t be working in settlements.

headline: Social movements in Brazil call for BDS actions
summary: Three Brazilian networks, representing some of the most important civil society networks in Brazil, call for a military embargo on Israel and the end to the Free Trade Agreement between Mercosur countries and Israel.

headline: Colombian activists launch campaign against Veolia
summary: Colombian activists launch a petition asking the mayor of Bogotá not to renew a contract with Veolia, the French multinational company involved in discriminatory infrastructure projects that serve illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: Dutch water company ends cooperation with Mekorot
summary: Vitens, the largest supplier of drinking water in the Netherlands, for the decision to end its cooperation agreement with Israel’s national water company Mekorot. Mekorot violates international law and is responsible for war crimes, including pillage of water resources in the Occupied Palestinian Territory (OPT), supply of this pillaged water to illegal Israeli settlements, and systematic discrimination and denial of water to the occupied Palestinian population.

headline: Major Dutch trade union drops G4S
summary: Abvakabo, a Dutch trade union with 350,000 members, ends its contract with G4S two months after Industri Energi, a Norwegian trade union representing 58,000 workers, did the same. The two trade unions join the renowned Cape Town Trauma Center in South Africa and multiple universities in the United Kingdom and Norway in taking action against G4S in 2013.

headline: Dutch trade union cuts ties with G4S
summary: Abvakabo, a Dutch trade union with 350,000 members, ends its relationship with G4S.

headline: Norwegian musician Moddi cancels Israel concert
summary: Moddi, a Norwegian musician, author, and activist, issues a statement saing "I have chosen to cancel my performance in Tel Aviv...The reason for my decision is the situation in Israel and the areas it controls...As long as ‘dialogue’ continues to be a goal in itself and not a means to solve one of the deepest, most intense conflicts of this time, I will not lend my voice to it."

headline: G4S faces major intergovernmental investigation
summary: The UK Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) Contact Point begins an investigation into G4S' services to the Israeli government, particularly the provision of surveillance equipment at checkpoints.

headline: Dutch pension giant divests from five Israeli banks
summary: PGGM, a Dutch pension fund with 2.6 million participants, announces it has divested tens of millions of Euros from five Israeli banks, citing the banks’ unethical and illegal practices in financing Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Veolia loses out on $4.26 billion Boston contract
summary: The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority ends a ten year partnership with Veolia, choosing another company for a $4.26 billion deal to operate and maintain its commuter rail trains. The decision follows a two year campaign by local activists to draw attention to Veolia's role in discriminatory infrastructure projects that serve illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: Isareli settlers say boycott cost them $29m in lost revenue
summary: Israeli settlers in the West Bank’s Jordan Valley say that European markets are increasingly unwilling to source products from illegal settlements. The export-driven income of settlers in the Jordan Valley’s illegal settlements dropped by more than 14 percent, or $29 million, last year.

headline: Friends of the Earth International joins BDS campaign
summary: Friends of the Earth International, a grassroots environmental network with over 2 million members around the world, issues a statement of support for Palestinian members calling for BDS.

headline: Junot Díaz, Chuck D, and Boots Riley Call endorse BDS
summary: Junot Dí­az, Chuck D, and Boots Riley join leading U.S. intellectuals, writers, and artists in endorsing the US Campaign for the Academic and Cultural Boycott of Israel.

headline: Scarlett Johansson resigns from role as Oxfam ambassador over SodaStream ties
summary: Scarlett Johansson announces she will step down from her role as Oxfam ambassador. The move comes after Johansson faced public backlash for appearing in an ad for SodaStream, an Israeli company based in an illegal Israeli settlement. In a statement, Oxfam said "Ms. Johansson’s role promoting the company SodaStream is incompatible with her role as an Oxfam Global Ambassador."

headline: Dozens of cartoonists call on comic festival to drop SodaStream sponsorship
summary: Notable international cartoonists, including Siné, Tardi and Joe Sacco, write an open letter calling on the International Festival of Comics in Angoulême, France to drop SodaStream as an official sponsor. SodaStream products are produced in an illegal Israeli settlement.

headline: Denmark’s largest bank blacklists Israel’s Hapoalim Bank
summary: Danske Bank, the largest bank in Denmark, places Bank Hapoalim on its investment blacklist due to its involvement in the funding of illegal Israeli settlements. In an announcement posted on its website, the bank stated that Bank Hapoalim was acting against the rules of international humanitarian law. Note: in 2016, Danske Bank decided to remove Bank Hapoalim from its exclusion list.

headline: University of Kent votes to cancel G4S contract
summary: The student union at the University of Kent announces it will terminate its contract with G4S due to its human rights abuses in Palestine, South Africa, the UK and other countries. G4S provides security and incarceration “services” to Israeli military bases, checkpoints, illegal settlements and prisons at which Palestinian political prisoners are held without trial and subjected to abuse and torture.

headline: Luxembourg state pension fund excludes 9 Israeli firms
summary: FDC, Luxembourg's state pension fund with $18 billion in assets, excludes ten companies from investment because of their involvement in illegal Israeli settlements and other human rights violations. This includes all five of Israel’s major banks, the arms manufacturer Elbit Systems, the U.S. company Motorola Solutions, and Israeli real estate developers Africa Israel, Jerusalem Economy, Ltd., and Real Estate Management & Development.

headline: University of Windsor students vote for BDS in referendum
summary: Students at the University of Windsor in Canada become the first in Canada to endorse BDS

headline: Nobel Peace Laureate Mairead Maguire calls for boycott of Israel
summary: Mairead Maguire, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1976, calls on the international community to support BDS until the Israeli government recognizes Palestinian human rights.

headline: National University of Galway students vote to join BDS
summary: The National University of Galway (NUIG) Students' Union passes a motion endorsing BDS and pledging to actively participate in the BDS movement.

headline: United Methodist Church board calls for SodaStream boycott
summary: The United Methodist Church board calls for a boycott of SodaStream due to its connection to illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: Israeli state water firm Mekorot loses $170 million deal in Argentina
summary: The Buenos Aires municipality suspends a $170 million water treatment plant deal with Israeli state water company Mekorot, following a a local campaign. Mekorot illegally appropriates Palestinian water, diverting it to illegal Israeli settlements and towns inside Israel, and imposes severe obstacles to Palestinians accessing their own water.

headline: Royal Institute of British Architects backs Israel boycott motion
summary: The Council of the Royal Institute of British Architects votes to call on the International Union Of Architects to exclude the Israeli Association of United Architects over its complicity in constructing illegal settlements on occupied Palestinian territory.

headline: BBC opts not to contract G4S
summary: The BBC elects not to award G4S a $132 million contract following a high profile campaign supported by film directors Ken Loach and Mike Leigh and novelist Ahdaf Soueif. G4S provides security and incarceration “services” to Israeli military bases, checkpoints, illegal settlements and prisons at which Palestinian political prisoners are held without trial and subjected to abuse and torture.

headline: Israeli state water firm Mekorot loses Portugal deal
summary: Lisbon's water company EPAL announces it has terminated a technology exchange deal with Israeli state water company Mekorot following protests over Mekorot's role in the theft of Palestinian water resources.

headline: King's College London students vote to back BDS
summary: The students union of King's College London votes to endorse the BDS movement at its Student General Meeting. The motion passed by a vote of 348-252.

headline: Dundee University students vote for BDS
summary: In a referendum held by the Dundee University Student Association (DUSA), students vote to approve a BDS motion with 72.6 percent in favour.

headline: Ryerson University students vote to join BDS
summary: Students at Ryerson University in Toronto vote to join BDS and to ban the student union from working with companies who do business in Israel.

headline: Students at University of South Florida students call for divestment
summary: Students call on the University of South Florida Foundation to divest from companies complicit in human rights violations in Palestine in a petition that gains over 10,000 student signatures.

headline: Earth Day Network cuts ties with SodaStream
summary: The Earth Day Network, which works with more than 22,000 partners in 192 countries to broaden, diversify, and mobilize the environmental movement, ends a partnership with SodaStream. After activists reached out to Earth Day Network, SodaStream was removed from the list of sponsors on its website, and Earth Day Network's logo was removed from a SodaStream campaign. SodaStream is an Israeli company that operates out of an illegal Israeli settlement.

headline: Divestment passes at Univeristy of California, Riverside
summary: The student senate at the University of California, Riverside passes a resolution calling on the university to pull its investments from U.S. companies profiting from Israel's occupation. The divestment resolution is the second to pass at the university, after an earlier resolution in April 2013 was challenged.

headline: Europe’s largest teachers’ union adopts boycott
summary: The UK's National Union of Teachers (NUT), which has more than 300,000 members in England and Wales, backs a boycott of companies profiting from Israel's illegal settlements.

headline: Graduate students at University of New Mexico vote to divest
summary: Graduate students at the University of New Mexico pass a resolution calling for divestment from companies profiting from human rights violations in occupied Palestine and at the US-Mexico border.

headline: Students at Wesleyan University supports divestment for student fund
summary: Students at Wesleyan Student Assembly vote to divest their student government endowment from companies profiting off of the Israeli military occupation in Palestine. The resolution also calls on the university to divest its own holdings from such companies.

headline: 1,200 scholars join academic boycott in Spain
summary: More than 1,200 professors, researchers and professors across Spain declare support for an academic boycott of Israeli institutions.

headline: Grace Lee Boggs, Danny Glover object to film screening in Tel Aviv
summary: Philosopher and activist Grace Lee Boggs and actor and activist Danny Glover denounce the inclusion of the film "American Revolutionary: the Evolution of Grace Lee Boggs’" in DocAviv, a government-sponsored Israeli film festival, saying "we stand in solidarity with the people of Palestine, and support their call for cultural and academic boycott of Israel."

headline: University of Helsinki ends G4S contract
summary: The University of Helsinki cancels a contract with G4S to provide campus security. The decision follows a campaign that was backed by unions representing its academics and students.

headline: European Union bans poultry exports from illegal Israeli settlements
summary: The European Union body bans imports of poultry and eggs from illegal Israeli settlements, the first EU ban on any Israeli products.

headline: DePaul University students pass divestment resolution
summary: The student government at DePaul University announces it passed a divestment resolution calling on the university to divest from companies “that profit from Israel’s discriminatory practices and human rights violations."

headline: The UK's National Union of Student's Black Students conference endorses BDS
summary: The largest constituency of Black students in Europe, represented by the National Union of Students’ Black Students' Campaign in the United Kingdom, endorses BDS in a motion that describes Israel as "a settler-colonial project, predicated on the ethnic cleansing and expulsion of its indigenous people."

headline: Rapper Talib Kweli cancels Israel gig
summary: Rapper Talib Kweli cancels plans to perform in Israel, saying "as much as I want to play Israel, I have decided not to in solidarity with Palestinians who will not have access to my show. After days of discussions with many, I’ve decided to try and visit Israel and Palestine with those who fight to end the state of apartheid."

headline: The Gates Foundation divests from G4S due to ties with the Israeli Prison Service
summary: The Gates Foundation divests from G4S following protests at its offices in London, Johannesburg, and Seattle over its 3.17 percent, $184 million stake in the company.

headline: The Shondes band pens open letter explaining support for BDS
summary: Brooklyn rock band The Shondes (Yiddish for “The Disgraces”) were disinvited from the Washington Jewish Music Festival due to support for Palestinian rights. In an open letter, they explain their support for BDS, saying "coming to support Palestinian rights...didn’t make us feel any less Jewish or less entitled to community. After all, what could be more Jewish than asking tough questions and fighting injustice?"

headline: United Methodist Church divests from G4S
summary: The United Methodist Church divests $110,000 from G4S over the company's activities with the Israeli prison service, one week after the Gates Foundation divested from G4S following protests at its offices in London, Johannesburg, and Seattle over its 3.17 percent, $184 million stake in the company.

headline: G4S says it will end Israeli prison contracts
summary: G4S announces it will pull out of the Israeli prison system, but says it will take three years to do so.

headline: Presbyterian Church votes to divest from companies complicit in Israeli occupation
summary: The Presbyterian Church General Assembly, meeting in Detroit, votes by 310-303 to sell stock in Caterpillar, Hewlett-Packard and Motorola Solutions. The church has 1.8 million members.

headline: Activists occupy the roof of G4S headquarters in the UK
summary: Activists stage a rooftop occupation at G4S’ international headquarters in West Sussex in the UK, prompting a legal battle that ended with the acquittal of the activists in 2013.

headline: Dutch pension giant ABP divests from two Israeli arms companies
summary: Dutch pension fund ABP, the pension fund for government and education employees with 2.8 million participants, adds two Israeli companies to its exclusion list, Aryt Industries Ltd. and Ashot Ashkelon, saying they "continue to conduct business in conflict with the principles of the UN Global Compact." Aryt Industries Ltd. is “primarily engaged in the manufacture of detonators.” Ashot Ashkelon Industries Ltd. is active in the aerospace and defence sector, and a subsidiary of Israeli government-owned defence company Israel Military Industries Ltd.

headline: Britain's largest union backs boycott of Israel
summary: UNITE, also called Unite the Union, a UK union with 1.3 million members, passes two pro-Palestinian resolutions, including one that instructs the union to work with others to develop BDS campaigns.

headline: 17 EU member states warn about risks of doing business with Israeli settlements
summary: At least 12 more European governments publish online guidance warning their citizens and businesses about risks involved in trade and other economic links with illegal Israeli settlements, bringing the total number of countries to publish such advice to 17.

headline: Scotland’s national poet endorses BDS
summary: Scotland’s national poet Liz Lochhead says “This is part of a necessary process — this boycotting...because we, the international community, must protest by any means possible Israel’s current actions in Gaza, and indeed its ongoing illegal treatment of all Palestinians."

headline: Dublin City Council calls for military embargo and the suspension of the EU-Israel Association Agreement
summary: Dublin City Council unanimously passes a motion calling upon the Irish government to push for an arms embargo and trade sanctions on Israel.  The motion calls for an immediate end to Israeli attacks on Gaza, the siege on Gaza, and the practice of administrative detention.

headline: Critical Ethnic Studies Association votes to back BDS
summary: The Critical Ethnic Studies Association endorses the BDS movement with the passage of a "Resolution on the Academic boycott of Israeli Academic Institutions."

headline: Chile suspends free trade negotiations with Israel over Gaza massacre
summary: Home to the largest Palestinian diaspora outside the Middle East, Chile suspended its Free Trade Agreement negotiations with Israel following the bombing campaign of Gaza. Chile also recalled its ambassador as part of its condemnation of Israel's attack.

headline: Nobel laureates join international call for military embargo on Israel
summary: Six Nobel laureates, including Archbishop Desmond Tutu (South Africa), Adolfo Peres Esquivel (Argentina), Betty Williams (Ireland), Jody Williams (US), Mairead Maguire (Ireland), and Rigoberta Menchú (Guatemala) sign an open letter calling for a military embargo on Israel.

headline: Veolia announces it will sell Israeli interests
summary: French multinational company Veolia announces it will "step back from Israel as a market place" and sell most parts of its Israeli interests by 2015. The campaign against Veolia will continue until it actually ends all aspects of its participation in Israeli violations of international law, including its involvement in the discriminatory Jerusalem Light Rail project.

headline: Victorian College of the Arts students vote to boycott Israel
summary: The Victorian College of the Arts Student Association (VCASA), which represents over 1,200 students, votes unanimously for a motion to join the BDS movement, in the midst of Israel’s bombing of Gaza.

headline: Rock stars Peter Gabriel and Bobby Gillespie urge arms embargo on Israel
summary: Peter Gabriel and Bobby Gillespie join 21,000 people who signed an open letter to David Cameron, the British Prime Minister, demanding a halt to the arms trade between the UK and Israel.

headline: Global hip hop artists make music video calling for BDS
summary: A global consortium of hip-hop notables, including Peruvian-American rapper Immortal Technique, El Tipo Este of Cuban duo Obsesion, Parisian rapper Tonto Noiza, and Jonnesburg-based Tumi Molekane, collaborate on a video calling for BDS.

headline: Turkish local municipalities and businesses declare boycott
summary: In Turkey, at least 12 local municipalities, a number of major business associations, and a major trade union issue calls for a boycott of Israeli products.

headline: New York Times bestselling author Ayelet Waldman tweets support for BDS
summary: New York Times bestselling author Ayelet Waldman says that although she is Israeli and loves her country, she is ready to give BDS a chance, stating, "this criminal war and occupation must end."

headline: Latin American social organizations call for suspension of trade agreement with Israel, arms embargo
summary: At the Mercosur Summit, a major gathering of Latin American organizations, over 15 social movements from Argentina, Colombia and Venezuela signed a letter urging South American countries to implement measures against Israel, including a suspension of free trade agreements with Israel, and an arms embargo.

headline: South Korean civil society demands an end to military cooperation with Israel
summary: A coalition of Korean civil society and popular movement organizations demand an immediate halt to all military transactions by the Korean government with Israel at a time of ongoing bombings and escalating casualties in Gaza. Weapons exports data reported to UN Comtrade reveal that Korea has exported some $30 million worth of weapons to Israel in the last ten years, and imported around $40 million of Israeli weaponry over the same period.

headline: Belgium calls for clear labelling of goods from Israeli settlements
summary: The Belgian Economics Ministry advises retailers to clearly label the origin of products made in illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: Brazil, Chile, Ecuador, Peru and El Salvador recall Israel envoys over Gaza operation
summary: Five Latin American countries recall their ambassadors from Tel Aviv, in protest of Israel's operation in the Gaza Strip.

headline: Danish cleaning company sells subsidiary operating in Israeli settlements
summary: A spokesperson of Danish ISS cleaning company confirms that company has sold its Israeli subsidiary.

headline: No Más Muertes, migrant rights group, endorses BDS
summary: No Más Muertes, an advocacy group that seeks to end fatalities of undocumented immigrants crossing the desert regions near the United States-Mexico border, calls on its members and allies to adopt BDS tactics in solidarity with Palestinians, noting "our struggle against death and suffering here in the Arizona borderlands is deeply implicated in the struggle against US-funded war and occupation in Palestine."

headline: Soros Fund Management divests from SodaStream
summary: Soros Fund Management, the family office of the billionaire investor George Soros, sells its stake in SodaStream following pressure by its Middle East partners.

headline: UK's National Union of Students approves BDS
summary: The UK National Union of Students, representing 7 million students, passes a motion in support of BDS campaigns amid Israel's 2014 assault on Gaza.

headline: Irish trade union calls for Irish retailers to boycott Israeli products
summary: Mandate, and Irish trade union, approaches more than 20 Irish retailers asking them to boycott Israeli products. In response, multiple small businesses announce they are joining the boycott.

headline: Over 100 Middle East Studies scholars and librarians call for boycott of Israeli academic institutions
summary: In an open letter, more than Middle East Studies scholars and librarians say "we feel compelled to join the growing number of academics in Israel and around the world who support the Palestinian call to boycott Israeli academic institutions."

headline: Hundreds of thousands turn out to protest Israeli attack on Gaza
summary: Hundreds of thousands of protesters took to the streets as part of an international Day of Rage initiated by groups in Gaza. Anti-apartheid hero Desmond Tutu called the day one of the biggest ever international mobilisations on a single issue. Protesters condemned Israeli attacks on Gaza and called for an end to Israel's military occupation and siege on Gaza.

headline: Latin American leaders issue "In Defense of Palestine" statement
summary: Bolivian President Evo Morales, deposed Honduran President Manuel Zelaya (signed with his common name “Mel Zelaya”), former Cuban president Fidel Castro, Cuban musician Silvio Rodrígiuez, and Uruguayan author Eduardo Galeano are among those signing a statement of solidarity with the Palestinian people under the banner of the Network for the Defense of Humanity.

headline: Russell Brand backs boycott of Israel
summary: In a video that went viral, British comedian Russel Brand urges banks, pension funds and other big businesses to sever investment ties with Israel.

headline: Ireland's biggest food retailer drops Israeli produce
summary: SuperValu, the largest food retailer in Ireland, tells the Irish media that it has withdrawn Israeli products from its shops. Major Israeli food exporters face an unprecedented wave of cancelations in orders from Europe as a result of Israel’s massacre of Palestinians in Gaza.

headline: Activists block Israeli ship from docking in Oakland for four days
summary: Thousands of protestors gathered in Oakland to prevent a ship from Zim Integrated Shipping Services Ltd., Israel’s biggest cargo shipping company, from docking. Demonstrations in serveral other cities were successful in temporarily delaying the Zim ships from unloading, costing the company hundreds of thousands of dollars.

headline: Ontario branch of Canadian Federation of Students joins boycott
summary: The Ontario branch of the Canadian Federation of Students, representing over 300,000 students, unanimously passes a BDS motion.

headline: Renowned Algerian singer Souad Massi explains boycott support
summary: In an interview with French media, Algerian singer Souad Massi explains at length why she will not perform in Israel, saying, "I sing for peace in the world, while the Israeli government is not doing much to achieve this purpose."

headline: Palestinians in the West Bank boycott Israeli goods
summary: Israeli media says “sales of Israeli products in the West Bank decreased by 50% due to the boycott accompanying the Israeli aggression on the Gaza Strip.” Abdel Karim of Birzeit University notes the special challenges Palestinians face in implementing a boycott, noting "there are basic goods that Palestinians cannot boycott, like fuel, electricity, cement and water."

headline: Irish artist boycott pledge receives 500th signature
summary: The "Irish Artists’ Pledge to Boycott Israel" receives its 500th signature, after launching with 140 signatures in 2010. Signatories include novelists, poets, painters, sculptors, film-makers, dancers, composers, performing musicians and others who pledge not "to perform or exhibit in Israel, nor to accept any funding from any institution linked to the government of Israel, until such time as Israel complies with international law and universal principles of human rights."

headline: Filipino Congressman Walden Bello calls for cancellation of Elbit deal
summary: Filipino Congressman, author and academic Walden Bello delivers a speech in Philippines congress calling on the government to cancel its $20 million deal with Israeli military company Elbit Systems.

headline: Union of European Football Associations rejects Israeli bid to host games in Jerusalem
summary: The Union of European Football Associations rejects an Israeli bid to host games in Jerusalem during the 2020 European Championships. Israel was one of just 6 countries that failed in its bid to host games. 75 ​Palestinian football teams and NGOs​​ wrote to​ UEFA president Michel​ Platini to oppose the bid. Sit-ins were held by Palestine solidarity activists at the headquarters of French and Italian football associations.

headline: 640 Swiss artists call for suspension of military co-operation with Israel
summary: 640 Swiss artists and cultural actors publish a public statement condemning the war crimes committed by Israel during its assault on the Gaza Strip. The statement calls on the Swiss Council to suspend all military cooperation with Israel, including canceling a recent order of drones made by Israeli military company Elbit Systems.

headline: ANC joins call for complete boycott of Israel
summary: South Africa's ruling party declards "(a) cultural, academic and education boycott of Israel, including travel bans for members and leaders of the ANC, the alliance, members of Cabinet, Members of Parliament and government officials."

headline: Los Angeles activists block unloading of Israeli cargo ship for two days
summary: The Block the Boat coalition of Los Angeles prevented an Israeli cargo ship, the Zim Savannah, from docking at the port of Long Beach for at least 34 hours.

headline: Israel excluded from Italian military drills
summary: The Italian defense ministry removed Israel from a list of countries participating in multinational military training exercises on the Italian island of Sardinia following a campaign by anti-war activists. Palestinians in Gaza appealed directly to Italy not to “train the pilots who bomb us.”

headline: Jewish group withdraws from festival over Israeli sponsorship
summary: The Union of Progressive Jews of Belgium (UPJB) withdraws their participation and their sponsorship from the Brussels Jewish Film Festival over its acceptance of funds from the Israeli embassy.

headline: University of Exeter students pass boycott of settlement products
summary: A referendum at the University of Exeter to boycott products associated with Israeli settlements passes with 86% in favour and the highest voter turnout in university history. Israeli settlements are illegal under international law.

headline: Government of Kuwait will boycott 50 companies over role in illegal Israeli settlements
summary: The Kuwaiti government says it will boycott 50 companies, including Veolia, that profit off of Israeli settlements and military occupation. This move follows their recent decision to exclude Veolia from a $750 million contract over its role in the Jerusalem Light Rail project and other projects that serve illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: SodaStream announces closure of illegal settlement factory
summary: SodaStream announces it will close its factory in the illegal Israeli settlement of Mishor Adumim in the West Bank, following a high profile global boycott campaign against the company. Although the company denies its decision is due to boycotts, share prices dropped as major retailers across North America and Europe deshelved its products. SodaStream's new factory is located in the Naqab, in an area where Palestinian Bedouins are being forcefully removed from their villages.

headline: Dream Defenders endorses BDS at national conference
summary: Dream Defenders, an American racial justice group focused on ending police and prisons, endorses BDS at their national conference, after a delegation of Dream Defenders organizers travelled to Palestine.

headline: 300 EU groups call to suspend the EU-Israel Association Agreement
summary: More than 300 political parties, trade unions and campaign groups call for the suspension of a key agreement between Israel and the European Union. The appeal urges the EU to freeze the “association agreement” with Israel, which facilitates largely unrestricted trade between the EU and Israel and allows Israel to participate in a wide range of the Union’s programs.

headline: Peace and Justice Studies Association endorses BDS
summary: Following Israel’s 2014 assault on Gaza, the Peace and Justice Studies Association (PJSA), a bi-national professional association including scholars in the United States and Canada, endorses BDS in 2014, joining the Critical Ethnic Studies Association’s vote for academic boycott in July 2014.

headline: UCLA students vote for divestment
