summary: The undergraduate student government of UCLA votes 8-2-2 to pass a resolution calling on the university to divest from American companies that profit from human rights violations in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. An earlier version of the resolution failed in February.

headline: Durham Municipality in North Carolina cuts ties with G4S
summary: The municipality of Durham County ends its contract with G4S, becoming the first U.S. municipality to boycott a company explicitly because of its role in perpetuating injustice in Israel/Palestine. G4S is the largest security firm in the world and provides security services and equipment to Israeli prisons and checkpoints, which routinely violate Palestinian human rights.

headline: Leicester city council boycotts settlement products
summary: Leicester City Council passes a resolution boycotting products made in illegal Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank, one of the first such moves by an elected body in the UK.

headline: Middle East Studies Association affirms members' right to boycott
summary: At their annual conference, members of the Middle East Studies Association (MESA) vote 265 to 79 to adopt a draft resolution defending their right to boycott Israeli academic institutions.

headline: Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul cuts ties with Elbit Systems
summary: Following protests by major social movements, trade unions and Palestinian groups, the Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul has cancelled a $17 million deal with Elbit Systems, Israel's largest weapons company.

headline: Baltimore City Council skips Veolia bid
summary: Two days after 100 people stood up at a City Council hearing to denounce a possible city contract with Veolia, an administrative panel approves the bid by its sole rival. Veolia is a French multi-national company involved in developing discriminatory infrastructure to serve Israeli settlements.

headline: American Studies Association adopts academic boycott
summary: Members of the American Studies Association vote for a boycott resolution by a 2 to 1 margin after months of open debate, resolving to "honor the call of Palestinian civil society for a boycott of Israeli academic institutions."

headline: Concordia students vote in favour of BDS
summary: Undergraduate students at Concordia University vote to endorse BDS, 1,276 to 1,067.

headline: University of California Student-Workers Union supports divestment
summary: The University of California Student-Workers Union, representing over 13,000 student workers, becomes the first major US labor union to support divestment from Israel by a membership vote. The vote passed with 65% of voting Members in support.

headline: Swansea University students pass BDS motion
summary: Students at Swansea, which has one of the largest student unions in Wales, pass a motion to endorse BDS.

headline: Harvard University Dining Services suspends SodaStream purchases
summary: Following student group complaints and internal discussions, Harvard University Dining Services decides to suspend purchases of Sodastream appliances.

headline: Two UK student unions cut ties with G4S
summary: The student unions at University College London and University of Essex vote to cancel their contracts with G4S.

headline: Egged bus company loses $372 million contract in Netherlands
summary: The Haarlem provincial government in the Netherlands decides not to award a ten year public transport contract, worth $372 million (€320 million), to EBS, whose parent company, Egged, operates buses in Israel that are inaccessible to Palestinians and profits from running bus lines to illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: University of California, Davis student government passes divestment resolution
summary: The student government at the University of California at Davis votes 8-2, with 2 abstentions, in favor of a resolution to divest from corporations profiting off of Israel’s occupation. Students revise the resolution in May 2015 to include new details on how it serves the interests of student welfare, and pass it again by a vote of 10-0-2. Seven out of nine undergraduate campuses within the University of California system have now voted in favor of divestment.

headline: Charges dropped against UK activists in Elbit case
summary: Apparently to avoid testifying in court about UK arms exports to Israel, Elbit Systems drops charges against 9 activists who occupied the roof of an Elbit facility for two days during the 2014 Israeli attack on Gaza.

headline: 1,350 UK artists join cultural boycott
summary: 1,350 UK artists, including Brian Eno, Gillian Slovo, Alexei Sayle, John Berger, Richard Ashcroft, Riz Ahmed, Miriam Margolyes and Ken Loach, sign the "artists pledge for Palestine." The artists pledge "to accept neither professional invitations to Israel, nor funding, from any institutions linked to its government until it complies with international law and universal principles of human rights."

headline: 63 members of European Parliament call for suspension of EU-Israel association agreement
summary: A group of 63 members of the European Parliament from across the five biggest political blocs in the parliament call on European Union foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini to suspend the EU-Israel “association agreement”, which facilitates trade between the EU and Israel, allows Israel to participate in EU programs, and permits Israeli arms companies to receive EU funding.

headline: Stanford students vote for divestment
summary: The Undergraduate Senate of Stanford University votes 10-1-4 to pass a resolution calling on Stanford to evaluate its investments and divest from companies that facilitate or maintain the infrastructure of the Israeli occupation, and/or the collective punishment and repression of Palestinians.

headline: Three environmental organizations clarify they are not collaborating with Beautiful Israel
summary: Greenpeace Italy, WWF Italy and Legambiente clarify that they are not collaborating, nor do they plan to collaborate, with the Council for a Beautiful Israel (CBI). CBI, which aims to use environmental projects to "change Israel's image", has a close relationship with the Israeli military and runs projects in illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: 58 US senators and representatives skip Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu's speech to a joint session of Congress
summary: 58 US congresspeople, including 8 senators and 50 representatives, skip a speech by Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu's to a joint session of Congress.

headline: University of Toledo students pass divestment motion
summary: The student government at the University of Toledo in Ohio approved a resolution to divest from companies which profit from Israeli violations of Palestinians’ rights. The resolution passed 21-4.

headline: SOAS students and staff vote for academic boycott
summary: In a campus-wide referendum, 75% of students and 91% of contract staff at SOAS (University of London) vote that the university should suspend ties to Israeli universities, such as Jerusalem-based Hebrew University. More than 2000 students and staff participate in the referendum.

headline: Palestine Power Generation Company (PPGC) withdraws from gas deal with Israeli company
summary: Palestine Power Generation Company (PPGC) withdraws from an agreement to buy gas from Israeli-American "Delek-Noble" consortium planning a power plant near Jenin in the occupied West Bank. The deal had covered a 20 years and was worth $1.2 billion.

headline: Safege and Puma pull out of Jerusalem cable car project
summary: Safege and Puma, two French firms, decline to take on a role in Israeli plans to develop a cable car system in East Jerusalem after assessing the legal risks involved.

headline: University of Sussex students vote for student union to join BDS
summary: In a campus-wide referendum, students at the University of Sussex vote that their student union should participate in BDS. More than 1000 students participate, with 68% voting in favor of BDS. The referendum ensures that Israeli products will remain off the shelves at student union shops, a policy that had been in place since 2009 but was due to expire.

headline: Veolia confirms sale of most projects in Israel
summary: Veolia, a French multinational transport company, sells its water, waste and energy activities in Israel after previously selling its bus operations in Israel in 2013. Veolia continues to be the target of boycott pressure, as it maintains a stake in the Jerusalem Light Rail.

headline: 20 South African businesses end contracts with G4S
summary: A group of South African businesses terminate their contracts with G4S over its involvement in Israeli prisons and human rights abuses after being approached by local activists. The contracts were worth an estimated $500,000 per year.

headline: Arab Labor Organization joins BDS
summary: The Arab Labor conference in Kuwait resolves that the Arab Labor Organization will join BDS. The Arab Labor Organization is an Arab League organization that consists of representatives of governments, private sectors, and trade unions in Arab countries.

headline: Major trade union in Quebec joins BDS
summary: The Central Council of the Confederation of National Trade Unions, Quebec, Canada votes to join the BDS movement and support the call to impose a military embargo on Israel. The CSN represents 325,000 workers in all sectors of activity in nearly 2,000 unions across Quebec.

headline: Egyptian civil society launches BDS Egypt
summary: A coalition of ten political parties, 15 student unions and groups,  six unions, and a number of civil society organisations, in addition to more than a hundred prominent political and media figures and artists, join together to start up the BDS Egypt movement.

headline: Barclays Bank no longer listed as Elbit shareholder
summary: UK high street bank Barclays sells $2.9 million of shares in Elbit Systems, the major Israeli military company that manufactures drones used by Israel. The decision follows a campaign of public pressure that included an Avaaz petition signed by 1.7 million people.

headline: 450+ Belgian academics join academic boycott
summary: 450+ Belgian academics sign a pledge endorsing the academic boycott of Israeli academic institutions.

headline: US hip hop artist Lauryn Hill cancels Israel concert
summary: Lauryn Hill releases a statement saying "we have decided to cancel the upcoming performance in Israel." Her decision follows an active campaign by organizers asking her not to cross the Palestinian picket line by performing in Israel.

headline: 1,600 professors and researchers from Spain join academic boycott
summary: More than 1,600 academic professors and researchers from across the Spanish state sign a declaration in support of the academic boycott.

headline: Belgian theatre group cancels appearance in Israel
summary: CAMPO, a Belgian theatre group, cancels a scheduled appearance at the Israel Festival in Israel.

headline: Brazilian social movements and progressive organisations call on government not to contract Israeli security company
summary: After International Security and Defence Systems, an Israeli security company, announced that it had received a $2.2 billion deal to coordinate security at the 2016 Olympic Games, 30 Brazilian social movements and progressive organisations call on the government of Brazil to cancel the contract. In response, the Brazilian government clarifies that ISDS had not been awarded the contract.

headline: Spanish state singer Marinah cancels Israel concert
summary: Marinah becomes the first singer from the Spanish state to cancel a scheduled concert in Israel. She was set to take part in the World Music Festival of Tel Aviv.

headline: 10,000 South African school students march to demand a boycott of Woolworths Supermarket
summary: More than 10,000 South African school students protest against Woolworths Supermarket over its trade with Israel. A researcher at Wits University estimates that Woolworths has lost millions of dollar since the #BoycottWoolworths campaign started in August 2014.

headline: Princeton graduate students vote in favor of divestment
summary: The majority (56%) of Princeton graduate students vote in favor of an initiative to divest from companies that profit off of Israeli human rights abuses.

headline: Finnish World Village Festival rejects participation by Jewish National Fund
summary: The Finnish World Village Festival notifies the Jewish National Fund that they will not be allowed to participate in the festival due to "questions about the legality of its activities." The Jewish National Fund controls land confiscated from Palestinians during and practices discrimination in the development and management of this land.

headline: The University of Helsinki in Finland cancels G4S contract
summary: A campaign backed by unions representing University of Helsinki academics and students leads the university to cancel its security contract with G4S. The campaign highlights the security company's role in human rights abuses against Palestinians, such as detention without trial and the use of torture, including of children.

headline: Earlham College Student Senate passes divestment motion
summary: By consensus decision, the Student Senate of Earham College passes a resolution in support of divestment from companies directly involved in the Israeli Occupation of Palestine, including Motorola Solutions, Hewlett Packard, and Caterpillar.

headline: Oglethorpe University students vote to divest
summary: Oglethorpe University in Atlanta, Georgia becomes the first university in the southeastern United States to successfully pass a divestment resolution targeting companies that are complicit in Israeli human rights abuses.

headline: Orange announces plans to exit Israeli market
summary: French telecom company Orange announces that it plans to end its relationship with an Israeli telecom, Partner Communications. The announcement follows boycott campaigns in Egypt and France, with Egypt being one of Orange's largest markets. Partner Communications provides services and infrastructure in illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: Protesters temporarily close four Elbit factories
summary: On the one year anniversary of Israel's 2014 attack on Gaza, organizers staged protests at four Elbit-owned factories in the UK and Australia, succeeding in forcing them to temporarily halt production. A general manager at one of the closed factories stated that the protests cost the company $280,000 in lost revenue. Elbit systems is Israel's largest arms manufacturer, whose drones and other weapons are used against civilians in Gaza.

headline: Multiple reports predict steep economic cost of BDS for Israel
summary: A leaked report by the Israeli government predicts that BDS could cost the country $1.4 billion per year, while a study by the Rand Corporation states that BDS could cost Israel $47bn over 10 years. The Ministry of Strategic Affairs receives $25.6m towards fighting BDS.

headline: UN agency reports 46% decline in foreign direct investment in Israel
summary: The UN’s trade and development agency UNCTAD releases its annual World Investment Report on foreign direct investment (FDI), finding that FDI into Israel fell by 46% in 2014. The report attributes the drop to the 2014 Israeli assault on Gaza and the growth of boycotts.

headline: American musician Thurston Moore (Sonic Youth) cancels Israel gig
summary: Thurston Moore, an American musician and Sonic Youth band member, explains why he cancelled a scheduled show in Tel Aviv, stating that the decision stems from his belief in “empowerment through choice of non-violent activism.”

headline: United Church of Christ passes resolution for boycott and divestment
summary: The United Church of Christ passes a resolution calling for boycott and divestment from companies that profit from Israel's occupation of Palestinian lands.

headline: 200 mental health professionals object to conference in Israel
summary: 200 mental health professionals sign an open letter to the European Association of Behavioural and Cognitive Therapists (EABCT) calling on them to move their upcoming annual conference in Israel in keeping with ethical commitments of therapeutic work.

headline: University of Valencia Faculty of Geography and History declares Apartheid Free Zone
summary: Declaring its department an Apartheid Free Zone, the University of Valencia Faculty of Geography and History becomes the first anywhere in Europe to officially endorse a BDS initiative.

headline: The BDS movement marks its 10th year
summary: On the 10th anniversary of the BDS call issued by Palestinian civil society, international figures and Palestinian leaders speak on the growth and impact of the movement. A press conference includes comments from Chief Mandla Mandela, grandson of Nelson Mandela and member of the South African Parliament; Marcel Khalife, prominent Lebanese musician and UNESCO Artist for Peace; Rebecca Vilkomerson, director of Jewish Voice for Peace.

headline: SodaStream CEO testifies to US congress on impact of BDS
summary: In a special hearing on the Impact of the Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions Movement arrange by the US House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, SodaStream CEO Daniel Birnbaum speaks to the impact of BDS on the company. He says that the company has faced numerous boycotts in the UK, Denmark, Italy, and Japan.

headline: 20 Italian artists call for boycott
summary: At the 2015 Venice Biennale, 20 prominent Italian artists launched an open letter calling on artists to use "leverage to bring global attention to injustice" and highlighting the boycott call.

headline: 1,100+ Black activists, artists, scholars, students and organizations sign statement of solidarity
summary: 1,100+ Black activists, artists, scholars, students and organizations sign a statement to reaffirm "solidarity with the Palestinian struggle and commitment to the liberation of Palestine’s land and people." The list of signatories includes scholar-activists Angela Davis and Cornel West, political prisoners Mumia Abu-Jamal and Sundiata Acoli, rappers Talib Kweli, Boots Riley and Jasiri X, Black Lives Matter co-founder Patrisse Cullors, and forty organizations. The statement highlights G4S' role in Israeli and U.S. human rights abuses.

headline: United Electrical, Radio & Machine Workers of America adopts BDS
summary: The United Electrical, Radio & Machine Workers of America, with 35,900 members, becomes the first major US national trade union to adopt BDS.

headline: Veolia withdraws from Jerusalem Light Rail, exits Israeli market
summary: After selling almost all its Israeli business in April 2015, Veolia confirms that it has withdrawn from its final project, the Jerusalem Light Rail. With this withdrawal, Veolia has completely exited the Israeli market after almost a decade of BDS campaigns cost the company an estimated $21 billion in contracts.

headline: European Parliament votes to label settlement products
summary: For the first time, the European Parliament expressed support for labeling products from illegal Israeli settlements as part of a policy of "territorial differentiation" between Israel and the settlements. The motion passes 525-70 with 31 abstaining. The Palestinian BDS National Committee clarifes that the move is "insufficient for fulfilling European states’ legal obligations under international law" and calls for continued grassroots action.

headline: 154 EU civil society organizations call out anti-BDS measures in EU-US trade deal
summary: 154 EU civil society organizations sign and open letter condemning attempts by the US to suppress BDS via measures proposed during Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) negotiations. Green and labor rights campaigners also fear TTIP will lead to a weakening of standards on such issues as food safety, public health and pollution.

headline: Brazil refuses to accept settler as Israeli ambassador
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff rejects the nomination of Dani Dayan, the former head of the Yesha Council, which represents the illegal Israeli settlements in the West Bank, as Israeli ambassador to Brazil.

headline: World Bank report shows 24% drop in Palestinian imports from Israel
summary: A World Bank Report shows that Palestinian imports from Israel fell 24% during the first quarter of 2015, and partially attributes the drop to boycotts of Israeli goods by Palestinians.

headline: Alphega pharmacies stop selling Ahava
summary: Alphega pharmacies, a Dutch network of more than 6000 pharmacies, confirms that it no longer sells Ahava products, stating that they do not sell well. Ahava has been the target of consumer boycott campaigns due to operating out of an illegal Israeli settlement in the West Bank and its use of Palestinian resources from the Dead Sea.

headline: Black Lives Matter co-founder Patrisse Cullors explains why she supports BDS
summary: Black Lives Matter co-founder Patrisse Cullors expresses support for BDS and calls on students at Stanford University to divest. She says "no studying could prepare me for the level of violence and trauma that exists inside Palestine" and "divestment is an action that everyday people of conscience around the world can take to show that we have not abandoned Palestinians."

headline: 160 Belgian artists pledge not to perform in Israel
summary: 160 Belgian artists sign a pledge not to perform in Israel, citing its "political abuse of art and culture in the service of apartheid."

headline: Seville football club turns down $5.7 million Israeli sponsorship
summary: La Liga football club in Seville rejected a $5.7 million sponsorship offer from Israel. Club president President José Castro says the decision was taken to ensure the club "stayed true to its principles, which value ethics over economic concerns.”

headline: Four Colombian film festivals join cultural boycott
summary: Four Colombia film festivals, including “Globale Bogotá”,  “Derecho a Ver”, “Muestra Arrecheras Heterodisidentes” and “Festival Internacional de Cortometrajes y Escuelas de Cine El Espejo”, announce that they will join the cultural boycott of Israel.

headline: Hundreds of UK academics join academic boycott
summary: UK academics place an ad in the Guardian consisting of a pledge to join the academic boycott of Israel. 343 academics sign the initial pledge, but the number of signatories quickly reaches 500 after publication, and continues to grow to 700 by 2019.

headline: Connecticut branch of major US labor union adopts BDS
summary: The 200,000-member strong Connecticut branch of American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations adopts BDS and calls on the national federation to follow suit.

headline: SodaStream announces it will close factory in illegal Israeli settlement
summary: SodaStream announces that it plans to close its factory in Mishor Adumim, an illegal Israeli settlement in the West Bank. This decision comes after boycott pressure saw SodaStream deshelved by major retailers across North America and Europe.

headline: Israeli arms manufacturers site fall in exports
summary: In a letter to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Israeli arms companies report a drop from $7.5bn to $5.5bn in exports from 2012 to 2014, citing “less desire for Israeli-made products” as a key factor. That period saw major popular mobilizations in multiple countries calling for a two way arms embargo against Israel.

headline: Brazilian musician Caetano Veloso says he will not return to Israel
summary: Although he did not heed BDS calls to cancel an appearance in Israel, Caetano Veloso writes that he will not return to Israel after visiting the West Bank and witnessing segregation. He writes, "all the complaints of the BDS participants are founded."

headline: Eight prominent American artists appear in cultural boycott video
summary: Eight prominent artists appear in a video endorsing the cultural boycott of Israel produced by Adalah-NY. Artists include Tony-nominated stage and television actress Kathleen Chalfant; musician Roger Waters (Pink Floyd); musicians Kyp Malone and Tunde Adebimpe (TV on the Radio); musicians Kool A.D and Tamar-kali; artist and author of Drawing Blood, Molly Crabapple; and visual artist Swoon.

headline: City Council of Amsterdam nixes proposal to twin with Tel Aviv
summary: After local protests against the idea of officially twinning Amsterdam and Tel Aviv, the City Council of Amsterdam decides against the proposal.

headline: San Jose State University students pass divestment resolution
summary: San Jose State University becomes the first California State University to pass a student government resolution to divest from companies complicit in the Israeli occupation of Palestineby a vote of 10-5.

headline: UK Labour party ends conference security contract with G4S
summary: The National Executive Committee (NEC) of the Labour Party votes to end its contract with G4S to provide security at its party conference, citing "concerns that this company has acted unethically and has been found to be in breach of the human rights obligations of the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Companies."

headline: National Women’s Studies Association adopts BDS
summary: Members of the National Women’s Studies Association endorse the Palestinian call for BDS by an overwhelming 90% vote, joining thousands of academics in Spain, Belgium, the UK, and South Africa in calling for an academic boycott of Israel in 2015.

headline: Portuguese retailer Worten drops SodaStream from 135 stores across the country
summary: After pressure from local organizers, Portuguese retailer Worten decides to stop selling SodaStream in its 135 stores across the country.

headline: UNHCR in Jordan says it no longer has contracts with G4S
summary: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in Jordan ends its contract with G4S, the first success in the #UNdropG4S campaign.

headline: American journalist and Hillary Clinton biographer opts not to work with Israeli publisher
summary: Doug Henwood, an American journalist and author of "My Turn", a biography of Hillary Clinton that is critical of her policies, announces he supports the BDS movement and will not sell rights to the book to Israeli publishers.

headline: More than 200 South African academics ensorse academic boycott
summary: Over 200 South African academics sign a declaration to join the academic boycott of Israel by not accepting invitations to visit Israeli academic institutions; not acting as referees for Israeli institutions; and not participating in conferences organised or funded by Israeli institutions.

headline: French telecom Orange ends relationship with Israeli company
summary: French telecom company Orange confirms the termination of its franchise relationship with the Israeli company Partner Communications following boycott campaigns in Egypt and France. Partner Communications provides services and builds infrastructure to support illegal Israeli settlements in occupied Palestinian territory.

headline: United Methodist Church divests from Israeli banks
summary: The Pension and Health Benefits Fund of the United Methodist Church, which manages $20.9 billion in assets, deems the five largest Israeli banks off limits for investment, and divests from two Israeli banks, Bank Hapoalim and Bank Leumi. Israeli banks support the occupation, for example by providing financing for the construction of illegal Israeli settlements in the Occupied Palestinian Territories.

headline: International building materials corporation CRH exits Israeli market
summary: International building materials corporation CRH exits the Israeli market by selling off its 25% equity stake in its Israeli operation Nesher Cement. Nesher Cement is involved in the construction of the Israeli wall and Israeli settlements, which are illegal under international law.

headline: Over 200 Brazilian academics join academic boycott
summary: Over 200 Brazilian academics sign an open letter affirming their “commitment to social justice and against all forms of racism” and pledging to “support the campaign for academic boycott of Israel in the terms proposed by the BDS movement.” Signatories included Paulo Sergio Pinheiro, professor and former UN rapporteur and B. Boris Vargaftig, physician and pharmacologist, and one of the most internationally quoted Brazilian academics.

headline: University of South Florida students pass Israel divestment resolution
summary: After two years of campaigning, the University of South Florida student senate passes a joint resolution calling on the board of trustees of the USF Foundation to divest from Caterpillar, Hewlett-Packard, G4S, Boeing, Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman, companies that are complicit in Israel's military occupation and human rights abuses against Palestinians. USF has also passed resolutions on divestment from private prisons and fossil fuels.

headline: 170 Italian academics join academic boycott
summary: 170 academics from more than 50 Italian universities and research institutes sign a pledge committing to a boycott of Israeli academic institutions. This marks the first Italian initiative of academic boycott. The initiative exclusively targets Israeli institutions while allowing for individual collaborations with Israeli colleagues.

headline: Cordoba Province in Spain declares itself Israeli Apartheid Free Zone
summary: In Spain, Cordoba province declares itself an 'Israeli Apartheid Free Zone' and approves cooperation with the BDS movement.

headline: 25 Oscar nominees skip free trip to Israel
summary: Oscars nominees opt not to take a free 10-day trip to Israel partially funded by the Israeli government. The trip was gifted to 5 Oscar-nominated directors and 20 lead and supporting actor and actress nominees, including Leonardo DiCaprio, Sylvester Stallone, Mark Rylance, Cate Blanchett, Jennifer Lawrence, Matt Damon and Kate Winslet.

headline: Colombian restaurant chain ends contract with G4S
summary: Crepes & Waffles, a major restaurant chain in Colombia, decides to end a contract with G4S following a year long BDS campaign.

headline: University College London Union votes to support BDS
summary: University College London Union passes a motion to support BDS by a margin of 14-4, with 3 abstentions.

headline: Unitarian Universalists divest from Hewlett Packard Enterprise, HP Inc., Motorola Solutions, and Caterpillar Inc.
summary: Unitarian Universalist Association's Committee on Socially Responsible Investing implements a new human rights investment screen. Hewlett Packard Enterprise, HP Inc., Motorola Solutions, Caterpillar Inc. are among several companies subject to disinvestment by UUA's Common Endowment Fund after failing to meet its human rights standards.

headline: Columbia University professors launch faculty divestment petition
summary: 78 professors at Columbia University sign a faculty petition calling on the university to divest from all corporations that supply, perpetuate, and profit off of Israel's military occupation.

headline: UNICEF in Jordan ends G4S contract
summary: The United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) in Jordan ends its contract with G4S following a campaign by BDS activists in the country over the company’s role in Israel’s detention and torture of Palestinian political prisoners and other Israeli human rights violations.

headline: 46 Palestinian women's groups call on women around the world to endorse BDS
summary: Palestinian women's groups sign an open letter calling on women and feminists around the world, as well as women’s organizations and collectives, to endorse the BDS Call. The letter details the impact of Israeli military occupation on Palestinian women, and expresses a vision of "an inclusive feminist vision that struggles for racial, social and economic justice, and is in solidarity with indigenous peoples and sovereignty rights globally."

headline: G4S announces plans to exit Israeli market
summary: After losing contracts worth millions of dollars in more than a dozen countries, G4S announces it will sell its Israeli subsidiary in 12-24 months, ending contracts with the Israeli military, prison service, police, and settlements to “[extract] itself from reputationally damaging work.”

headline: Israeli cosmetics company Ahava announces plans to move factory
summary: Ahava, an Israeli cosmetics company that appropriates resources from the Dead Sea in the occupied West Bank, announced it will move its factory from Mitzpeh Shalem, an illegal settlement in the West Bank, to another location in present-day Israel.

headline: Swedish foreign ministry says governments should not interfere with BDS action
summary: In response to Israeli claims that Swedish foreign minister Margot Wallström had promised in private meetings to publicly denounce BDS, the Swedish foreign ministry clarifies, "As regards BDS, it is a civil society movement. Governments should not interfere in civil society organization views."

headline: Bahia province in Brazil cancels Mekorot contract
summary: Following a campaign by civil society, legislators in the Brazilian province of Bahia ended an agreement between Bahia’s two water utility companies, Embasa and CERB and Israeli water company Mekorot. Mekorot is the target of BDS campaigns due to its role in restricting Palestinians access to water.

headline: Amnesty International calls on Israeli government to end "long standing attacks" on human rights defenders
summary: Amnesty International issues a statement demanding an end to attacks and intimidation against Palestinian human rights defenders. The statement highlights Israeli legislation curtailing freedom of expression, as well as assassination threats made by Israeli ministers against Omar Barghouti and other Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions (BDS) activists.

headline: University of Chicago students vote to divest
summary: University of Chicago student government passed a resolution calling on the university to divest assets from firms aiding or profiting from Israel’s violation of human rights and international law in Palestine.

headline: UNOPS ends relationship with G4S
summary: The United Nations Office for Project Services (UNOPS) in Jordan becomes the third UN agency in the country to cut ties with G4S over the firm’s role in Israeli human rights abuses.

headline: NYU graduate student union joins BDS
summary: The Graduate Student Organizing Committee (GSOC), a union of student workers at NYU, votes to join BDS. The referendum was triggered by a petition calling for divestment from Israeli institutions and international companies complicit in human rights violations against Palestinians.

headline: Dalhousie University student union votes for divestment
summary: The Dalhousie University student union votes to divest from nine companies that profit off of Israeli human rights abuses, including Caterpillar, General Mills, Teva Pharmaceuticals, Toyota, United Technologies, Adidas, and Allianz.

headline: Alliance of Baptists endorses BDS
summary: At their National Gathering, the Alliance of Baptists affirmed the use of nonviolent boycott, divestment, and sanctions (BDS) strategies and comprehensive education and advocacy programs to end the Israeli occupation, and Endowment Committee of the Alliance Board of Directors to divest from companies that profit off of the occupation.

headline: University of Chile’s Law Faculty students vote to support BDS
summary: In a referendum held by the University of Chile Law Faculty, 64% of students voted to cut ties with Israeli universities. Close to one thousand students participated in the referendum

headline: Catholic Conference of Major Superiors of Men calls for boycott and divestment
summary: Catholic Conference of Major Superiors of Men, a national organization of Catholic leaders, calls for a boycott of Israeli settlements and divestment from companies that profit off of Israel's occupation. Their statement highlights Sodastream, Keter/Black and Decker, Ahava Cosmetics, Motorola, Hewlett Packard, Caterpillar, and the top 5 Israeli Banks as boycott and divestment targets.

headline: Two Dutch political parties call for sanctions on Israel
summary: At the Dutch national congress, Democrats 66 and the Green Left parties each adopted motions calling for the suspension of the EU-Israel Association Agreement if Israel does not halt its construction of settlements on occupied lands.

headline: Reebok cancels plans for special edition Israel sneaker
summary: International sportswear maker Reebok cancels plans by an Israeli distributer to market a special edition sneaker marking the 68th anniversary of Israel's statehood. A Reebok spokesperson said, "we do not support this initiative.”

headline: Israeli Apartheid Week events take place in 225 cities
summary: Israeli Apartheid Week events take place in 225 cities with the aim "to educate people about the nature of Israel as an apartheid system and to build Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions (BDS) campaigns as part of a growing global BDS movement."

headline: Major British unions push G4S to clarify Israel exit plan
summary: Four British Unions, including Unite the Union, UNISON, NUT, UCATT, and the Fire Brigades Union, sign an open letter to G4S CEO Ashley Almanza pushing for clarifications on when G4S will exit Israel, following its exit announcement in March 2016.

headline: Uruguayan union calls for boycott and divestment
summary: The Human Rights Secretariat of the Uruguayan Federation of Workers of Services and Commerce (Fuecys) calls for the boycott of Israeli products and for companies in Uruguay to break their ties with Israeli insitutions that contribute to the violation of Palesitnian human rights.

headline: Ontario parliament rejects anti-BDS law
summary: Ontario parliament members vote 39-18 to strike down a bill that would have created a blacklist of persons and organizations supporting or participating in the BDS movement. The New Democratic Party's spokesperson on higher education describes the bill as an attack on freedom of speech and academic freedom.

headline: UW-Madison Union of Graduate Student Workers (TAA) endorses BDS movement
summary: Members of the Teaching Assistants’ Association at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, the oldest graduate student labor union in the United States representing over 9,000 graduate workers and students, vote 81% in favor of a resolution to divest from the State of Israel and corporations that profit from the illegal occupation of Palestine.

headline: Irish festival refuses Israeli Embassy funding
summary: The Listowel Writers’ Week Festival decides not to accept funding from the Israeli Embassy in Ireland, following communication with local activists.

headline: Irish and Dutch governments affirm right to call for BDS
summary: The Dutch and Irish governments publicly state that calls for a boycott of Israel are legitimate, following a similar statement by the Swedish government. The Dutch foreign minister describes BDS as “protected by the freedom of expression”, while the Irish foreign minister says BDS is a “legitimate political viewpoint.”

headline: Large coalition of US rights groups affirms right to boycott
summary: A large coalition of US human rights groups, including the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), sends an opposition letter to the New York legislature over proposed bills that would suppress the right to boycott, calling such measures "dangerous and unconstitutional."

headline: Bondy municipality votes to boycott settlement goods
summary: Bondy, a municipality near Paris, France, passes a motion to boycott products from Israeli settlements and called for the enforcement of European Commission regulations that require settlement goods entering the European union to be clearly labeled.

headline: Moroccan shop owners boycott Israeli dates
summary: Following a campaign by local activists, dozens of Moroccan shop owners in the Darb Mila date markets to stop selling Israeli “Medjoul” dates.

headline: 356 European rights groups call on EU to support right to boycott
summary: 356 European human rights organisations, church groups, trade unions and political parties sign a letter calling on the EU commission to “introduce the human rights guidelines guaranteeing freedom of speech and right to boycott and to use all other means you have in your disposal to support European citizens in their struggle to uphold basic human rights.”

headline: Kuwaiti social security fund divests from G4S
summary: The Public Institution for Social Security (PIFSS) in Kuwait divests from G4S over its role in Israeli human rights abuses.

headline: International Federation of Human Rights (FIDH) endorses right to call for BDS
summary: The International Federation of Human Rights (FIDH), a federation for human rights organizations representing 184 member organisations in over 100 countries, releases a statement supporting the right to participate in and call for Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions.

headline: Centre for the Study of Violence and Reconciliation (CSVR) in South Africa cancels participation in conference hosted in Israel
summary: The Centre for the Study of Violence and Reconciliation (CSVR) in South Africa withdraws its participation from an International Network of Genocide Scholars (INoGS) conference set to be held at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, stating that they “cannot turn a blind eye to the nature of the location and the host institutions for the conference.”

headline: More than 2,500 academics and intellectuals in the Gulf region endorse academic boycott
summary: More than 2,500 academics and intellectuals in the Gulf region call for academic boycott of Israel in a letter that specifically condemns meetings between Israeli and Saudi government officials. Earlier in 2016, hundreds of Brazilian and Italian scholars pledged to boycott.

headline: City of Denver drops G4S
summary: The city of Denver, Colorado decides to drop its $2.5 million municipal contract with G4S over the "company's notorious oppressive practices."

headline: The Presbyterian Church USA assembly votes to study the BDS call
summary: The Presbyterian Church USA assembly votes to study the BDS call and "prayerfully listen to and understand" the demands of Palestinian civil society.

headline: The editorial board of the Los Angeles Times defends right to boycott
summary: In an article titled "Boycotts of Israel are a protected form of free speech", the Los Angeles Times editorial board speaks out against US laws that seek to punish supporters of BDS.

headline: United Congregational Church of Southern Africa (UCCSA) becomes first South African church to join BDS
summary: At the South African Synod Conference, the United Congregational Church of Southern Africa (UCCSA) issues a statement of support for BDS, become the first church in South Africa to do so. The UCCSA has 500,000 members in 450 local congregations in Botswana, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Zimbabwe.

headline: Pharrell Williams cancels Israel gig
summary: Pharrell Williams, a ten-time Grammy Award winning artist, has cancels a performance in Tel Aviv. Williams does not provide an explanation on his reasons for cancellation.

headline: Massachussetts state senate withdraws anti-BDS bill
summary: The Massachusetts senate withdraws an anti-boycott amendment following a campaign by Palestine solidarity groups. The amendment, which was tacked onto an unrelated economic bill, would have blacklisted individuals and businesses that engage with the Palestinian-led boycott of Israel.

headline: 32 members of the European Parliament affirm right to boycott
summary: 32 members of the European Parliament express concern regarding “growing attempts to silence and repress advocates of BDS” and call on the EU to “guarantee that it will not introduce measures aimed at limiting freedom of expression regarding the Middle East and BDS.” They also call to recognize Omar Barghouti, a co-founder of the BDS movement, as a human rights defender.

headline: Berkeley City Council resolves to divest from private prisons
summary: The Berkeley City Council passes a unanimous resolution to direct the City Manager to consider creating a portfolio screen preventing any future investments in private prison corporations including GEO Group, CoreCivic, Inc., and G4S.

headline: National Labor Relations Board confirms legality of union support for BDS
summary: The National Labor Relations Board dismisses a complaint brought by an Israeli law firm claiming that support for BDS by the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America (UE) amounts to a violation of trade union legislation.

headline: Movement for Black Lives (M4BL) policy platform references BDS
summary: The Movement for Black Lives (M4BL) releases a policy platform calling for an end to military aid to Israel, and a reinvestment of those funds into "reparations and for building a just and equitable society domestically." The platform also promises to act against anti-BDS legislation. The Palestinian BDS National Committee endorses the M4BL platform and pledges to stand in solidarity with black Americans resisting state violence.

headline: Demonstration by Celtic fans aims to raise awareness of BDS
summary: Celtic Football Club fans unfurl Palestinian flags during a match with with an Israeli team in order "to raise awareness of the Boycott, Divest, Sanctions (BDS) campaign" and protest policies implemented by Scotland and the Union of European Football Association to prohibit political messages at matches. The protest prompted fans of other teams to take similar action.

headline: Portuguese Ministry of Justice withdraws from training exchange with Israeli police
summary: The Portuguese Ministry of Justice announces it has withdrawn its participation in LAW TRAIN, a joint EU-funded project with the Israeli Ministry of Public Security, the Israeli National Police and Israel’s Bar Ilan university. The  project aimed to unify police interrogation methodologies. The Israeli Ministry of Public Security and Israel’s police carry out illegal detention, routinely use torture during interrogations, and deploy excessive violence against Palestinian protesters.

headline: The Green Party of Canada adopts BDS
summary: At its annual convention, the Green Party of Canada passes a resolution incorporating BDS into its platform. The resolution states that the Green Party will support using BDS to target sectors of the Israeli economy and society that profit from the occupation, and will oppose efforts to prohibit or punish support for BDS. In December 2016, this resolution is replaced with another resolution that also calls for economic sanctions against Israel.

headline: UK composer Brian Eno refuses to license music groups sponsored by Israeli state
summary: UK composer Brian Eno writes a letter to two dance companies using his music, stating "I don’t want my music to be licensed for any event sponsored by the Israeli embassy."

headline: Spanish state towns and cities declare themselves Israeli Apartheid Free Zones
summary: More than 50 cities and towns across the Spanish state, including Gran Canaria, Santiago de Compostela, Xixón-Gijón, Sevilla, Córdoba and Santa Eulària in Ibiza, vote to declare themselves free from Israeli apartheid. Local authorities in these areas agree to boycott corporations complicit in violations of international law, break ties with the Israeli regime and its complicit institutions, and support local awareness raising efforts.

headline: Irish town council calls for boycott on Israeli goods
summary: Derry City and Strabane District Council in Northern Ireland passes 29-9 in favor of boycotting Israeli goods.

headline: French labour union joins BDS
summary: The French General Confederation of Labour ‐ National Institute for Agricultural Research (CGT‐INRA) releases a statement of support for BDS tactics.

headline: French suburb with 60,000 residents affirms right to boycott
summary: The town council of Ivry-sur-Seine, a Paris suburb with 60,000 residents, voted by a large majority to call on the French government to end its criminalization of BDS and Palestine solidarity activism, and calls for a ban on the importation of goods from Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank and Syria’s Golan Heights.

headline: Portland State University student senate passes divestment resolution
summary: The student senate of the Associated Students of Portland State University (ASPSU) passes a resolution calling on the university to divest from companies that profit off of Israeli human rights violations. The resolution passed 22-2, with 1 abstention. The resolution highlighted four corporations: Hewlett-Packard, Motorola Solutions, G4S and Caterpillar.

headline: Federica Mogherini, EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs, speaks on free expression and BDS
summary: Federica Mogherini, EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs, condemns attacks on human rights defenders and affirms the rights of European citizens to freedom of expression and association, including through participation in the BDS movement.

headline: Students at Norwegian University of Science and Technology adopt a BDS resolution
summary: Students at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology adopt a resolution opposing a possible collaboration between NTNU and Israeli universities on oil and gas research.

headline: World renowned Bolivian chef Kamilla Seidler drops out of event in Israel
summary: World-renowned Kamilla Seidler, head chef of Gustu restaurant in Bolivia, drops out of the Round Tables event sponsored by the Israeli government, which brings top chefs from around the world to take over the kitchens of Israeli restaurants for a week.

headline: US State Department official comments on right to boycott
summary: When asked if the US has a view on a bill introduced in the Israeli Knesset to ban supporters of BDS from entering Israel, US State Department Spokesperson Mark Toner said "we value freedom of expression, even in cases where we do not agree with the political views espoused." Toner also agreed that BDS is a nonviolent, peaceful effort.

headline: University of Qatar Students’ Union adopts BDS call
summary: University of Qatar Students’ Union passes a resolution calling for BDS.

headline: Trondheim city council in Norway adopts boycott of settlement goods
summary: Elected representatives in Trondheim, Norway’s third-largest city, vote to boycott goods and services from Israel’s settlements in the occupied West Bank, and call on Norweigian parliament to adopt the same policy.

headline: Global BDS Week of Action against HP includes 100 actions in 100 cities
summary: The Global BDS Week of Action against Hewlett Packard companies mobilizes 100 actions in 100 cities across 6 continents. The campaign against HP highlights the company's involvement in equipping Israeli authorities with technology and equipment used at checkpoints and other locations to restrict and control the Palestinian population.

headline: Japan External Trade Organization (JETRO) withdraws from event promoting wine from Israeli settlements
summary: The Japan External Trade Organization (JETRO) withdraws from hosting an Israel Wine Seminar planned by the Israeli embassy in Japan, which was set to feature win from illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: G4S confirms sale of most of Israeli business
summary: G4S confirms that it has sold its Israeli security business for $111 million, but the company retains a presence in Israel through its ownership stake in Policity Ltd., a company contracted by the Israeli police to build and operate Israel’s National Police Academy. The training provided by the National Police Academy includes repressive tactics used against Palestinian communities, such as crowd control, home invasions, interrogation techniques, target shooting, and undercover operations.

headline: UN World Food Program in Jordan ends G4S contract
summary: UN World Food Program in Jordan ends its contract with British security company G4S, becoming the fourth UN agency in Jordan to do so. The contract was reportedly worth $900,000 in 2015. Although the company confirmed the sale of its Israeli affiliate in December 2016, it continues to hold partial ownership of Policity Ltd., a company contracted by the Israeli police to build and operate Israel’s National Police Academy. The training provided by the National Police Academy includes repression tactics used on Palestinian communities, such as crowd control, house raids, interrogation techniques, target shooting and undercover operations.

headline: Canada's Green Party calls for economic pressure against Israel
summary: Following their approval of a BDS motion in August 2016, the Green Party of Canada passes a replacement addendum that calls for: "strong diplomatic action, including economic pressure" toward Israel; a ban on Israeli settlement goods; and the repeal of the House of Commons resolution condemning the BDS movement.

headline: Dutch government rejects call to cease funding organizations that support BDS
summary: The Dutch government clarifies that it will not bar BDS advocates from receiving aid, after NGO Monitor, a group with ties to the Israeli government and military, lobbied the Dutch government to review such funding. The Netherlands was among the first governments in Europe to uphold the right to BDS against Israel.

headline: 200 European legal scholars weigh in on right to boycott
summary: An open letter signed by 200 European legal scholars affirms the right to boycott as a lawful exercise of freedom of expression and condemns efforts by governments to suppress BDS.

headline: University of Manchester student senate votes to endorse BDS
summary: University of Manchester student senate passes a motion to endorse BDS, calling on the university to end institutional links with Technion (Israeli university) and to divest about $18 million in shares in corporations linked to Israel’s oppression of the Palestinians, such as Caterpillar.

headline: Two French municipal councils vote to boycott Israeli settlement products
summary: The municipal councils of Clermond-Ferrand and St. Pierre des Corps in France vote to boycott Israeli settlement products.
city: Clermond-Ferrand and St. Pierre des Corps

headline: UNICEF in Lebanon ends G4S contract
summary: The United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) in Lebanon ends its contract with British security company G4S, following a boycott campaign by activists in the country. Although the company confirmed the sale of its Israeli affiliate in December 2016, it continues to hold partial ownership of Policity Ltd., a company contracted by the Israeli police to build and operate Israel’s National Police Academy. The training provided by the National Police Academy includes repression tactics used on Palestinian communities, such as crowd control, house raids, interrogation techniques, target shooting and undercover operations.

headline: Tromsø city council in Norway votes to boycott certain Israeli goods and services
summary: The Tromsø city council in Norway votes 25-18 to adopt a boycott Israeli goods and services produced in areas occupied by Israel in 1967. Tromsø, which has a population of 75,000, is the second city in Norway to take such action.

headline: City of Portland pauses corporate investments amidst BDS pressure
summary: In response to pressure to divest from Caterpillar and other corporations that participate in Israeli human rights abuses, the City of Portland votes to suspend corporate investments in order to review its investment policies. In April 2017, the city votes to divest all city funds from corporations.

headline: Valencia city council votes unanimously to become Apartheid Free Zone
summary: Valencia, the third largest city in Spain, unanimously passes a resolution declaring itself an "Apartheid Free Zone." The motion includes the adoption of new ethical standards related to the enforcement of human rights and international law in city contracts and provincial grants.

headline: French government passes on Elbit for drone deal
summary: Elbit Systems, an Israeli arms company, loses a $100 million bid to provide more than 200 drones to the French Directorate General of Armament. BDS France ran a months-long campaign leading up to the decision. Activists wrote thousands of postcards to President François Hollande and staged rallies in dozens of cities. The decision marks the second time the French government has passed over Elbit since 2016.

headline: 6 NFL players withdraw from Israel tour
summary: Six NFL players in the United States turn down an Israeli government-sponsored, all expenses paid propaganda trip to Israel: Michael Bennett, Kenny Stills, Martellus Bennett, Cliff Avril, Carlos Hyde and Justin Forsett.

headline: UN-commissioned report finds that Israel is committing the crime of Apartheid
summary: UNESCWA publishes a report establishing that Israel has imposed a system of apartheid on the entire Palestinian people. The report also calls for BDS measures to end this apartheid regime.

headline: De Anza Community College in California passes divestment motion
summary: De Anza Community College in California becomes the first community college to pass a resolution in support of divestment from companies profiting from the Israeli occupation. The resolution named Hewlett-Packard Enterprises, Motorola Solutions, G4S, and Caterpillar as companies that “affect the De Anza community directly, including students whose families experience occupation, systematic discrimination, death, injury, and other forms of human rights violations."

headline: Doctors’ Syndicate in Beirut drops G4S
summary: The Doctors’ Syndicate in Beirut decides to end its relationship with G4S out of concern for Palestinian human rights. G4S is the largest security firm in the world. Although the company confirmed the sale of its Israeli affiliate in December 2016, it continues to hold partial ownership of Policity Ltd., a company contracted by the Israeli police to build and operate Israel’s National Police Academy. The training provided by the National Police Academy includes repression tactics used against Palestinian communities, such as crowd control, house raids, interrogation techniques, target shooting and undercover operations.

headline: Princess Nokia cancels show in Tel Aviv
summary: American rapper Princess Nokia cancels a scheduled appearance at the Tel Aviv Kalamazoo Festival. A statement released by festival organizers attributes the cancellation to "heavy BDS pressure".

headline: Tufts University student senate passes divestment resolution
summary: Students at Tufts University have passed a resolution urging the university to divest and withhold future investments from companies that support the Israeli occupation. The resolution specifically mentions divestment from Elbit Systems, G4S, Northrop Grumman, and Hewlett Packard Enterprise.

headline: Barcelona City Council adopts ethical procurement guidelines
summary: The Barcelona City Council votes to support Palestinian rights by adopting ethical procurement guidelines. These guidelines specifically exclude companies involved in Israel’s military occupation.

headline: Claremont Colleges – Pitzer students pass boycott amendment
summary: The Claremont Colleges – Pitzer Student Senate adopts an amendment to the Budget By-Laws which reads in part, “Student Activities Funds shall not be used to make a payment on goods or services from any corporation or organization associated with the unethical occupation of Palestinian territories.”

headline: University of Wisconson, Madison students pass divestment resolution
summary: University of Wisconsin Associated Students of Madison unanimously approved a divestment motion calling for an end to UW’s support of corporations that profit from human rights violations, and requesting greater transparency from the UW Foundation regarding its $3.1 billion investment portfolio.

headline: UK teachers union declares it will not buy or use HP products
summary: The UK's National Union of Teachers, the largest union of school teachers,  announces it will not buy or use products made by HP as a gesture of solidarity with Palestinians. HP provides services and technology to the Israeli military, used at checkpoints and prisons.

headline: Norway's largest trade union federation endorses boycott of Israel
summary: The Norwegian Confederation of Trade Unions, representing over 900,000 workers, endorses a full "international economic, cultural and academic boycott of Israel" as a "necessary means to achieve Palestinian fundamental rights."

headline: Two major Chilean Universities cancel Israeli embassy-sponsored events
summary: Two Chilean universities cancel events sponsored by the Israeli embassy. The event featured speaker Joe Uziel, a director of the Israel Antiquities Authority (IAA), who conducts illegal archaeological digs in the occupied Palestinian West Bank. The cancellation followed a campaign by students.

headline: 14 filmmakers and artists withdraw from TLVFest
summary: Fourteen filmmakers and other artists cancel their participation in TLVFest, an LGBTQ film festival sponsored by the Israeli government, in solidarity with the Palestinian LGBTQ community and in support of Palestinian human rights.

headline: Swiss Parliament's Upper House blocks a motion that would have criminalized BDS
summary: The Upper House of the Swiss Parliament amended a motion to remove language that criminalized BDS, noting that such language threatened the essential right of civil society to criticize governments.

headline: Sacramento transit drops G4S
summary: The Sacramento Regional Transit board drops its contract with G4S after a human rights and labor coalition highlighted the company’s role in violating human rights in Palestine and the United States.

headline: Israeli bus company Egged loses $212 million Dutch contract deal
summary: Egged Bus System, an Israeli bus company, is not awarded a $212 million (€190 million) deal to work on a public transportation project in the Province of North Holland. The bid was the subject of a campaign by local activists. Egged operates buses in Israel that are inaccessible to Palestinians and profits from running bus lines to illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: UK High Court upholds right of local councils to divest
summary: A UK court originally rules that the UK government acted unlawfully by attempting to restrict local councils from divesting from companies complicit in Israel’s violations of Palestinian human rights. However, on June 22, 2017, the UK Court of Appeals overrules the original decision in this case. The new ruling fails to protect the right of pension holders to make ethical decisions regarding the investment of their funds. In 2020, the UK Supreme Court rules in favor of PSC.

headline: The Spanish parliament affirms the right to advocate for Palestinian rights
summary: The Spanish parliament unanimously passes a motion recognizing the right to advocate for Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions (BDS) as protected under the right to freedom of expression and association. Hundreds of elected officials in the Spanish state also endorse BDS for Palestinian rights.

headline: The Mennonite Church USA votes to divests from companies profiting from the Israeli occupation
summary: The Mennonite Church USA's votes by an overwhelming 98% majority to divest from companies that profit from the Israeli occupation, following several mainline churches that adopted similar policies in recent years. The Mennonite resolution addresses the injustices of military occupation as well as the suffering caused by antisemitism.

headline: 200+ Latin American groups write #StopCemex campaign letter
summary: 200+ Latin American groups publish a letter addressed to the Board of Directors of the Mexican multinational company Cemex, calling on its members to end the company’s complicity in Israel’s human rights violations in the Occupied Palestinian Territory. Cemex is the second largest building materials company in the world and supplies Israel with cement and concrete for the construction of its wall, military checkpoints and illegal settlements in the Occupied Palestinian Territory.

headline: South African Council of Churches (SACC) and the Council of African Independent Churches (CAIC) announce support for BDS
summary: The South African Council of Churches (SACC) and the Council of African Independent Churches (CAIC), representing more than a million Christians in South Africa, release a media statement affirming their support for the Palestinian struggle and the BDS movement.

headline: The ACLU says US anti-boycott bill in Senate would infringe on Americans constitutional rights
summary: The American Civil Liberties Union writes a letter asking US Senators not to co-sponsor or vote for the Israel Anti-Boycott Act (H.R. 1697/S. 720), on the basis that it is unconstitutional. The letter refers to the US Supreme Court ruling in NAACP v. Claiborne  Hardware Co., which established that peaceful political  boycotts are protected under the First Amendment of the US Constitution.

headline: 23 US Churches pledge to go HP free
summary: 23 churches around the United States, representing seven different denominations, sign a pledge to boycott Hewlett-Packard (HP) until it stops selling information technology to the Israeli military and government. HP technology is used to support violations of Palestinian human rights at Israeli checkpoints and prisons.

headline: California Democrats pass resolution addressing repression of Palestinian activism
summary: The California Democratic Party passes a resolution at its state convention to reject efforts to "restrict or discourage open public discourse" about Israeli policy and oppose "any attempt to restrict or penalize those who exercise their views through nonviolent action to effect change." The resolution also admonished Israeli settlement activity and its practice of denying entry to activists who criticize the state.

headline: The 25,000-strong Democratic Socialists of America endorse the Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions movement
summary: At their annual national convention, the Democratic Socialists of America overwhelmingly pass a resolution to endorse the Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions movement. Over 90% of delegates voted in favor of the resolution.

headline: Hundreds of American rabbis sign "Rabbis Against Israel’s Travel Ban" letter
summary: More than 200 American rabbis sign a letter opposing Israel’s travel ban on BDS activists, calling it undemocratic.

headline: 8 musical acts withdraw from Pop-Kultur festival
summary: 8 musical acts withdraw from Pop-Kultur, a Berlin based music festival, because it accepted sponsorship from the Israeli embassy. In statements, many artists affirm their stands against all forms of discrimination and oppression and the responsibility of artists to be true to their beliefs.

headline: 40 Portuguese photographers pledge solidarity with Palestinian human rights
summary: On World Photography Day, over 40 Portuguese photographers, teachers of photography and photography students launch a pledge not to accept professional invitations or financing from the State of Israel and to refuse to collaborate with Israeli cultural institutions complicit in Israeli occupation and human rights abuses.

headline: Seven companies in Jordan cut ties with G4S
summary: Seven companies, including Jordan Hospital and Medical Center and local affiliates of Orange and IKEA cut ties with G4S. G4S is the largest security firm in the world. Although the company confirmed the sale of its Israeli affiliate in December 2016, it continues to hold partial ownership of Policity Ltd., a company contracted by the Israeli police to build and operate Israel’s National Police Academy. The training provided by the National Police Academy includes repression tactics used on Palestinian communities, such as crowd control, house raids, interrogation techniques, target shooting and undercover operations.

headline: Largest Canadian private-sector union endorses BDS
summary: UNIFOR, Canada’s largest private-sector union representing 310,000 workers, adopts a motion declaring support for "the use of divestment, boycott and sanctions (“BDS”) that are targeted to those sectors of Israel’s economy and society which profit from the ongoing occupation of the OPT."

headline: Medical students in Chile overwhelmingly vote to break institutional ties with Israeli universities
summary: More than 75% of students at the University of Chile’s Faculty of Medicine vote to break institutional ties with Israeli universities in a student referendum. They also vote against Israeli government sponsorship or attendance of events at their university. Before the vote, Palestinian medical students sent a video message to Chilean students, highlighting the impact of Israeli military occupation on their rights to health and education.

headline: UN starts issuing notices to companies doing business in Israeli settlements
summary: After voting in March 2016 to establish a database of companies doing business in Israeli settlements, the United Nations Human Rights Commissioner sends letters to 150 companies in Israel and around the world, warning them that they will be added to the database. Several companies reportedly respond saying they will not renew their contracts in Israel. Israeli settlements in the West Bank and East Jerusalem are illegal under international law.

headline: Two renowned chefs in Ireland and Peru reject invitation to participate in Israeli event
summary: Prominent chefs from 10 countries and more than 180 civil society groups wrote urging chefs not to participate in the Israeli Round Tables event, which brings top chefs from around the world to take over the kitchens of Israeli restaurants for a week. Irish chef JP McMahon, owner of the Michelin-starred restaurant Aniar, and Peruvian chef Mitsuharu Tsumura, owner of the world-class Maido restaurant, opted out of the event. The chefs did not directly refer to the BDS movement in their statements of cancellation.

headline: UN Women in Jordan drops G4S contract
summary: UN Women in Jordan ends its contract with G4S, the last of Jordan’s five UN agencies to do so, following UNHCR, UNICEF, the World Food Program, and UNOPS.

headline: Australia’s flying doctors drop Israeli arms maker Elbit
summary: One of the largest aeromedical organizations in the world, Australia’s Royal Flying Doctors (RFDS), refused services from the Israeli military and tech company Elbit Systems. Elbit Systems produces 85% of the drones used by the Israeli military, including those used to attack Palestinian civilians in Gaza from 2009 to 2014.

headline: Denmark's third largest pension fund moves to exclude companies involved in Israeli settlements
summary: Sampension, Denmark's third largest pension fund managing $46 billion in assets, excludes four companies from its portfolio based on their investments in illegal Israeli settlements: Israeli banks Hapoalim and Leumi; Heidelberg Cement, a German construction company; and Bezeq, Israel’s largest telecommunications company.

headline: Major Indian union of farmers and agricultural workers endorses BDS
summary: All India Kisan Sabha (AIKS), representing over 16 million farmers and agricultural workers across 21 states in India, endorses BDS. AIKS was formed in 1936, before India's independence from British colonialism. It played a critical role in mobilizing farmers and agricultural workers to end British imperialism.

headline: Air Canada ends contract with Israeli arms firm
summary: Air Canada ends a maintenance contract with the arms maker Israel Aerospace Industries. The five-year, multi-million dollar contract for heavy maintenance on Air Canada Boeing 767 jets was terminated with two years remaining.

headline: California State University, Long Beach students pass divestment resolution
summary: Members of the student government at California State University, Long Beach voted overwhelmingly in favor of calling on the university to divest from two companies linked to the Israeli occupation. The same day, they also passed resolutions encouraging divestment from companies that profit from LGBTQ+ oppression and private prisons.

headline: Leaders of 17 American Christian organizations urge congress to reject anti-BDS legislation
summary: Christian leaders in the US, including leaders of the Alliance of Baptists, the Presbyterian Church (USA) and the United Church of Christ, send an open letter to congress urging them to oppose the Israel Anti-Boycott Act.

headline: University of Michigan students pass divestment resolution
summary: The University of Michigan Central Student Government executive board passes a resolution on divestment and calls for the University's Board of Regents to create a committee to investigate three companies operating in Israel and involved in human rights violations against Palestinians

headline: South Africa's largest residential university endorses academic boycott
summary: Tshwane University of Technology (TUT), with over 60,000 students, endorsed the academic boycott of Israel.

headline: 9 Colombian grassroots groups call for BDS
summary: Major Colombian social movements, organizations and unions call for BDS in a letter highlighting South to South solidarity.

headline: Irish Communications Workers Union adopts BDS
summary: Communications Workers Union in Ireland officially endorses the call for BDS.

headline: Catholic University of Leuven in Belgium withdraws from LAW TRAIN
summary: The prestigious Catholic University of Leuven in Belgium announces that it will not collaborate on future phases of LAW TRAIN, an EU-funded research cooperation project that aims to share interrogation techniques between countries. The university's rector particularly cited ethical concerns stemming from the participation of the Israeli police and the Israeli Ministry of Public Security.

headline: South Africa's ruling African National Congress votes to downgrade diplomatic ties to Israel
summary: The African National Congress, South Africa's ruling party, voted unanimously to adopt the Oliver Tambo Resolution, which dicatates “an immediate and unconditional downgrade” of its embassy in Tel Aviv to a liaison office to show support for Palestinian human rights.

headline: Lorde cancels Israel concert
summary: In the wake of an open letter from two New Zealand-based activists, Lorde cancels her concert in Israel.

headline: More than 100 well-known artists sign letter of support for Lorde after she faces backlash for canceling Israel concert
summary: More than 100 prominent artists write in support of Lorde’s right to follow her conscience and exercise her right to boycott, including Roger Waters, Brian Eno, Angela Davis, Mark Ruffalo, Viggo Mortenson, and Alice Walker.

headline: Tunisia's largest union joins BDS
summary: The Tunisian General Labour Union adopts BDS on the seventh anniversary of the Revolution of Freedom and Dignity in Tunisia.

headline: Tunisian civil society calls for the academic and cultural boycott of Israel
summary: Prominent Tunisian academics, artists, and political and labor union leaders launch the Tunisian Campaign for the Academic and Cultural Boycott of Israel.

headline: Federal court strikes down Kansas law that punishes supporters of boycott
summary: In a major victory litigated by the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), a federal court strikes down a Kansas law that sought to silence human rights defenders who boycott Israel. The court rules that the law is an unconstitutional denial of free speech. In response to the ruling, Kansas no longer requires individuals paid by the state to certify that they do not boycott Israel.

headline: BDS movement nominated for Nobel Peace Prize
summary: Norwegian parliamentarian Bjørnar Moxnes nominates the BDS movement for Palestinian rights for a Nobel Peace Prize. This move is supported by Moxnes' progressive Rødt (Red) Party, which states that BDS "should be supported without reservation by all democratically-minded people and states."

headline: Brazilian political party PSOL reaffirms support for BDS
summary: At their National Congress gathering, the National Executive of PSOL, a Brazilian political party, reaffirms support for the BDS movement and its demands.

headline: Massachusetts legislature opts not to advance anti-boycott bill
summary: The Massachusetts Joint State Administration and Regulatory Oversight (SARO) committee sent an anti-boycott bill to study, rather than releasing it for a full vote of the legislature, effectively ending its chances of being passed in the current session. At a hearing in July, the ACLU of Massachusetts and other constitutional lawyers testified against the bill.

headline: Black artists and organizers in the US issue statement of support for H.R. 4391, a bill to protect Palestinian children
summary: Black artists and organizers call on US representatives to sign H.R. 4391, a bill to prevent US tax dollars from supporting the Israeli military's ongoing detention and abuse of Palestinian children. Signatories include Jesse Williams, Rosario Dawson, Tom Morello, Michelle Alexander, Danny Glover, Vic Mensa, Angela Davis and Talib Kweli.

headline: Indian women's movement organizations endorse BDS
summary: Orgazinations from the Indian women’s movement, representing over 10 million Indian women, demand the release of Palestinian teen activist Ahed Tamimi and all Palestinian child prisoners, and ensores the BDS movement as the most effective form of solidarity with Ahed and other child prisoners.

headline: California Democrats endorse bill protecting Palestinian children and oppose bills penalizing boycotts of Israel
summary: California Democrats vote to endorse a bill that would prevent US tax dollars from supporting the Israeli military’s ongoing detention and mistreatment of Palestinian children. They also vote to oppose bills that seek to silence supporters of the BDS movement.

headline: Bangkok's Kasetsart University ends partnership with Ariel University for Women's Studies Conference
summary: Kasetsart University in Bangkok and the International Center for Research and Development (ICRD) end a partnership with Ariel University focused on the International Conference on Gender & Women's Studies. They also revoke an invitation to Professor Mally Shechory-Bitton, Head of the Criminology Department at Ariel University, to serve as the academic chair and main keynote speaker for the conference. Ariel University is located in an illegal Israeli settlement.

headline: Washington court dismisses lawsuit against Olympia Food Co-op over Israel boycott
summary: A Washington state court dismisses a lawsuit filed in 2011 to block Olympia Food Co-op from boycotting Israeli products, after two lower courts dismissed the lawsuit in 2012 and 2014. Olympia Food Co-op was the first grocery store in the US to boycott Israeli goods.

headline: The Irish National Teachers Organisation (INTO) votes to support BDS
summary: The Irish National Teachers Organisation (INTO) votes to fully support the Irish Congress of Trade Union's (ICTU) position on Palestine, including full support for the BDS movement for Palestinian rights.

headline: Union of Students in Ireland (USI) votes for BDS
