summary: At their annual congress, the Union of Students in Ireland (USI) votes to join BDS. Moving forward, USI pledges to lobby universities to divest from companies that profit off of the Israeli occupation, as well as to support an academic boycott of Israeli institutions.

headline: Jeremy Corbyn speaks out on Israel’s killing of unarmed Palestinian protesters in Gaza
summary: Jeremy Corbyn, leader of the British Labour Party, expresses outrage over Israel's policy of killing unarmed Palestinian protesters in Gaza. He criticizes Western “silence” and demands an independent international inquiry.

headline: Green Party of Canada calls to suspend all military trade with Israel
summary: Green Party of Canada leader Elizabeth May releases a statement condemning "the shooting of unarmed civilians in a peaceful protest along the border between Gaza and Israel" and says Canada “must suspend all military trade with Israel.”

headline: 50+ NYU student groups endorse BDS
summary: More than 50 New York University (NYU) student groups endorse the BDS movement in an open letter, stating "we support the Boycott, Divestment, and Sanctions movement for Palestinian human rights as it is a non-violent method of resisting Israeli apartheid from abroad."

headline: Palestinian film actors, directors, and producers withdraw from Istanbul Film Festival over Israeli sponsorship
summary: A wave of actors, directors and producers withdraw from the Istanbul Film Festival after activists with BDS Turkey point out that the festival is accepting sponsorship from the Israeli government. Annemarie Jacir, Ossama Bawardi, Saleh Bakri, Mohammad Bakri, May Odeh, Muayad Alayan and Adeeb Safadi are among those who withdraw.

headline: Dublin City Council votes to support BDS movement and discontinue HP contracts
summary: Dublin becomes the first European capital to endorse BDS. Citing Israel’s “inhumane blockade and siege of Gaza,” the Dublin City Council promises to discontinue business contracts with Hewlett Packard-branded companies and spin-offs, including DXC Technology, given their complicity in Israel’s violations of Palestinian human rights.

headline: 42 civil society organizations demand publication of UN database of businesses in Israeli settlements
summary: 42 civil society organizations from 6 countries in Asia (Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Thailand, India & Pakistan) call on the United Nations to publish its database of companies operating in illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: Durham, North Carolina bans police department from Israel training exchange
summary: Durham, North Carolina becomes the first US city to ban its police department from participating in international exchanges with the Israeli military or police. In a unanimous vote, Durham’s City Council bans police exchanges with any international agencies that would give Durham officers “military-style training” contrary to the city's vision for community safety.

headline: Over 150 European civil society organizations call on EU to stop funding Israeli arms companies
summary: 150 trade unions, parties, NGOs and faith groups across 16 European countries call on the European Union to stop funding Israeli arms companies until Israel ceases its violations of Palestinian rights.

headline: Over 500 Latin American artists endorse cultural boycott of Israel
summary: Over 500 Latin American artists sign a statement to publicly endorse the Palestinian call for a cultural boycott of Israel. They pledge not to perform or exhibit in Israel and to decline Israeli funding until Israel respects the rights of the Palestinian people under international law.

headline: Barnard College students pass divestment resolution
summary: Students at Barnard College in New York vote to support a resolution to divest from companies profiting off of Israel's human rights violations. Reports say that “both opponents and supporters of the BDS movement believed that Barnard could be a bellwether" due to its large community of Jewish students.

headline: Natalie Portman refuses to attend Genesis Prize award ceremony in Israel
summary: American actress Natalie Portman refuses to attend the Genesis Prize award ceremony in Israel, where she was set to accept the million-dollar prize. Her decision not to appear came as Israeli forces shot 31 unarmed Palestinian protesters in Gaza. A representative of Portman states, "recent events in Israel have been extremely distressing to her and she does not feel comfortable participating in any public events in Israel."

headline: George Washington University Student Association Senate passes divestment motion
summary: The George Washington University Student Association Senate passes a motion calling on the university to divest from 9 companies that profit off of the Israeli occupation.

headline: Regional Council of Los Ríos, Chile calls for revision of military agreements with Israel
summary: The Regional Council of Los Rios, one of fifteen regional governments of Chile, approves a resolution that calls on the national government to “condemn the military repression against Palestinians in the Gaza Strip” and to “revise the cooperation agreement” between the Chilean army and the Israeli army until it is sure that Palestinian human rights are respected. The city of Valdivia, the capital of Los Rios, also calls for the revision of military agreements and for an end to “all economic negotiations and treaties with Israel.”

headline: Amnesty International calls for arms embargo on Israel
summary: Amnesty International calls for an arms embargo on Israel and releases a video promoting its call. Amnesty particularly criticizes the United States and the European Union for their military deals with Israel and holds them responsible for “fueling mass violations" of Palestinian human rights.

headline: The Movement for Black Lives issues statement of solidarity with Gaza protesters
summary: In the aftermath of Israeli attacks on unarmed Palestinian protesters in Gaza, the Movement for Black Lives in the United States releases a statement of solidarity with Palestinians and reiterates previous demands that the US government stop arming Israel.

headline: 36 filmmakers, journalists, and artists publish open letter calling for cultural boycott
summary: In an open letter published in The Guardian, 36 filmmaker, journalists, and artists, including Helena Kennedy, Maxine Peake and Juliet Stevenson, call on UK media and cultural institutions to "refuse to provide platforms for national celebrations sponsored by Israel." The letter comes as venues across the UK prepare to host events associated with the Seret London Israeli Film and TV Festival, co-sponsored by the Israeli embassy and the World Zionist Organisation.

headline: Jean-Luc Godard joins Israel cinema boycott
summary: Jean-Luc Godard and 80 other artists in France issue a joint letter denouncing France-Israel Cultural Season 2018, a joint cultural initiative sponsored by both the French and Israeli governments. Signatories refuse to participate in events organized within this framework.

headline: Federation of Journalists' Unions joins BDS in solidarity with Palestinian journalists
summary: The 4th Congress of the Federation of Journalists' Unions (FeSP) joins BDS and condemns Israel's attacks against journalists, citing that two journalists were killed and dozens injured by Israeli forces during the Great March of Return protests.

headline: Dublin Lord Mayor and Irish Eurovision winner Charlie McGettigan call for a boycott of Eurovision 2019 in Israel
summary: The Dublin Lord Mayor and Irish Eurovision winner Charlie McGettigan call for a boycott of the 2019 Eurovision Song Contest, set to be hosted by Israel.

headline: US Senator Patrick Leahy calls for State Department to investigate Israeli shootings
summary: After Israel’s massacre of 60 Palestinians in Gaza on May 14, 2018, Vermont Senator Patrick Leahy demands that the State Department “promptly determine if individuals or units involved in the [Israeli] shootings should be prohibited from receiving US training or equipment, consistent with the Leahy Law.”

headline: Podemos, the Spanish progressive party, demands a military embargo on Israel
summary: In the Spanish State, the progressive party Podemos demands a military embargo on Israel, saying "no democracy should support the use of live ammunition to stop protests."

headline: South Africa withdraws its ambassador to Israel
summary: The South African government condemns Israeli attacks agasint Palestinian protesters in Gaza, and recalls its ambassador with immediate effect.

headline: Turkey recalls ambassadors to Israel and United States
summary: Turkey recalls its ambassadors to Israel and the United States following the killing of dozens of Palestinian protesters by Israeli forces amid the opening of the US embassy in Jerusalem.

headline: University of Chile students vote in favour of academic boycott
summary: At the University of Chile, 90% of the Philosophy and Humanities Faculty students vote to support the academic boycott of Israeli institutions and universities. Students also vote that the university should sever ties with the University of Tel Aviv and the Hebrew University of Jerusalem.

headline: British Labour MP Chris Williamson suggests support for BDS
summary: British Labour MP Chris Williamson suggests that it is time to support the BDS Movement "following the massacre of unarmed Palestinians by Netanyahu’s apartheid regime." He also calls for a review of Britian's arms export licence criteria, stating that they "are clearly not satisfactory if they allow us to continue selling arms to Israel."

headline: Iceland petition to boycott Eurovision 2019 gains widespread support
summary: A petition circulated in Iceland calling for the boycott of Eurovision 2019 gains 5000 signatures.

headline: Belgium, Ireland and Luxembourg summon ambassadors after massacre in Gaza
summary: Following Israel's policy of shooting at unarmed Palestinian protesters during the Great March of Return, Belgium, Ireland and Luxembourg summon Israeli ambassadors and move to set up an international inquiry.

headline: The Scottish Green Party releases educational video "Why Boycott Israel"
summary: The Scottish Greens party releases a video titled "Why Boycott Israel", featuring Ross Greer, a Member of the Scottish Parliament. The video calls for support for BDS. The Scottish Green Party first endorsed BDS in 2015.

headline: Portuguese National Theatre director cancels participation in an Israeli festival
summary: Tiago Rodrigues, the director of Portugal’s National Theater, cancels his participation in an Israeli festival and joins the cultural boycott of Israel, becoming the first director of a national theater in Europe to do so.

headline: The European Coordination of Committees for Palestine (ECCP) calls for a military embargo on Israel.
summary: European Coordination of Committees for Palestine (ECCP), a network of 42 European committees, organizations, NGOs, unions and international solidarity movements from 19 European countries, demands an international investigation into Israel’s killings of unarmed Palestinian protesters, as well as an arms embargo and sactions.

headline: The Swiss Forum for Human Rights in Israel/Palestine calls for military embargo
summary: The Swiss Forum for Human Rights in Israel/Palestine, a coordinating body for influential Christian and human rights groups, sends a letter to the Swiss government calling for a military embargo.

headline: British engineering company Versarien attributes losses to ties with Israeli Aerospace Industries
summary: The CEO of British engineering firm Versarien states that the company lost $4 million when share prices fell due to BDS campaigning. Versarien is an engineering company that partners with Israel arms company Aerospace Industries.

headline: Gilberto Gil cancels Israel perfomance
summary: Brazilian musician Gilberto Gil cancels a performance in Tel Aviv as the number of unarmed Palestinian protesters killed by Israeli forces in Gaza reaches 100.

headline: Wave of British musicians endorse BDS on social media
summary: Numerous artists, including Wolf Alice, Portishead, and Shame, post a message of support for BDS on social media as Israeli snipers fire on protesters in Gaza. The messages read: "As long as the Israeli government commits war crimes against the Palestinian people, we support their call for a boycott of Israel as a means of peaceful protest against the brutal occupation.”

headline: Four major Italian cities call for an arms embargo on Israel
summary: Four major Italian cities, Naples, Turin, Florence and Bologna, call for an arms embargo on Israel, in support of Palestinian rights.  Additionally, the City Council of San Giuliano Terme in the Pisa area calls for an end to arms sales to Israel and endorses the BDS movement.

headline: Artists withdraw from Pop-Kultur music festival in Berlin for second year in a row
summary: For the second year in a row, the Pop-Kultur music festival in Berlin accepts funding from the Israeli embassy. Six artists withdraw as a result, including UK band Shopping, singer-songwriter Richard Dawson, Welsh musician Gwenno, and American artist John Maus.

headline: California State University – East Bay students pass divestment resolution
summary: The Student Government of California State University – East Bay endorses a resolution calling for divestment from corporations that profit off of the Israeli occupation. The resolution specifically names Caterpillar, Hewlett Packard, G4S, and Motorola Solutions as companies directly involved in allowing the Israeli government to maintain and enforce the occupation and construct illegal Israeli settlements, walls, barriers, and checkpoints.

headline: 40 Cambridge University student groups demand boycott of BAE and Caterpillar
summary: A wide coalition of Cambridge University student groups call on the university to end its partnership with major arms producer BAE Systems and Caterpillar Inc. due to the companies' role in enabling violations of international law by Israel, Turkey, and Saudi Arabia.

headline: Over 30 Italian cities and towns protest the Giro d’Italia cycling race starting in Jerusalem
summary: Over 30 Italian cities and towns protest along nearly every stage of the Giro d’Italia cycling race starting in Jerusalem. The president of the Italian Football Coaches association announces his support for a boycott of the race.

headline: Shakira cancels Tel Aviv show
summary: Grammy-winning Colombian star Shakira cancels a planned performance in Tel Aviv. Shakira is a goodwill ambassador for UNICEF, the UN children’s agency that has documented many of Israel’s abuses. Shakira previously visited Israel in 2011, when she held a press conference with then-president Shimon Peres.

headline: Major cities in Spain take action for Palestinian rights
summary: A wave of major cities across Spain take measures to support Palestinian rights, including Madrid, the capital and largest city in Spain, which passes a motion condemning Israel’s “disproportionate and indiscriminate use of force." Barcelona calls upon countries to stop arming Israel until it ends its violations of Palestinian human rights. Pamplona passes a resolution that supports the right of return of Palestinian refugees.Terrassa and Badalona call on the Spanish government to stop arming Israel.

headline: Norweigian government affirms right to boycott
summary: The state secretary at the Norweigian foreign ministry says that boycotts of “goods and services produced in settlements does not contradict Norway’s international commitments.” The statement comes in response to pressure by right wing groups to force boycotts by the Trondheim and Tromsø municipalities to be rescinded.

headline: The Argentina National Football team suspends match with Israel
summary: The Argentina National Football team suspends a match with Israel set to take place in Jerusalem, following months of BDS campaigning that kicked off in Argentina.

headline: Filmmakers boycott TLVFest
summary: Eleven filmmakers cancel their participation in TLVFest, an LGBTQ film festival in Tel Aviv. Palestinian LGBTQ organizers have called on LGBTQ communities around the world to demonstrate solidarity through BDS.

headline: Human Rights Watch calls for sanctions against Israel
summary: Human Rights Watch says Israel's actions against unarmed Palestinians in Gaza "may amount to war crimes" and says officials responsible should be held accountable. The group calls for “sanctions against officials implicated in ongoing serious human rights violations.”

headline: Monaghan City Council becomes fifth Irish city council to endorse BDS
summary: In response to Israeli forces killing unarmed Palestinian protesters in Gaza, Monaghan City Council becomes the fifth county or city council in Ireland to declare support for BDS. Dublin, Donegal, Galway, and Derry have previously declared support.

headline: Prominent artists accuse German festival of censoring support for Palestinian human rights
summary: Numerous prominent cultural figures accuse the Ruhrtriennale arts festival in Germany of censorship after they disinvite the Young Fathers, a band that has been open about its support Palestinian human rights. In an open letter, artists such as Massive Attack, Angela Davis, Patti Smith, Danny Glover, Viggo Mortensen, Peter Gabriel and Tunde Adebimpe call BDS "lawful exercise of freedom of expression" and "a legitimate nonviolent tactic." In response, Ruhrtriennale re-invites the Young Fathers.

headline: South African Students Congress (SASCO) adopts BDS
summary: The South African Students Congress (SASCO), the largest student movement in Africa, affirms its support for BDS at its National General Council.

headline: Europcar shuts down car rental branches in illegal Israeli settlements
summary: French car rental giant Europcar shuts down rental facilities run by its Israeli franchisee, Albar, in illegal Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank.

headline: French engineering company Systra promises to pull out of Jerusalem light rail project
summary: Human rights defenders say they have received a commitment from French firm Systra to pull out of a project to expand Israel’s Jerusalem light rail. The Jerusalem light rail services illegal Israeli settlements in the West Bank, connecting them to Jerusalem.

headline: 140 global political parties in Socialist International association endorse BDS
summary: Socialist International, an association of 140 global political parties, including 35 parties in government, adopts BDS and calls for a "total embargo on all forms of military trade and cooperation with Israel as long as it continues its policies of occupation and Apartheid against the people of Palestine."

headline: India’s largest student federation passes BDS resolution
summary: India’s largest student federation, the 4 million-member Students’ Federation of India, votes to adopt BDS and boycott Hewlett Packard.

headline: Christian Peacemaker Teams International endorses boycott of Hewlett Packard (HP) companies
summary: Christian Peacemaker Teams International endorses boycott of Hewlett Packard (HP) companies due to their involvement in Israeli human rights abuses. HP provides services and equipment at Israeli checkpoints and and barriers.

headline: 40 Jewish groups issue statement saying BDS movement stands against all forms of racism and bigotry
summary: 40 Jewish social justice organizations across the globe sign a statement expressing the view that the BDS movement "has demonstrated an ongoing proven commitment to fighting antisemitism and all forms of racism and bigotry, consistent with its dedication to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights." Signatories, which came from the United States, South Africa, Canada, New Zealand, Germany, Brazil, the UK, France, Australia, Israel, the Netherlands, Belgium, Switzerland, Spain, Argentina and beyond, condemned attempts to stifle criticism of Israeli policies and systems of injustice.

headline: The Episcopal Church adopts new investment screen
summary: The Episcopal Church, with 3 million members in the United States, votes to adopt an investment screen to ensure it does not invest in companies that profit from human rights abuses against Palestinians.

headline: British author Kamila Shamsie chooses not to publish in Israel
summary: Kamila Shamsie chooses not to work with an Israeli publisher interested in acquiring two books. She says "I do not want to cross the picket line formed by Palestinian civil society."

headline: US Rep. Betty McCollum speaks out on detention of Palestinian children
summary: US Congresswoman Betty McCollum (D-MN) delivers remarks on the House floor encouraging colleagues to co-sponser H.R. 4391, Promoting Human Rights by Ending Israeli Detention of Palestinian Children Act.

headline: Glasgow City Council vows to refrain from sponsoring future arms fairs
summary: Glasgow City Council promises that it will no longer sponsor arms fairs featuring Israeli weapons manufacturers and will ensure that the city's guidelines for hosting events reflect that “Glasgow is a human rights respecting city.”

headline: Construction giant Limak Holding declines to participate in construction of US Embassy in Jerusalem
summary: High-profile Turkish construction firm, Limak Holding, refuses to help build the US embassy in Jerusalem even though a partnership it is involved in won the contract for the project.

headline: Jordanian firm refuses to sell to Israel pipeline project
summary: A Jordanian construction company has refused to sell its sand after discovering the material was to be used in building a gas pipeline linking the country with Israel.

headline: Scottish Falkirk Pension Fund divests $7.8 million from Israeli bank
summary: The Scottish Falkirk Pension Fund divests $7.8 million in holdings from Bank Hapoalim, an Israeli bank that funds illegal settlement construction in the occupied Palestinian territories. The Falkirk Pension Fund is the first local authority pension fund in the UK to divest from a company complicit in Israel's violations of Palestinian rights.

headline: Adidas no longer sponsoring Israel Football Association
summary: Adidas is no longer sponsoring the Israel Football Association (IFA). Over 130 Palestinian football clubs urged the company to end its sponsorship due to FIFA's inclusion of six teams based in illegal Israeli settlements. BDS organizers also delivered a petition with 16,000 signatures to Adidas’ headquarters in Amsterdam.

headline: Half of invited speakers withdraw from physics conference at Ariel University
summary: Six out of eleven speakers set to appear at an Israeli physics workshop confirm their withdrawal. The workshop was scheduled to take place at Ariel University, which is situated in the illegal settlement of Ariel in the West Bank, on land Israel confiscated from surrounding Palestinian villages. The withdrawals come after Palestinian and international academics issue a letter to make participants aware of the context of the event, and Israel's denial of academic freedom to Palestinian scholars and students.

headline: French Parliamentarian calls for solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza
summary: Elsa Faucillon, a French parliamentarian, calls for solidarity with the Palestinian people in Gaza and demands that the French government put an end to Israel's impunity.

headline: US rappers cancel performance in Israel, festival canceled
summary: American rappers Tyga and Fat Joe cancel their scheduled appearance for the Shaka hip-hop festival at the Rishon Letzion Amphitheater in Israel. A Shaka producer claims the cancelation was due to "security reasons." As a result of the cancellation, the entire festival is called off.

headline: European Association of Social Anthropology passes motion on Israeli academic institutions in the Occupied Palestinian Territories
summary: Members of the European Association of Social Anthropology vote not to cooperate with Israeli academic institutions located in illegal Israeli settlements in the Occupied Palestinian Territories. The vote passed with 830 members supporting the motion, 21 opposed, and 37 abstentions. Both the Israeli Anthropological Association (IAA) and the Israeli Sociological Association (ISA) have previously stated they will not cooperate with academic institutions based in the settlements, describing them as "exclusionary", "beyond the pale of academic and anthropological ethics" and part of an Israeli policy of "creeping annexation."

headline: Tunisian activists stop shipment from Israeli Zim shipment company
summary: Tunisian dockworkers in Radès threaten to strike to prevent a ship rented by Israel's Zim shipment company from docking. As a result, Zim indefinitely suspends its services to the Tunisian port.

headline: Lana Del Rey among 20 musicians to cancel gig at Meteor Festival in Israel
summary: American pop artist Lana Del Rey cancels plans to headline the Meteor Festival in Israel. She is one of 20 musical acts to cancel from a range of countries, including the United States, Turkey, Sweden, the UK, and South Africa. Several artists released statements directly referring to Israel's human rights record or the BDS movement as a reason for their decision not to play in Israel.

headline: French online payment company refuses to close accounts associated with BDS
summary: HelloAsso, a French company that provides online payment services, rejects pressure by Israel lobby groups to shut down the accounts of two French groups which support the BDS movement for Palestinian human rights. HelloAsso explains that it does not take a position as a company on BDS, but "considers this movement as within the realm of free expression and not as discriminatory." The company points to a 2016 statement from the European Union that establishes that BDS fall under the right to freedom of expression and freedom of association in EU territory.

headline: 140 artists publish open letter supporting the appeal from Palestinian artists to boycott Eurovision 2019 in Israel
summary: In an open letter published by the Guardian, 140 artists from 19 countries express their support for the call by Palestinian artists to boycott the Eurovision Song Contest 2019, set to be hosted by Israel. The letter says "until Palestinians can enjoy freedom, justice and equal rights, there should be no business-as-usual with the state that is denying them their basic rights."

headline: 200 Palestinian sports clubs call on Puma to end sponsorship of the Israel Football Association (IFA)
summary: More than 200 Palestinian sports clubs call on Puma to end its sponsorship of the Israel Football Association (IFA), which governs and advocates on behalf of clubs based in illegal Israeli settlements on stolen Palestinian land.

headline: Wave of top DJs and electronic musicians around the world endorse BDS
summary: A wave of DJs and electronic musicians, such as Caribou, the Black Madonna, Four Tet, Laurel Halo, and Ben UFO, share a post on social media declaring support for BDS. Hashtagged #DJsforPalestine, the posts say "as long as the Israeli government continues its brutal and sustained oppression of the Palestinian people we respect their call for a boycott of Israel as a means of peaceful protest against the occupation."

headline: Professor opts not to write letters of recommendation for Israeli study abroad programs
summary: University of Michigan Associate Professor John Cheney-Lippold notifies a student of his position not to write letters of recommendation for students to participate in study abroad programs at Israeli universities. The BDS movement's guidelines around academic boycott extend to include study abroad programs affiliated with Israeli institutions.

headline: German city court confirms that BDS advocacy is protected under freedom of expression and assembly
summary: After the City of Oldenburg shut down a BDS event, the Administrative Court-Oldenburg rules that the city’s cancellation of the event was unlawful. The court's reasoning is that calling for BDS falls under the fundamental rights to freedom of expression and assembly which are protected by the German constitution.

headline: UK Labour Party votes for immediate freeze of arms sales to Israel
summary: The UK Labour Party passes a resolution calling for an immediate freeze of arms sales to Israel. The resolution also condemns Israel’s killing of unarmed Palestinian protesters during the Great March of Return. From 2014 to 2018, the UK government approved licences for exports to Israel of arms and other military technology worth $660 million.

headline: Irish Minister of State and 50 Irish lawmakers call for Ireland to stop arming Israel
summary: An open letter signed by an Irish Minister of State and 50 Irish lawmakers calls for a military embargo on Israel, noting "the shooting dead of some 205 protestors, including 40 children, and wounding of more than 5,000 people by live fire in Gaza since April."

headline: City Council of Ghent, Belgium votes to ban contracts with companies that violate human rights
summary: In response to engagement with Palestinian solidarity activists, the City Council of Ghent, Belgium votes to ban contracts with companies that violate human rights.

headline: University of Leeds becomes first UK university to divest from firms involved in the Israeli arms trade
summary: University of Leeds becomes the first university in the UK to divest from companies that trade military equipment with Israel, selling $1.2 million in holdings of Airbus, United Technologies, and Keyence Corporation.

headline: For third year in a row, top chefs withdraw from Israeli event
summary: For the third year in a row, several top international chefs drop Israel’s Round Tables Festival from their schedule. The government-sponsored event brings top international chefs to take over Israeli kitchens for a week. This year, Chefs Gabrielle Hamilton (United States), Ana Roš (Slovenia), and Isa Mazzocchi (Italy) withdraw from the lineup. They do not issue any statement elaborating on their decision, but Palestinian activists had written to participants asking them to respect the call for cultural boycott and highlighting the event's links to the government and companies involved in illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: Pitzer College faculty pass resolution calling for suspension of the College’s exchange with Haifa University
summary: Faculty at Pitzer College in California pass two BDS motions. One calls for a suspension of the College's study abroad exchange with Haifa University. The other protests actions of the College administration to rescind a BDS motion passed democratically by its Student Senate.

headline: Airbnb changes policy on listings in illegal Israeli settlements
summary: Following years of campaigning by a coalition of rights groups, Airbnb announces it will remove approximately 200 property listings located in illegal Israeli settlements in the West Bank. In April 2019, Airbnb reverses its decision, re-listing the properties to settle legal action brought against the company. Airbnb states that it will donate profits from future settlement bookings to humanitarian causes, but Omar Shakir, the Israel and Palestine director of Human Rights Watch, says "Airbnb cannot wash its hands by donating profits from unlawful settlement listings. So long as they continue to broker rentals on land stolen from Palestinians who themselves are barred from staying there, they remain complicit in the abuses settlements trigger.”

headline: Quakers in Britain become first UK Church to bar investment in companies that profit off of the Israeli occupation
summary: Quakers in Britain becomes the first church in the UK to announce it will not invest any of its centrally-held funds in companies profiting from the Israeli occupation of Palestine, saying "“We believe strongly in the power of legitimate, nonviolent, democratic tools such as morally responsible investment to realise positive change in the world. We want to make sure our money and energies are instead put into places which support our commitments to peace, equality and justice."

headline: Government of Chile passes ban on Israeli settlement goods
summary: The Chilean congress passes a resolution calling for a boycott Israeli settlements and the re-examination of the countries agreements with Israel. The Chilean resolution comes as a similar bill is being considered in Ireland.

headline: Vermont State Police cancel training in Israel
summary: Vermont State Police Director Colonel Birmingham announces that the department has cancelled its planned participation in a training seminar in Israel. Similar programs across the country bring local law enforcement to Israel for training with the Israeli military, police and secret service. These trainings, organized and funded by the Anti-Defamation League, promote and extend discriminatory and repressive policing tactics such as extrajudicial executions, shoot-to-kill policies, racial profiling, spying and surveillance, deportation and detention, and attacks on human rights defenders.

headline: Nobel laureate George P. Smith speaks about the importance of BDS
summary: In a speech in Sweden, American professor George P. Smith, who was awarded the 2018 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, endorses the BDS movement, saying "people of conscience all over the world have an obligation to pay attention to abuses of human rights, like [Israel’s] 71-year regime of dispossession and subjugation."

headline: Ilhan Omar and Rashida Tlaib become first sitting U.S. members of Congress to publicly endorse BDS
summary: US Representatives Ilhan Omar, of Minnesota, and Rashida Tlaib, of Michigan, make history by publicly endorsing the BDS movement. Tlaib also says she will organize a congressional trip to the West Bank for lawmakers to be exposed to the experiences of everyday Palestinians. Since 2009, the American Israel Education Foundation, the education arm of powerful Israel lobby group AIPAC, has spent $12.9 million on trips to Israel for 363 US lawmakers and 657 congressional staff members. These trips explicitly aim to strengthen US support for Israeli policy.

headline: Public protests impact "France-Israel Season" events
summary: An Israeli official complains that the so-called Saison France-Israël, or France-Israel Season, a series of hundreds of cultural events backed by both governments, has failed to improve Israel's public image in France. The events in France were heavily protested by activists around the country, with at least one event being cancelled and others drawing small audiences.

headline: The Irish Senate passes a bill prohibiting the import of goods and services produced in illegal settlements
summary: The Irish Senate passes a bill prohibiting the import of goods and services produced in illegal Israeli settlements. Senator Frances Black, who introduced the bill, says that the demand to end trade in settlement goods “is not a radical demand: it seeks consistency in [Irish] foreign policy and disassociation from clear breaches of humanitarian law.”

headline: HSBC divests from Elbit Systems
summary: HSBC, the largest bank in Europe, confirms it has fully divested from Elbit Systems over the company's involvement with cluster munitions. Elbit Systems is Israel's largest weapons company and markets its products globally as "field tested" based on their use against Palestinian civilians. HSBC's announcement follows a year-long campaign in which activists picketed monthly at 40 HSBC branches and sent more than 24,000 emails calling on the bank to divest.

headline: Canada Revenue Agency audits charitable status of Jewish National Fund of Canada
summary: The Canada Revenue Agency is undertaking an audit of the Jewish National Fund of Canada. The audit stems from a complaint over the organization's activities, which have included funding infrastructure projects on Israeli army, air and naval bases. Canadian law bans tax-exempt charities from issuing tax receipts for donations to foreign militaries. The JNF of Canada has long been criticized by Palestinian human rights groups for "greenwashing" through projects such as Canada Park, a park built on top of three depopulated Palestinian villages that extends into the West Bank.

headline: Birmingham Civil Rights Institute reinstates award to Angela Davis
summary: The Birmingham Civil Rights Institute’s (BCRI) board of directors announces it has restored its offer to award Angela Davis the Fred L. Shuttlesworth Human Rights Award. The organization rescinded its initial offer of the award to Davis after it received backlash over her support for Palestinian human rights. The board issued a public apology to Davis.

headline: Canada Revenue Agency revokes charitable status of Beth Olath over support for Israeli military
summary: The Canada Revenue Agency revokes the charitable status of Beth Olath Charitable Organization over its involvement in activities deemed non-charitable under Canadian law, such as increasing “the efficiency and effectiveness of the Israeli armed forces” and funding Israeli projects in the occupied Palestinian territory, which the CRA notes runs contrary to Canada’s policy on the Israel-Palestine conflict. The organization had been a registered charity since 1980. In 2017, it reported more than CAD $60 million in revenues. The Jewish National Fund of Canada (JNF Canada) is also under audit for supporting the Israeli army and settlements.

headline: Judge dismisses lawsuit against American Studies Association over Israel boycott
summary: A district court in Washington D.C. dismisses a lawsuit against the American Studies Association (ASA) over its adoption of an academic boycott of Israel. ASA members passed the boycott resolution in 2013 by a 2 to 1 margin after months of open debate. They were sued in 2016 by the Louis D. Brandeis Center, a pro-Israel group that engages in "lawfare" to silence and intimidate Palestinian rights groups. The court held that “nowhere” could the plaintiffs explain how they were injured by the boycott.

headline: Scottish pension fund divests from Bank Hapoalim
summary: Tayside Pension Fund, a Scottish pension fund responsible for investing Dundee local authority pension funds, no longer invests in Bank Hapoalim, an Israeli bank involved in financing Israeli settlements in the West Bank, which are illegal under international law.

headline: Jeremy Corbyn renews call to end UK arms sales to Israel
summary: UK Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn says in a tweet that the UK must cease arms sales to Israel. The tweet links to an article about a new UN report that says Israel's killings of Palestinian protesters in Gaza "may amount to war crimes."

headline: Student government at Swarthmore College passes divestment resolution
summary: The student government at Swarthmore College vote in favor of a resolution calling on the university to divest from companies complicit in human rights violations against Palestinians, including Boeing, Caterpillar, Elbit Systems, Hewlett Packard, Bank Hapoalim, Hyundai and Lockheed Martin. Student organizers supporting the resolution faced a campaign of online harassment by pro-Israel groups, prompting prominent scholars and professors including Angela Davis and Robin D.G. Kelley, human rights lawyers Maria LaHood and Noura Erakat, and Jewish Voice for Peace’s executive director Rebecca Vilkmoerson to write an open letter expressing support for Swarthmore students.

headline: Panamericana book store cancels G4S contract
summary: The Colombian bookstore chain Panamericana cancels its contract with G4S following an online petition signed by 900 people, as well as demonstrations at a number of its stores. Panamericana is the largest bookstore chain in Colombia, with 35 stores and 1,700 direct employees. G4S is the largest security firm in the world. Although G4S confirmed the sale of its Israeli affiliate in December 2016, it continues to hold partial ownership of Policity Ltd., a company contracted by the Israeli police to build and operate Israel’s National Police Academy. The training provided by the National Police Academy includes repression tactics used against Palestinian communities, such as crowd control, house raids, interrogation techniques, target shooting, and undercover operations.

headline: South Africa maintains downgraded status of South African embassy in Israel
summary: President Ramaphosa confirms that South Africa will continue to abide by its 2017 policy to downgrade the status of its embassy in Israel to a liaison office. He explains that the decision is "informed by our concern at the ongoing violation of the right of the Palestinian people to self determination."

headline: Pitzer College faculty, students and staff vote to suspend study abroad program with Haifa University
summary: Pitzer College faculty, students and staff voted 67-28 in favor of suspending a study abroad program with Haifa University over Israel’s discriminatory policies against Palestinian students and those supporting Palestinian human rights.. Pitzer College President Melvin Oliver vetoed the motion.

headline: Stop Cemex online action reaches 1 million people
summary: Cemex, a Mexican construction company involved in building Israel's wall and settlements, saw its annual "Cemex Day" celebration disrupted by online protests raising awareness of the company's role in human rights violations against Palestinians. More than one million people saw the message "StopCemex from building Israeli apartheid."

headline: Brown University students pass divestment referendum
summary: Undergraduate student at Brown University vote 69% in favor of a referendum to divest from Israel. The referendum, which prompted a high turnout of 3,076 voters, proposes to “identify and divest from companies that profit from Israeli violations of human rights.”

headline: Barney Greenway, lead vocalist of metal British metal band Napalm Death, endorses cultural boycott
summary: In conversation with Palestinian metal fans, Barney Greenway, lead vocalist of metal British metal band Napalm Death, says he would not return to play in Israel today, stating that "cultural boycotts are very valid." Napalm Death had previously played in Israel in 2011.

headline: University of Cape Town passes resolution for Palestinian rights
summary: The Council of the University of Cape Town passes a resolution to reserve the right to disassociate itself from academic institutions that support or enable, directly or indirectly, the violation of human rights. The resolution also condemns "the atrocities and human rights violations perpetrated in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, and elsewhere in the world."

headline: German court rules in favor of BDS event in City of Oldenburg
summary: The Higher Administrative Court of Lower Saxony overturns the verdict of the lower court and rules that the City of Oldenburg must provide its halls for the 2019 Israeli Apartheid Week events of BDS Oldenburg. The City, which was convicted in 2018 for violating the right to freedom of expression and assembly by canceling a contract with BDS Oldenburg, refused to grant space for the event. The City was ordered to cover the plaintiff’s legal costs for the proceeding.

headline: 200 Global South individuals and organizations release statement of solidarity with Palestinians
summary: 200 Latin American, African, and Asian organizations sign a statement of solidarity with Palestinian human rights and endorse BDS. They call for a complete military embargo on Israel, saying "this call is of urgent importance to us in the Global South as military trade with Israel is furthering the militarization of our societies while directly financing Israel’s military industry."

headline: Former U.S. President Jimmy Carter speaks out on right to boycott
summary: In a press release published by the Carter Center, former U.S. President Jimmy Carter urges the House of Representatives to reject the BDS Act of 2019, an anti-boycott provision, stating "U.S. courts have protected the right of individuals to participate in boycotts as a form of political protest. The same protection applies to the right to advocate or oppose BDS."

headline: 90 human rights groups meet in Mexico to examine impact of Israeli arms industry
summary: 90 human rights organizations and Mexican movements gather for the Second People's Tribunal on Israel's role in the militarization of Latin America. They call on the Mexican government to freeze existing contracts and refrain from entering new contracts with Israel, its institutions, and military and security sector companies, based on "the danger that the Israeli military and security industry represents for democracy and human rights in Mexico, in addition to violating international law and various United Nations conventions of which Mexico is a signatory."

headline: AXA partially divests from Elbit Systems
summary: AXA Investment Managers, Europe's fifth-largest asset manager, sells all its shares from Elbit Systems, Israel's largest weapons manufacturer, following a year of civil society campaigning, including a petition that garnered 140,000 signatures. AXA remains linked to Elbit Systems through its subsidiary Alliance Bernstein (AB) and is also invested in five Israeli banks.

headline: Largest trade union in the Netherlands joins boycott HP campaign
summary: Federatie Nederlandse Vakbeweging (FNV), the largest trade union in the Netherlands with 1.1 million members, drops a partnership with HP. Previously,  the union was regularly offering a 15% discount on HP products to members. The Union stated, "as long as we do not know for certain that HP is not complicit in human rights abuses, we will no longer include them...in FNV Membership Offers”. HP provides equipment and technology to Israel’s military and police, and is involved in maintaining the population registry that Israel uses to enforce its system of racial segregation.

headline: Texas court strikes down anti-BDS law
summary: Judge Pitman of the Western District of Texas rules that a Texas anti-BDS law, H.B. 89, is unconstitutional. The Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) brought the First Amendment lawsuit on behalf of Bahia Amawi, a Texas speech language pathologist who lost her job because she refused to sign a “No Boycott of Israel” clause. The Attorney General of Texas is no longer permitted to include or enforce “No Boycott of Israel” clauses in any state contract.

headline: NYU department ends relationship with Tel Aviv campus
summary: New York University Department of Social and Cultural Analysis faculty vote in favor of a resolution of non-cooperation with the university's Tel Aviv campus. The resolution cites the obligation to uphold the university’s Policy of Ethical Conduct on non-discrimination and equal opportunity, noting that Israeli authorities restrict entry on the basis of ancestry and political speech.

headline: Israeli Apartheid Week 2019 includes 200 events across 30 countries
summary: Israeli Apartheid Week (IAW) 2019 featured more than 200 events, across 30 countries, on five continents, under the theme “Stop Arming Colonialism.” Israeli Apartheid Week (IAW) is an international series of events that seeks to raise awareness about Israel’s apartheid regime and build support for the BDS movement.

headline: Multinational companies drop out of bid on Jerusalem light rail extension
summary: Alstom, a French multinational company, is the latest company to drop plans to bid on an extension of the Jerusalem light rail. Canada’s Bombardier, Australia’s Macquarie, and Germany’s Siemens also dropped out. A Greek-led consortium opted not to bid. The Jerusalem light rail connects Israeli settlements in the West Bank to each other and to Jerusalem. Israel’s construction of settlements in the occupied West Bank, including East Jerusalem, is a war crime.

headline: Low tourist attendance at Eurovision 2019 as boycott call puts focus on Palestinian rights
summary: More than 150,000 Europeans and others signed petitions urging the boycott of Eurovision 2019 in Tel Aviv. Hundreds of leading artists lent their support, including former Eurovision contestants and one winner. Over 100 LGBT+ organizations and centers called for boycott. These mobilizations received significant media coverage in mainstream press outlets. Ultimately, only 5,000-7,000 tourists arrived in Tel Aviv for Eurovision 2019, far fewer than expected by Israeli officials.

headline: Mexico City Metro removes misleading Israeli embassy-sponsored photographs from metro stations
summary: Mexico City Metro removes 12 photographs the Israeli embassy placed in two metro stations, after being notified that the photographs falsely presented images of the Golan Heights, East Jerusalem and the West Bank as part of Israel. Civil society protests have led to the cancellation of several other events sponsored by the Israeli embassy in Mexico during a month-long series.

headline: Glasgow City Council releases statement on new ethical events policy
summary: One year after declaring it would no longer host arms fairs featuring Israeli weapons manufacturers, the city council publishes an update stating that defense has been removed from the sectors it aims to attract under its new events hosting policy.

headline: Public Services unions across Europe call on their governments to suspend arms trade with Israel
summary:
Delegates at the European Public Service Union (EPSU) vote in favor of a resolution that "calls on European governments to suspend arms
trade with Israel until the Israeli Government complies with international human rights law." The resolution also protests the US decision to move its embassy to Jerusalem and calls for an independent Palestinian state providing quality public services to its citizens.

headline: Apartheid Free Zone campaign launches in Italy
summary: The Apartheid Free Zone campaign launches in Italy, with 100 commercial, cultural and sporting activities in Italy joining the campaign. The Apartheid Free Zone campaign creates networks of spaces that stand against all forms of discrimination and commit to having no relations with institutions and companies complicit in Israel’s systematic violations of international law. Similar Apartheid Free Zone campaigns exist in Belgium, Norway and the Spanish State.

headline: Belfast City Council nixes investment trip to Israel
summary: Belfast city councillors vote not to send the council's Director of Economic Development John Greer on an investment trip to Israel. The aim of the visit was to “facilitate access to investment and new market opportunities for five Belfast based businesses.”

headline: 14 rugby teams support call from Palestinian athletes to boycott Puma
summary: Italian men’s and women’s amateur rugby teams show their support for the Boycott PUMA campaign. Puma sponsors the Israel Football Association (IFA), which includes teams in illegal Israeli settlements on stolen Palestinian land. More than 200 Palestinian sports clubs have called for a worldwide #BoycottPuma campaign.

headline: 240 Jewish and Israeli scholars sign open letter criticizing German suppression of right to boycott
summary: 240 Jewish and Israeli scholars, many of whom specialize in anti-Semitism, Jewish history and history of the Holocaust, sign an open letter condemning anti-boycott motions being considered by the German government. The letter expresses concern about "the growing tendency to label supporters of Palestinian human rights as anti-Semitic." While signatories to the letter hold different view on BDS, they all "reject the deceitful allegation that BDS as such is anti-Semitic and maintain that boycotts are a legitimate and non-violent tool of resistance."

headline: Former Barcelona football player Oleguer Presas supports boycott of Puma
summary: Former Barcelona football player Oleguer Presas calls on PUMA to end its support for Israel's military occupation and apartheid. Puma sponsors the Israel Football Association (IFA), which includes teams in illegal Israeli settlements on stolen Palestinian land. More than 200 Palestinian sports clubs have called for a worldwide #BoycottPuma campaign.

headline: British Society for Middle Eastern Studies endorses academic boycott
summary: The British Society for Middle Eastern Studies (BRISMES) passes a resolution calling for a boycott of complicit Israeli academic institutions, noting that Israeli universities "play a key role” in Israeli military occupation and that "Israel has obstructed Palestinians’ right to education.”

headline: 34 European trade unions call for ban on settlement trade
summary: 34 European trade union organizations, representing millions of workers across Europe, write to the European Commission and European governments demanding a ban on trade with Israeli settlements, which are illegal under international law. The EU allows Israel to export large quantities of products produced or partly produced in illegal Israeli settlements to Europe. These products are widely sold by European retailers, providing direct economic support to the ongoing expansion of the settlements.

headline: Unite, UK's second largest trade union, boycotts HP
summary: At its executive council meeting, Unite the Union, the second largest trade union in the UK with 1.2 million members, passes a resolution to join the Boycott HP campaign. The resolution states that Unite will cease purchasing HP products. HP provides equipment and technology to Israel’s military and police, and is involved in maintaining the population registry that Israel uses to enforce its system of racial segregation.

headline: 11 Indian companies join HP boycott
summary: A group of 11 Indian companies declare themselves HP-free zones. HP provides equipment and technology to Israel’s military and police, and is involved in maintaining the population registry that Israel uses to enforce its system of racial segregation.

headline: Lawsuit against revised Texas anti-boycott law advances
summary: Judge Pitman of the Western District of Texas rules that H.B. 793, an amended version of H.B. 89, a Texas anti-BDS law "does not ameliorate the constitutional defects the Court identified."  After H.B. 89 was struck down as unconstitutional in April 2019, the Texas state legislature tried to amend the law in a way that would prevent judicial scrutiny, but judge Pitman stated, "no amount of narrowing its application will cure its constitutional infirmity."

headline: Vancouver City Council rejects new definition defining criticism of Israel as anti-semitic
summary: The Vancouver City Council chooses not to adopt a new definition of anti-semitism that aims to silence support for Palestinian rights. The definition broadly equates criticism of the State of Israel with anti-semitism. The city's decision came as a result of the council's engagement with Jewish community leaders who oppose the new definition, as well as the B.C. Civil Liberties Association.

headline: Federal Court of Canada rules against "product of Israel" labels on Israeli settlement goods
summary: The Federal Court of Canada rules that “Product of Israel” labels on wines produced in Israel’s West Bank settlements are “false, misleading and deceptive” and that “as such, they contravene the requirements of subsection 7(1) of the Consumer Packaging and Labelling Act and subsection 5(1) of the Food and Drugs Act.”

headline: US Representatives Ilhan Omar, Rashida Tlaib, and John Lewis introduce house resolution affirming right to boycott
summary: US Representatives Ilhan Omar, Rashida Tlaib, and John Lewis introduce a historic house resolution affirming the right to boycott. H.Res.496 affirms that "all Americans have the right to participate in boycotts in pursuit of civil and human rights at home and abroad, as protected by the First Amendment to the Constitution."

headline: Judge orders Fordham University to recognize Students for Justice in Palestine club
summary: Five Fordham University students win a landmark legal victory against Fordham University, which sought to prohibit them from forming a Students for Justice in Palestine (SJP) club at their university. Awad, et al. v. Fordham University is the first lawsuit in the country challenging institutional censorship of students advocating for justice in Palestine, and marks the first major legal victory for free speech for advocates of Palestine on US college campuses.

headline: David Clennon, Emmy-Winning actor, endorses cultural boycott
summary: David Clennon, an Emmy-winning American film and television actor, publishes an op-ed explaining why he turned down an audition for a Netflix series "Sycamore" (working title) in solidarity with Palestinian rights. The series was set to be a co-production between Israeli and U.S. companies, involving two creators, Avi Issacharoff and Lior Raz, who were previously criticized for racist portrayals of Palestinians and Arabs and for glorifying the Israeli military in the Netflix series "Fauda." Clennon notes "I have supported the Academic and Cultural Boycott of Israel since the 2014 Israeli War on Gaza."

headline: Democratic Socialists of America establish national working group on BDS
summary: At their national convention, the Democratic Socialists of America (DSA) passed a resolution to establish a national working group on BDS and Palestine solidarity. The DSA first endorsed BDS in 2017.

headline: Brooklyn rapper KOTA the Friend cancels Tel Aviv show
summary: Brooklyn rapper KOTA the Friend cancels a scheduled show in Tel Aviv, saying "I will not perform a show where certain groups are not permitted to attend."

headline: The Red Nation urges Native people and Nations to respect BDS call
summary: The Red Nation, a group dedicated to the liberation of Native peoples from capitalism and colonialism, releases a statement of solidarity with Palestinian liberation, including urging all Native people and Nations to respect the Palestinian call for BDS.

headline: UK Trades Union Congress calls for military embargo
summary: The UK’s Trades Union Congress, representing 48 unions and six million people, passes a motion calling for an end to arms trade with Israel that violates Palestinian rights, and commits to placing pressure corporations to end complicity in violations of Palestinian rights.

headline: Administrative Court in Germany rules in favor of BDS supporters
summary: The Administrative Court of Cologne ruled that the German-Palestinian Women’s Association (as well as two other Palestinian Solidarity Movements) must be allowed to participate in the Bonn cultural festival. Festival organizers had previously informed these groups that they would not be allowed to participate, following a motion from the German parliament in September 2018 condemning BDS. The court declared that the anti-BDS motions "do not constitute legislative acts" and "cannot justify, from any legal perspective, the restriction of an existing legal right." The court further declared that the attempt to exclude these groups constitutes “unequal treatment” and is “not even remotely” justified.

headline: Polls show growing support for BDS and right to boycott among American progressives and liberals
summary: A September 2019 poll by Shibley Telhami finds that 72% of all Americans oppose laws penalizing people who boycott Israel. Another September 2019 poll by Data for Progress shows that, among Democratic voters, 44% support BDS and 15% oppose it.

headline: UK Labour Party votes for Palestinian Right of Return
summary: At their annual conference, the UK Labour Party voted overwhelmingly to recognize the right of Palestinian refugees to return to their homes, as supported by international law. They also reaffirmed a resolution from the previous year calling for an end to arms sales to Israel. The votes are symbolic, as the 1940s Labour party adopted a platform calling for the ethnic cleansing of Palestinians.

headline: Anglican Church of South Africa adopts BDS
summary: The Anglican Church of South Africa votes unanimously to adopt a resolution supporting non-violent action to end the Israeli occupation, especially BDS actions. The resolution states, "there are possible similarities between Apartheid in South Africa and what is happening in Israel and Palestine and that in some respects the situation there can be described as worse than apartheid." The resolution also condemns all forms of anti-semitism and islamophobia.

headline: Portland Trail Blazers basketball team drops Leupold & Stevens partnership
summary: Portland Trail Blazers President Chris McGowan confirms that Leupold & Stevens no longer sponsors that NBA basketball team. Leupold & Stevens supplies rifle scopes to the U.S. military and other armed forces, including the Israeli Defense Force. The team faced pressure from the Portland Democratic Socialists of America and other groups, but denies that these protests influenced the change.

headline: Kamila Shamsie, award winning author, makes the case for cultural boycott on British television
summary: Kamila Shamsie, a British Pakistani novelist known for her award-winning novel, Home Fire, appears on British Channel 4 News to explain why she endorses a cultural boycott of Israel. The interview comes after the city of Dortmund in Germany denied Shamsie the Nelly Sachs Prize after discovering her stance on BDS. More than 250 writers then penned an open letter in the London Review of Books defending Shamsie and the right to boycott.

headline: Artist Tai Shani endorses cultural boycott
summary: Contemporary British artist Tai Shani, who won the prestigious Turner Prize in 2019, endorses the cultural boycott of Israel. Shani, who lived in Israel for 8 years, says "I don't see it [the Palestinian-Israeli situation] as a conflict, I see it as an absolute and asymmetrical abuse of power and a rewriting of history. The expulsion and occupation of Palestinians is ground zero."

headline: Episcopal Church divests from three companies involved in human right abuses against Palestinians
summary: The Executive Council of the Episcopal Church says it is divesting from Motorola Solutions, Caterpillar, and Israel Discount Bank and adding them to its no buy list. The news comes one year after the Episcopal Church, which has 3 million members, adopted a new investment screen to identify and exclude companies involved in human rights abuses against Palestinians. Rev. Canon C.K. Robertson, canon to the presiding bishop for ministry beyond The Episcopal Church, comments, "the Church does not want to make profits from companies that contribute to the suffering of others."

headline: Boycott Puma day of action reaches 50 cities worldwide, Donegal Celtic Football Club in Belfast supports
summary: 50 cities around the world join the second Global Boycott PUMA Day of Action. Donegal Celtic Football Club in Belfast supports the boycott of Puma initiated by 200 Palestinian sports clubs. Puma sponsors the Israel Football Association (IFA), which includes teams in illegal Israeli settlements on stolen Palestinian land.

headline: Oslo City Council bans settlement goods and services
summary: Oslo, Norway's capital and largest city, implements a ban on Israeli settlement goods and services from public procurements. Israeli settlement construction in the occupied West Bank, including East Jerusalem, and Syria’s Golan Heights, is illegal under international law. Five other Norwegian cities including Trondheim and Tromsø have already adopted similar bans on settlement goods and services.

headline: Maritime Union of Australia - Sydney Branch endorses boycott HP campaign
summary: Members of the Maritime Union of Australia - Sydney Branch decide to join the boycott HP campaign, referencing its history of boycotting apartheid South Africa. Members pledged to refrain from purchasing HP products until the company cancels all contracts that aid Israel’s violation of Palestinian rights and international law. HP provides equipment and technology to Israel’s military and police, and is involved in maintaining the population registry that Israel uses to enforce its system of racial segregation.

headline: 150 Italian groups declare Apartheid Free Zone in 5 months
summary: The Apartheid Free Zone campaign in Italy, which launched in June 2019, reaches 150 endorsers, including associations, trade unions, movements, artisans, commercial activities and cultural and sports centers. The Apartheid Free Zone campaign is also active in Belgium, Norway and the Spanish State, with more than three hundred endorsers, including dozens of local administrations. Endorses refuse ties with institutions and companies involved in violations of international law and Palestinian human rights.

headline: European Court of Justice says EU states must label Israeli settlement products
summary: The European Court of Justice, the EU's top court, rules that EU states must identify products made in Israeli settlements on their labels. The decision further states that settlements “give concrete expression to a policy of population transfer conducted by that State outside its territory, in violation of the rules of general international humanitarian law.” The ruling is expected to impact $16.5 billion worth of imports to the EU from Israeli settlements every year.

headline: Jamia Millia Islamia University agrees not to host events sponsored by Israeli government
summary: Jamia Millia Islamia University heeds student demands to stop hosting events sponsored by the Israeli government. The decision comes after the university initially responded violently to a student protest against such an event, which led to a 10-day, campus-wide sit-in.

headline: Columbia College Student Council agrees to hold divestment referendum
summary: The Columbia College Student Council votes to hold a referendum on whether the University should divest from companies profiting from or otherwise supporting Israeli policy toward the Palestinian people. The referendum will be included on the Spring 2020 elections ballot, and seeks the views of Columbia College students. The results will be presented to Columbia's Advisory Committee on Socially Responsible Investing, which has previously approved divestment from companies that profit off of private prisons and thermal coal.

headline: 55 academics sign open letter condemning call for "Israeli model" in Kashmir
summary: 55 academics condemn comments by Sandeep Chakravorty, Consul General of India in New York, about following an "Israeli model" in Kashmir with the regard to the return of Kashmiri Pandits. The letter calls for a military embargo on Israel, noting that India is one of the biggest importers of Israeli arms.

headline: Brown University committee votes to divest from companies connected to Israeli occupation
summary: Brown University’s Advisory Committee on Corporate Responsibility in Investment Policies (ACCRIP), composed of students, faculty, staff, and alumni, votes to recommend that the school divest from companies that facilitate Israeli human rights violations. The ACCRIP vote comes after 69% of Brown undergraduate students voted in favor of a divestment in March 2019. The non-binding decision will now be presented to Brown University President Christina Paxson for the university's decision.

headline: Brazilian groups stop bill in Parliament to strengthen military, scientific ties with Israel
summary: 50+ groups in opposition in Brazil’s parliament successfully filibustered a bill to strengthen military and scientific cooperation with Israel.

headline: Jordan's Parliament votes against natural gas imports from Israel
summary: After weeks of popular protest, Jordan’s parliament approved a draft law to ban imports of Israeli gas. The measure was passed just days after imports started under a $10 billion supply deal originally struck between Jordan’s state-owned utility and a U.S.-Israeli consortium led by Texas-based Noble Energy in 2016.

headline: Harvard Law Review says BDS "cannot be considered discriminatory"
summary: An article in Harvard Law Review publishes a note titled "Wielding Antidiscrimination Law to Suppress the Movement for Palestinian Rights." The note concludes that "anti-BDS laws cannot properly be viewed as combatting discrimination", that "BDS cannot be considered discriminatory even on a philosophical basis", and that anti-BDS laws reflect a "goal of chilling a disfavored political movement."

headline: Chester Football Club drops Puma as its supplier
summary: Chester Football Club announces that they have dropped Puma as the team's supplier. Puma sponsors the Israel Football Association (IFA), which includes teams based in illegal Israeli settlements, which are considered war crimes under international law. Puma’s exclusive licensee in Israel, Delta Galil, is listed in the United Nations settlement companies database due to its branches in illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: UN publishes list of companies operating in illegal Israeli settlements
summary: The UN Human Rights Council (UNHRC) publishes a database of 112 companies complicit in business activities in illegal Israeli settlements. Prominent companies named include travel companies TripAdvisor, Airbnb, Booking.com, Edreams and Expedia; the top five Israeli banks (Bank Hapoalim, Bank Leumi, First International Bank of Israel, Mizrahi Tefahot Bank and Israel Discount Bank); Israeli national water company Mekorot; General Mills, Motorola Solutions, JCB, and Alstom. The publication is an important step towards accountability, though the database only represents the tip of the iceberg of corporate complicity in Israeli human rights violations.

headline: International Trade Union Confederation calls on companies in UN database to end activities in illegal Israeli settlements
summary: The International Trade Union Confederation, the world's largest trade union federation with 207 million members in 163 countries, expresses support for the UN's publication of a list of 112 companies complicit in business activities in illegal Israeli settlements, and calls on all listed companies to end involvement in settlements.

headline: Largest Malaysian University ends contract with Puma
summary: Malaysia’s largest university, Universiti Teknologi MARA (UiTM), ends a sponsorship deal with global sportswear brand Puma over the company’s support for illegal Israeli settlements in the occupied Palestinian territory. Puma sponsors the Israel Football Association (IFA), which includes settlement teams, and Puma’s exclusive licensee in Israel, Delta Galil is listed in the United Nations database of settlement companies.

headline: 70 Basque groups call on Basque company to withdraw from Jerusalem Light Rail
summary: Basque groups called on CAF - Construction and Railroad Auxiliary, a Basque company, to withdraw from the Jerusalem Light Rail project after winning a $1.8 billion bid to expand the illegal settlement railway project.

headline: 170 Queer filmmakers pledge not to participate in Israeli government-sponsored LGBTQ film festival, 19 participants withdraw
summary: More than 170 LGBTQIA+ filmmakers from 15 countries sign a "Queer Cinema for Palestine" pledge committing not to participate in TLVFest, the Israeli government-sponsored LGBT film festival in Tel Aviv. Additionally, 19 participants in TLVFest 2020 withdrew, including 8 Brazilian filmmakers.

headline: Israeli Apartheid Week integrated into International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination
summary: 100+ European groups signed onto a call from Palestinian civil society to coordinate Israeli Apartheid Week events with International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination activities.

headline: 10 student groups from Complutense University of Madrid join Apartheid Free Zone
summary: 10 student associations and groups from Complutense University of Madrid declare themselves Apartheid Free Zones (AFZ). They commit to integrating activities to support Palestinian liberation and oppose Israel’s violations of Palestinian rights.

headline: Microsoft drops Israeli facial recognition startup
summary: Microsoft announces it will sell its stake in AnyVision, an Israeli facial recognition startup, and said it will no longer make minority investments in companies that sell the controversial technology. AnyVision's technology is used to surveil Palestinians living under Israeli military occupation.

headline: Italy's Apartheid Free Zone campaign grows to 200 groups
summary: More than 200 commercial activities, cultural and sports centers, and associations throughout Italy that have declared themselves apartheid free zones. The spaces that endorse the campaign take a public position in favor of human rights and against all forms of discrimination, and stand firmly with the Palestinian struggle for freedom, justice and equality.

headline: United Nations Development Program in Jordan drops G4S
summary: The United Nations Development Program (UNDP) reportedly will not renew their contracts with G4S, following a campaign by Jordanian civil society. UNDP is the fifth UN body in Jordan to sever ties with G4S, following UN Women, the World Food Program (WFP), UNICEF and UNHCR. G4S is the world’s largest security company, and has a long track record of involvement in human rights abuses worldwide, including in the management of Israel’s Police Academy in Jerusalem.

headline: UK Supreme Court upholds right of local councils to divest in landmark case
summary: The UK Supreme court rules in favor of the Palestine Solidarity Campaign in a landmark case. The case challenged UK government regulations which effectively banned Local Government Pension Schemes from divesting from companies involved in Israel’s human rights violations. The case has been ongoing since 2017.

headline: Forest Green Rovers football club pledges not to work with Puma
summary: The UK football club Forest Green Rovers pledges not to work with Puma as long as it remains involved in Israel's violations of Palestinian rights, with club chair Dale Vince stating that Palestine represents the "greatest global injustice" of his lifetime. Puma sponsors the Israel Football Association (IFA), which includes teams in illegal Israeli settlements on stolen Palestinian land.

headline: World Council of Churches and Middle East Council of Churches (MECC) condemn Israeli annexation plan, call for EU to impose "real consequences"
summary: The World Council of Churches, a fellowship of 350 churches from more than 110 countries, representing over 500 million Christians worldwide, pens a letter with the Middle East Council of Churches to the EU to condemn Israeli plans to officially annex large areas of the occupied West Bank. The letter calls on the EU to "ensure that any such annexation is met with real consequences, at least commensurate with those adopted by the EU in response to Russia’s annexation of Crimea."

headline: Over 400 scholars and artists oppose political litmus tests in Germany
summary: 426 scholars and artists sign a pledge committing not to serve on prize juries or in academic hiring committees in Germany whenever there are convincing indicators they may be subject to political interference or litmus tests. The pledge comes in response to multiple instances in which artists and scholars suspected of supporting the BDS movement were subjected to repressive political interference and smear campaigns by German public officials.

headline: Student Federation of the Austral University declares itself an Apartheid Free Zone
summary: The Student Federation of the Austral University of Chile joins the Apartheid Free Zone campaign. The students pledge to ensure their campus is free of complicity in Israel's violations of Palestinian human rights. More than 60 professors express their support for the Student Federation's statement and pledge to refuse institutional ties with Israeli universities complicit in violations of Palestinian human rights.

headline: Spanish courts affirm right to boycott in City of Cadiz
summary: Two Spanish courts, the Court of First Instance and the Court of Appeal, reject a criminal complaint filed by an Israel lobby group in response to BDS action in the City of Cadiz. The complaint cited the City of Cadiz's decision to cancel an Israeli embassy-sponsored film festival in 2017, on the basis of a motion which declared the city free from Israeli Apartheid. Both courts affirm that the city's action was intended to promote international law and human rights and that there was no discriminatory intent.

headline: European Court of Human Rights rules in favor of French BDS activists
summary: The European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) unanimously rules that the French highest court’s 2015 criminal conviction of 11 BDS activists violated article 10 of the European Convention on Human Rights on Freedom of Expression. The decision reinforces a 2016 European Union position defending the right to call for BDS against Israel to achieve Palestinian rights under international law.

headline: 250+ prominent South Africans call for sanctions to stop Israeli annexation
summary: 250 prominent South Africans sign a statement calling on the government of South Africa to sanction Israel due to its plan to annex up to 30% of the West Bank. Signatories include retired and current members of the judiciary, the Deputy Speaker of National Assembly, religious leaders, former and current university vice chancellors, former cabinet ministers, veterans of the liberation struggle, retired military generals including a former commander of the South African National Defence Force (SANDF), senior academics, social activists, human rights defenders, community leaders, members of the business community, arts and culture activists, journalists, and ex-political prisoners.

headline: Largest Dutch pension fund divests from two Israeli banks
summary: ABP, the largest pension fund in the Netherlands and one of the largest in the world with $500 billion in assets, divests from Israeli banks Hapoalim and Leumi for their financial services to illegal Israeli settlements. ABP previously divested $2.7 million from Elbit Systems, Israel’s largest weapons company, in 2010,and divested from two other Israeli companies in 2014.

headline: 20 cities join Boycott Puma Day of Action
summary: Over 20 cities across the world join Global Boycott PUMA Day of Action. On social media, #BoycottPUMA was the most used hashtag related to PUMA, with over 7 million impressions. Puma sponsors the Israel Football Association (IFA), which includes teams in illegal Israeli settlements on stolen Palestinian land. More than 200 Palestinian sports clubs have called for a worldwide #BoycottPuma campaign.

headline: 13 US Congressional Representatives call to condition military funding to Israel
summary: Betty McCollum, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Ilhan Omar, Bernie Sanders and Rashida Tlaib are among 13 US Congressional Representatives to sign a letter condemning Israeli plans to annex large areas of the West Bank. The letter pledges "should the Israeli government continue down this path, we will work to ensure non-recognition of annexed territories as well as pursue legislation that conditions the $3.8 billion in U.S. military funding to Israel to ensure that U.S. taxpayers are not supporting annexation in any way."

headline: Latin American leaders support call for sanctions on Israel
