summary: Former Latin American Presidents Dilma Rousseff (Brazil), Lula da Silva (Brazil), Evo Morales (Bolivia), Ernesto Samper (Colombia), Rafael Correa (Ecuador), José Mujica (Uruguay), and Fernando Lugo (Paraguay) are among over 320 public figures from Latin America to sign a statement calling for sanctions against Israel as a response to its planned de jure annexation of occupied Palestinian territory and to its ongoing de facto annexation and apartheid.

headline: Israel lobby loses appeal against American Studies Association
summary: A three-judge panel of the US Court of Appeals in Washington, DC, unanimously affirmed an earlier dismissal of a lawsuit brought against the American Studies Association over its support of an academic boycott of Israel. The ASA was sued in 2016 by the Louis D. Brandeis Center, a pro-Israel group that engages in "lawfare" to silence and intimidate Palestinian rights groups.

headline: Psychologists for Social Responsibility endsorses BDS
summary: Psychologists for Social Responsibility, a community who work to advance peace and social justice through the ethical use of psychological knowledge, research, and practice, vote to endorse BDS.

headline: The largest university in Europe divests from Caterpillar and Booking.com
summary: The University of Manchester, the largest university in Europe, divests $5 million from Caterpillar and Booking.com over complicity in Israeli violations of Palestinian human rights

headline: Luton Town Football Club drops Puma as its supplier
summary: Following engagement with local human rights activists over Puma's support for illegal Israeli settlements, the UK Championship League club Luton Town Football Club drops Puma as its supplier. Puma sponsors the Israel Football Association (IFA), which includes teams based in illegal Israeli settlements, which are considered war crimes under international law. Puma’s exclusive licensee in Israel, Delta Galil, is listed in the United Nations settlement companies database due to its branches in illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: Two Italian regional and city councils call for sanctions against Israel’s annexation plans
summary: The Emilia Romagna Regional Council and the Turin City Council in Italy pass resolutions opposing Israeli annexation plans in the West Bank and calling for sanctions.

headline: Leading artists condemn Israeli raids on Palestinian cultural centres and call for sanctions
summary: More than 60 musicians, filmmakers, and writers, including Massive Attack, Steve Coogan, Peter Gabriel, Maxine Peake, Philip Pullman and Benjamin Zephaniah, sign an open letter condemning a series of Israeli raids on Palestinian cultural centers and the arrests of their directors. The letter calls for sanctions related to trade, arms sales, and security co-operation.

headline: 60+ Arab leaders call for sanctions on Israel to counter apartheid and illegal annexation
summary: Arab intellectuals, former officials, human rights activists, academics, jurists, scientists, artists, and concerned politicians from 15 countries sign an open letter calling for “a broad range of effective sanctions” to counter Israeli apartheid and illegal annexation.

headline: BDS coordinator Mahmoud Nawajaa freed following sustained international pressure
summary: BDS coordinator Mahmoud Nawajaa is freed after Israel detained him without charge for 19 days. Israeli soldiers stormed his house, handcuffed and blindfolded him, and confiscated his laptop and cellphone as well as his wife’s. His arrest, in retaliation for his human rights work, prompted a campaign of sustained global pressure for his freedom. Amnesty International said Nawajaa was detained "solely for exercising his rights to freedom of expression and association and is therefore a prisoner of conscience."

headline: 4 international filmmakers withdraw from Docaviv
summary: 4 international participants, including Cíntia Gil, Director of Sheffield Doc/Fest, and filmmaker Eva Marie Rødbro, withdraw from Docaviv, the Tel Aviv International Documentary Film Festival, after being privately approached by BDS organizers. The festival was supported by the Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

headline: Arab artists pledge to boycott the UAE regime over Israel normalization
summary: More than 90 Arab artists, including many Palestinians, and 17 cultural organizations have pledged to boycott cultural activities sponsored by the UAE regime, after the latter announced it would normalize relations with Israel. They include filmmakers Mai Masri, Hany Abu Assad and Mohammad Bakri, visual artists Rachid Koraichi, Nabeel Anani and Suleiman Mansour, and musician Rima Tarazi.

headline: UK's Trades Union Congress passes motion calling for sanctions to oppose Israel’s annexation plans
summary: UK's Trades Union Congress (TUC), representing nearly six million UK workers, votes in favour of a motion which opposes the current Israeli government’s plans to annex up to 30% of the West Bank. The motion commits the TUC to continued partnership with the Palestine Solidarity Campaign in building opposition to Israel’s annexation plans and calls for the UK government to take decisive action including sanctions.

headline: Homi Bhahba, renowned scholar of postcolonial studies, withdraws from Israel conference
summary: Homi Bhahba, a humanities professor at Harvard and renowned scholar of postcolonial studies, confirms his withdrawal from the Israeli Sociological Society conference in Israel, where he was scheduled to give a keynote address via Zoom. He states “I have withdrawn from the ISS conference because I have decided that it is not only what you say that matters, but also when and where you say it.”

headline: San Francisco State University students vote to divest
summary: The student government at San Francisco State University votes 17-1-2 in favor of a resolution calling on the university to support divestment and review its investments in companies complicit in the Israeli occupation.

headline: 452 civil society organizations call on the UN to investigate Israeli apartheid
summary: 452 trade unions, movements, political parties and organizations from tens of countries call on the United Nations General Assembly to investigate Israeli apartheid and impose sanctions on Israel, as they historically did in the case of South African apartheid. Apartheid is a crime against humanity, giving rise to individual criminal responsibility and State responsibility to bring the illegal situation to an end.

headline: University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign students pass divestment resolution
summary: The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign student government passes a BDS resolution titled “Human Rights Violations in University Investments + Police Forces”, calling on the university to divest from companies that fund the American and Israeli military, prisons, police forces, and ICE. The resolution passed by a vote of 22-11-7.

headline: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez withdraws from event honoring former Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin
summary: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez confirms her withdrawal from a memorial event for former Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, saying "this event and my involvement was presented to my team differently from how it’s now being promoted." Rabin (who was assassinated by an Israeli right-wing extremist in 1995), was an operations officer during the 1948 Nakba and signed the order to expel over 50,000 Palestinians from their homes in the “Lydda Death March.” During the First Intifada, Rabin allegedly told soldiers to break the bones of any Palestinian who resisted.

headline: Columbia University students pass divestment resolution
summary: The student body at Columbia University passes a referendum calling on the university to divest from companies "that profit from or engage in the State of Israel’s acts towards Palestinians."

headline: Liverpool cancels Electronic Warfare Europe 2020 arms fair
summary: The city of Liverpool (UK) cancels the Electronic Warfare Europe arms fair at the city-run ACC Exhibition Centre following mobilization by a strong local coalition. Elbit Systems, Israel’s largest private weapons manufacturer whose arms are regularly used by the Israeli military to kill Palestinian civilians, was one of the fair's global partners.

headline: UK Government body will investigate JCB over activities in occupied Palestinian territories
summary: The UK-based construction equipment company JCB will be investigated after a UK Government body, The UK National Contact Point, which is part of the Department for International Trade, finds that key aspects of a human rights complaint against it are “material and substantiated”, in relation to the use of its heavy machinery in Israel’s illegal demolitions and settlement construction in the occupied Palestinian territory. JCB is listed in the UN database of companies with a “substantial and material” involvement in Israeli settlement activities.

headline: Norweigian firm divests from four companies profiting from Israeli occupation and settlement
summary: Storebrand Asset Management, the largest private asset manager in Norway, confirms that it has divested from four companies––DXC Technology Co., First Solar, Inc., General Electric Co., and Israel Discount Bank––over their operations in occupied Palestinian territories, and is examining additional divestments. Storebrand is also reviewing companies involved in the Western Sahara.

headline: 8 Norwegian trade unions call for excluding CAF, a transport company, from public contracts
summary: Norwegian trade unions, including railway unions, urge Norway’s public sector not to work with CAF - Construction and Railroad Auxiliary, until it stops building Israel’s illegal Jerusalem Light Rail, which connects Israeli settlements in the West Bank to each other and to Jerusalem.

headline: Cori Bush, BDS supporter, wins election to US Congress
summary: Cori Bush, first black Congresswoman in Missouri history and a BDS supporter, wins landslide victory to become U.S. Representative. During her campaign, Bush was attacked for her stance on BDS, but did not back down. Her campaign stated, "Cori Bush has always been sympathetic to the BDS movement, and she stands in solidarity with the Palestinian people, just as they have stood in solidarity with Black Americans fighting for their own lives."

headline: 100+ groups call on UN to add HP to database of companies operating in illegal settlements
summary: Over 100 unions, student associations, people’s movements and solidarity groups from around the world call on the UN to add Hewlett Packard Enterprises to its database of businesses complicit in Israel’s settlement enterprise. HP provides exclusive servers to maintain the database for Israel’s Population and Immigration Authority. This includes the ‘Yesha database’ of Israeli citizens living in illegal settlements in the occupied Palestinian territory.

headline: Portuguese company ends drone contract with Israel's Elbit Systems
summary: Portuguese company CeiiA decides not to renew the lease of two drones from Elbit Systems, Israel's largest arms company, for border patrol and other missions for the European Maritime Safety Agency (EMSA). This decision follows the signing of a "Stop Israeli Killer Drones" petition by over 10,000 European citizens demanding the end of the contract. However, other EU member states and EU border guard agency Frontex continue to use Israeli drone services.

headline: German court rules in favor of BDS groups' right to host events
summary: A German court rules that the city of Munich cannot deny public space to BDS groups for their events.

headline: Grassroots pushback stops majority of US bills repressing advocacy for Palestinian rights
summary: Paletine Legal new analysis that only a fraction (25%) of hundreds of bills lawmakers have introduced to repress advocacy for Palestinian rights have become law because of strong grassroots and civil liberties opposition.

headline: Students at Tufts University become first to adopt "Deadly Exchange" campaign demands on campus
summary: In a student-wide referendum, students at Tufts University vote overwhelmingly to end the Deadly Exchange at Tufts. The "Deadly Exchange" refers to US police departments’ participation in trips taken to Israel in which high ranking officials train with the Israeli military, police, and security forces to exchange "worst practices" such as racial profiling, excessive force, spying and surveillance, and more. The campaign began after a Freedom of Information Act request revealed that Tufts former police chief, Kevin Maguire, went on a “counter-terrorism” training trip to Israel.

headline: UN diplomat Lakhdar Brahimi calls on UN to investigate Israeli apartheid
summary: Lakhdar Brahimi, Algerian UN Diplomat and Member of the Elders, calls on the UN to investigate Israeli apartheid, saying “the General Assembly of the UN played a central role in the successful dismantling of apartheid in South Africa. It could, it should play an equally important role in ending Israel’s apartheid regime against Palestinians.” He cites the Palestinian civil society call for the UN General Assembly to investigate Israeli apartheid, and to impose targeted sanctions to end Israeli apartheid. Global support for the UN to investigate Israeli apartheid also include 452 civil society organizations worldwide; ten ex-Presidents from Latin America and Africa; and 720 Global South members of parliament, diplomats and cultural figures.

headline: AXA boycott pledge draws widespread support
summary: Some 10,000 people and over 230 organizations and businesses sign a pledge to boycott AXA, the French multinational insurance firm, over complicity in Israel’s illegal occupation. AXA invests $7 million in three Israeli banks (Bank Leumi, Israeli Discount Bank and Mizrahi Tefahot Bank) that finance Israel’s illegal settlements. All three banks are named in the UN database of companies that are complicit in Israel’s illegal settlement enterprise. AXA also maintains a 9% stake in Equitable Holdings, a company which invests in these Israeli banks and in Elbit Systems, a leading Israeli arms manufacturer involved in Israeli war crimes against Palestinians.

headline: 32 leading German cultural organizations criticize 2019 German anti-BDS resolution
summary: At a news conference in Berlin, the directors of 32 prominent German cultural institutions release an open letter in which they reject the censorship of the German Parliament’s 2019 anti-BDS resolution, describing it as "dangerous." The directors of the Berliner Festspiele, the Humboldt Forum and the Federal Cultural Foundation, along with the leaders of theaters, museums, and institutes for Jewish cultural studies from across the country are among those who sign the appeal.

headline: Seville cancels Electronic Warfare Europe 2021 arms fair
summary: Following the city of Liverpool's decision not to host the 2020 Electronic Warfare Europe arms fair, the city of Seville also cancels its plans to host the 2021 edition of the fair. The Seville City Council says the government's decision responds to the "inconvenience of linking the city's image as a major congress venue to a controversial event with national and international repercussions."

headline: 170 Latin American academics from 17 countries endorse academic boycott
summary: 170 academics from 17 Latin American countries pledge not to participate in any type of academic exchange or cooperation with complicit Israeli institutions or accept funding from such institutions or from the Israeli government. In addition, they call on Latin American universities to suspend cooperation with complicit Israeli institutions, until Israel respects the political and human rights of the Palestinian people. Among the signatories are anthropologist Ochy Curiel, Colombian anthropologist Arturo Escobar, Maya-Kaqchikel thinker Aura Cumes Simón, Chilean historian Igor Alexis Goicovic Donoso, Chilean historian Sergio Grez Toso, Chilean artist Ingrid Wildi Merino, Argentine philosopher (based in Mexico) Silvana Rabinovich, Colombian philosopher María del Rosario Acosta, Chilean philosopher Rodrigo Karmy Bolton and Colombian philosopher Laura Quintana.

headline: More than 1,400 German and international artists reject German anti-BDS resolution
summary: 1,400+ German and international artists follow elite German cultural institutions in rejecting Germany's 2019 anti-BDS resolution. Their letter states, "We urge the German parliament to heed the findings of the European Court of Human Rights, which recently rejected the criminalization of boycotts directed against Israel...no state should be exempt from criticism. Regardless of whether we support BDS or not, as signatories of this letter we share an insistent belief in the right to exercise non-violent pressure on governments that violate human rights."

headline: Community declaration in Montreal calls for cancellation of Canada-Israel Free Trade Agreement
summary: 150+ academics & artists and 20+ trade unions, cultural organizations, student groups and indigenous collectives in Montréal urge the Canadian government to cancel the Canada-Israel Free Trade Agreement.

headline: Methodist Council calls to revise investments to screen companies profiting from Israeli occupation
summary: The Methodist Council voted overwhelmingly in favour of calling on the Joint Advisory Committee on the Ethics of Investment (JACEI) to revise the existing policy related to companies involved in Israel's occupation of Palestine.

headline: Italy's Apartheid Free Zone campaign grows to 250 groups
summary: Across Italy, 250 social, cultural, sports and commercial spaces commit to having no ties with companies and institutions complicit in Israel's apartheid regime.

headline: For second time, University of California in Irvine students pass divestment resolution
summary: University of California in Irvine's Student Senate votes 19-3 in favor of a resolution calling on the university to divest "from all corporations contributing to the human rights violations of Palestinians." UC Irvine students first voted in favor of divestment in 2012. This resolution stood for seven years until it was repealed by the 2019–2020 student government. In reinstating the call for divestment, the new resolution notes that seven other UC campuses have also passed divestment motions on Israeli apartheid.

headline: East Sussex Pension Fund divests from Elbit Systems
summary: East Sussex Pension Fund divests $22,000 from Elbit Systems, Israel’s largest arms company, after months of campaigning by human rights activists and scheme members. The pension fund has 78,000 members and manages over £2.5 billion in assets. A spokesperson for the fund said the company "fell out of the portfolio” after a review of “environmental, social and corporate governance factors.”

headline: Women in sports express support for Puma boycott with #SheBoycotts
summary: On International Women's Day, as Puma launches the "She Moves Us" marketing campaign, the hashtag #SheBoycotts trended on Twitter as women in sports expressed solidarity with the Palestinian campaign to boycott Puma over its sponsorship of the Israeli Football Association, which includes teams located in illegal Israeli settlements on stolen Palestinian land. More than 200 Palestinian sports clubs have called for a worldwide #BoycottPuma campaign.

headline: Association of Professors of the University of Brasília opposes collaboration with Israeli companies
summary: Association of Professors of the University of Brasília (ADUnB) votes by 80% to reject a collaboration with Israeli companies. The vote came after the Office of the Rector announced a meeting with the Israeli ambassador in which proposals for cooperation were discussed, such as "strengthening the relationship with Israeli companies" through a presence in the Science and Technology Park of the National University of Brasilia.

headline: The University of Costa Rica incorporates BDS into ethics standards
summary: Following a boycott campaign by the Federation of Students of the University of Costa Rica, the University of Costa Rica announces new ethics standards to prevent the university from entering into cooperation agreements that support Israel's military occupation, colonialism, and apartheid over the Palestinian people.

headline: 150 Jewish faculty issue statement against IRHA definition of antisemitism, recognizing legitimacy of BDS
summary: In response to a pressure campaign on Canadian universities to adopt a working definition of antisemitism that conflates criticism of Israel with antisemitism, 150 prominent Jewish faculty from across Canadian universities and colleges issue a statement opposing the definition and supporting the right to boycott. The statement says "we add our voices to a growing international movement of Jewish scholars to insist that university policies to combat antisemitism are not used to stifle legitimate criticisms of the Israeli state, or the right to stand in solidarity with the Palestinian people. We recognize that the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions (BDS) movement is a legitimate, non-violent form of protest. While not all of us endorse the BDS movement we oppose equating its support with antisemitism." They also state that "the IHRA working definition distracts from experiences of anti-Jewish racism, and threatens to silence legitimate criticism of Israel’s grave violations of international law and denial of Palestinian human and political rights."

headline: Human Rights Watch says Israel is committing the crime of apartheid
summary: Human Rights Watch publishes "A Threshold Crossed: Israeli Authorities and the Crimes of Apartheid and Persecution," concluding that Israel is committing the crime of apartheid.

headline: First student association in Switzerland endorses BDS, declares Apartheid Free Zone
summary: The Graduate Institute Student Association (GISA) in Switzerland endorses BDS and declares itself an Apartheid Free Zone after holding an online vote, becoming the first student association in Switzerland to do so.

headline: 130 Mexican civil rights organizations demand CEMEX end complicity with Israeli apartheid
summary: 130 Mexican civil rights organizations sign and open letter demanding that CEMEX, a Mexican construction company, end complicity with Israeli apartheid. CEMEX has production plants in territories occupied by Israel. Its cement and concrete are used in the construction of illegal Israeli settlements and Israel's wall.

headline: Rugby player Duncan Casey and French football club FC Ménilmontant join calls to boycott Puma
summary: Retired Irish rugby player Duncan Casey calls on PUMA to end support for Israeli apartheid as PUMA’s #OnlySeeGreat campaign is taken over by #OnlySeeApartheid ahead of its shareholders meeting. French football club FC Ménilmontant also joins the campaign. Puma sponsors the Israel Football Association (IFA), which includes teams in illegal Israeli settlements on stolen Palestinian land. More than 200 Palestinian sports clubs have called for a worldwide #BoycottPuma campaign.

headline: Local union of roofers calls for sanctions against Israel
summary: The Roofers Local 36 in Los Angeles calls for stopping all economic and military funding to Israel, saying "imperialist aggression, ethnic cleansing and genocide are the enemy of all working people and organized Labor must step up to defend the democratic rights of oppressed peoples everywhere."

headline: United Educators of San Francisco (UESF) becomes first teachers union in the US to endorse BDS
summary: United Educators of San Francisco (UESF), representing some 6,200 teachers and other school employees, passes a resolution endorsing BDS at its monthly delegate assembly.

headline: Unprecedented wave of academic support for BDS, Palestinian rights amidst Israeli attack on Gaza
summary: More than 350 academic departments, programs, centers, unions and societies worldwide endorse statements in support of Palestinian rights in response to the May 2021 Israeli attack on Gaza, many of which include support for BDS. Similar statements from individual scholars, researchers, university staff, students and alumni garner 24,000 signatures.

headline: Qatar Sports Club states they won't renew PUMA contract
summary: Qatar Sports Club confirms that they don't plan to renew their contract with sportswear manufacturer Puma due to its compliance with Israeli occupation. Puma sponsors the Israel Football Association (IFA), which includes teams in illegal Israeli settlements on stolen Palestinian land. More than 200 Palestinian sports clubs have called for a worldwide #BoycottPuma campaign.

headline: Hundreds of Finnish scholars, artists, cultural orgs & academic institutions pledge to support BDS
summary: 380+ scholars and artists and 25+ cultural orgs & academic institutions in Finland call on "Finnish and Finland-based artists, cultural workers and academics as well as cultural organizations and academic institutions to join the boycott" of complicit Israeli institutions. They also call on Finland to "immediately end all arms trade with Israel and ban the import of products from the illegal settlements."

headline: Middle East section of American Anthropological Association votes for academic boycott
summary: Anthropologists of the Middle East, the Middle East Section of the American Anthropological Association, votes 157 to 11 in favor of a resolution to boycott Israeli academic institutions, stating "the boycott represents an act of solidarity from scholars specializing on the region, many of whom have long studied U.S. support for Israel’s colonial practices and violent suppression of the Palestinian people."

headline: Norway's largest pension fund divests from 16 companies over links to Israeli settlements
summary: KLP, a Norwegian pension fund with $70 billion in assets, announces it will divest $32 million in shares from 16 companies based on their contributions to “the abuse of human rights…through their links with the Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank." KLP previously divested from Israeli weapons manufacturer Elbit Systems in 2009.

headline: 39 labour organizations call for suspension of military trade with Israel
summary: 39 Candian labour organizations, representing hundreds of thousands of workers across Canada, sign an open letter to Prime Minister JustinTrudeau, urging the Government of Canada to immediately suspend bilateral trade of all arms and related materials with Israel.

headline: A third Scottish pension fund divests from Israeli bank
summary: Lothian Pension Fund, the second largest local authority pension fund in Scotland with 84,000 members and £8 billion of assets, has divested from Israeli Bank Hapoalim. Falkirk Pension Fund divested in 2018 and  Tayside Pension Fund in 2019. Bank Hapoalim is listed in the UN’s database of business enterprises involved in illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: Chilean parliament bans import of Israeli settlement goods
summary: The Chilean parliament introduces a bill to ban import of goods from sraeli settlements, which are illegal under international law.

headline: City University of New York (CUNY) Union condemns Israeli apartheid, commits to discussing BDS
summary: The City University of New York (CUNY) staff congress, representing 30,000 members across the university system, passes a resolution condemning recent escalation of Israeli violence and calling out Israel as a settler colonial apartheid state. The resolution also states that the union will facilitate discussions of BDS in the Fall of 2021.

headline: Japanese supermarket stops selling wine manufactured in illegal Israeli settlements
summary: A branch of Ozeki, a famous supermarket chain in Tokyo, stops sales of wine manufactured in illegal Israeli settlements in response to a letter from BDS Japan Bulletin (BJB).

headline: Prominent scholar Richard T. W. Arthur withdraws from conference hosted by Israel's Technion
summary: Richard T. W. Arthur, a prominent scholar of philosophy and Professor Emeritus at McMaster University, withdraws from a conference hosted by Israel's Technion, stating "it has recently been brought to my attention that the Technion has been proactive in helping the state of Israel to develop the military technology used to repress the Palestinians in the recent attacks on Gaza (including destruction of a hospital and universities), and to bulldoze their homes in the occupied territories, through its close cooperation with Elbit Systems and Rafael Advanced Systems. I have therefore withdrawn my participation from this conference."

headline: Seattle teachers union endorses BDS
summary: The Seattle Education Association (SEA), representing around 5,500 teachers and staff who work for Seattle Public Schools, passes a resolution endorsing BDS. The resolution expresses solidarity with Palestine and demands an end to collaboration between the Seattle Police Department and the Israeli military.

headline: Canada’s largest labour organization, with 3.3 million members, endorses divestment
summary: The Candian Labour Congress (CLC) adopts an emergency motion that commits to supporting a ban on settlement goods, promoting divestment from Israeli military and security companies, and calling on Canada to halt arms sales to Israel, among other measures. The CLC is the central labour body in Canada with a membership of 3.3 million.

headline: Berlin group Buttons severs ties with venue in solidarity with Palestinians
summary: Buttons, a group that events focused on providing "safer spaces, dance floors, art, income and music for queer artists in this city," severs a longstanding relationship with ://about blank, the nightclub at which they have housed their events for over 5 years, over the venue's stance "in favor of all actions of the Israeli state to the point of silencing both Jewish and Palestinian voices." The crew explained, "queer liberation is fundamentally tied to the dreams of Palestinian liberation: self-determination, dignity, and the end of all systems of oppression.”

headline: Leaked Puma memo shows impact of boycott campaign
summary: A leaked internal memo from Puma shows that the company has had to respond to "an increase in number of requests from our business ambassadors " around the "claim that Puma sponsors teams in illegal settlements." Puma sponsors the Israeli Football Association (IFA), which includes clubs based in illegal Israeli settlements in the Occupied Palestinian Territory. More than 200 Palestinian sports clubs have called for a worldwide #BoycottPuma campaign.

headline: 10 former presidents and hundreds of cultural figures from Latin America, Asia, and Africa call for sanctions on Israel
summary: Ten former presidents, and more than 700 members of parliament, mayors, cultural figures and academics from Latin America, Asia and Africa, called on the UN to recognize Israel as an apartheid State and to impose sanctions on it.

headline: Protesters highlight Israeli "sportwashing" during Tour de France
summary: Protesters along the Tour de France route highlighted "sportswashing" by the Israel-Premier Tech cycling team. The team, sponsored by the Israeli government, recruits elite international riders as, according to the team owner, "ambassadors of the country of Israel...We use sport to create ties and promote the country’s image.” The team is owned by a Canadian billionaire.

headline: Clapton Community Football Club players join international day of action to boycott Puma
summary: Clapton Community Football Club, a fan-owned British team, announces support for the boycott of Puma and declares itself an apartheid free zone. Puma sponsors the Israeli Football Association (IFA), which includes clubs based in illegal Israeli settlements in the Occupied Palestinian Territory. More than 200 Palestinian sports clubs have called for a worldwide #BoycottPuma campaign.

headline: FC Barcelona refuses to play match in Jerusalem
summary: A planned match between FC Barcelona and Beitar Jerusalem is canceled after FC Barcelona conditions the match on it not being played in Jerusalem. Beitar Jerusalem fans have chanted "death to Arabs" at matches.

headline: Ben & Jerry's announces it will end agreement with Israeli licensee
summary: Ben & Jerry's announces it will not renew its licensing agreement with its Israeli licensee in order to end sales of its ice cream in illegal Israeli settlements, saying "we believe it is inconsistent with our values for Ben & Jerry’s ice cream to be sold in the Occupied Palestinian Territory."

headline: 160 recipients of EU research funding, 522 academics from Europe, and 60 Members of European Parliament call on the EU not to fund Israeli academic institutions
summary: In three separate appeals in 2021, 160 past and current recipients of prestigious European Union research funding, 522 academics from Europe, and 60 Members of European parliament urge the EU to exclude Israeli academic institutions complicit in Israel’s grave violations of international law and Palestinian human rights from its research funding and programmes.

headline: Two Judokas drop out of Olympics in solidarity with Palestinians
summary: Algerian Fethi Nourine and Sudanese Mohamed Abdalrasool drop out of the Tokyo Olympics as a statement of solidarity with Palestinians. The two athletes were scheduled to face an Israeli opponent. Nourine stated, "we worked a lot to reach the Olympics, but the Palestinian cause is bigger than all of this.”

headline: Protesters picket Puma stores for #BoycottPuma day of action; 150,000 signatures delivered to Puma offices
summary: Global Boycott PUMA Day of Action sees actions in 50 cities on six continents and 20 million impressions on Twitter.  Palestinian and international athletes call on Puma to drop its sponsorship of the Israeli Football Association (IFA), which includes clubs based in illegal Israeli settlements in the Occupied Palestinian Territory. More than 200 Palestinian sports clubs initiated the campaign.

headline: Author Sally Rooney complies with BDS
summary: Irish author Sally Rooney issues a statement announcing that she has denied a bid by an Israeli publishing company to translate her latest novel, "Beautiful World, Where Are You," into Hebrew to comply with BDS guidelines. She writes "I am responding to the call from Palestinian civil society" and expresses "my solidarity with the Palestinian people in their struggle for freedom, justice, and equality." Rooney's previous novels include Conversations with Friends and Normal People.

headline: 1000+ Google and Amazon workers condemn contract with Israeli military
summary: In a letter in The Guardian, Google and Amazon workers demand that their companies end "Project Nimbus," a $1.2 billion contract to provide cloud services for the Israeli military and government. They say, "this technology allows for further surveillance of and unlawful data collection on Palestinians, and facilitates expansion of Israel’s illegal settlements on Palestinian land. We cannot look the other way, as the products we build are used to deny Palestinians their basic rights, force Palestinians out of their homes and attack Palestinians in the Gaza Strip – actions that have prompted war crime investigations by the international criminal court."

headline: Coalition of over 60 labor unions endorses BDS
summary: The Centre International De Solidarité Ouvrière (CISO), a coalition of 60+ Quebec labor unions and civil society groups unanimously passes a resolution endorsing BDS. The resolution also calls on the Canadian government to designate Israel as an apartheid state, commits to educating CISO members on Palestine and BDS, and vows to protect freedom of speech on Palestine.

headline: Puma agrees to meet after 120,000 signatures delivered to offices across four continents
summary: A SumofUs petition that garnered 120,000 signatures is delivered to Puma offices across four continents. The CEO of Puma joins a meeting with SumOfUs about the campaign. Puma sponsors the Israeli Football Association (IFA), which includes clubs based in illegal Israeli settlements in the Occupied Palestinian Territory. More than 200 Palestinian sports clubs initiated the campaign.

headline: With the Miss Universe pageant scheduled to be held in Israel, South African government withdraws support for Miss South Africa pageant
summary: The South African government withdraws its support for the Miss South Africa pageant after the pageant organizers decide to participate in the Miss Universe pageant in Israel.

headline: Prominent legal journal, the N.Y.U. Review of Law & Social Change, endorses BDS
summary: The N.Y.U. Review of Law & Social Change publishes a statement expressing "our firm commitment to the Boycott, Divestment, Sanctions (“BDS”) movement and our solidarity with Palestinians collectively struggling towards liberation."

headline: Queer Cinema for Palestine features 250 queer filmmakers who support BDS
summary: The premier edition of Queer Cinema for Palestine features 250 queer filmmakers who have either withdrawn from  the Israeli government-sponsored TLVFest or pledged not to participate in response to the Palestinian call for BDS.

headline: Greek contestant Rafaele Plastira withdraws from Miss Universe pageant in Israel
summary: In aolidarity with Palestinians, Miss Universe Greece, Rafaele Plastira, announces she will not attend the Miss Universe pageant hosted by Israel. She issued a statement on Instagram captioned "humanity above beauty pageants," in which she explained "I can't go up on that stage and act like nothing is happening when people are fighting for their lives out there...Palestine lives in my heart forever."

headline: 70 prominent writers support Sally Rooney's boycott
summary: 70 prominent writers, poets and playwrights, including Kamila Shamsie, Monica Ali and China Miévillehave, sign a letter endorsing Sally Rooney’s decision to decline a contractual offer with an Israel publishing house in support of the Palestinian call for BDS, describing it as “an exemplary response to the mounting injustices inflicted on Palestinians.”

headline: Malaysia bars entry to Israeli team at World Squash event
summary: Malaysia, which has no diplomatic relations with Israel, refuses to grant visas for Israeli players to participate in the World Squash Federation's (WSF) Men's Squash Team Championship.

headline: Canadian Association of University Teachers adopts motion to protect academic freedom on Palestine
summary: Canadian Association of University Teachers (CAUT) adopts a motion to protect academic freedom on Palestine, specifically opposing the conflation of criticism of Israel with antisemitism in the IRHA definition of antisemitism. CAUT represents 72,000 teachers, librarians, researchers, general staff, and other academic professors at around 125 higher education institutions in Canada,

headline: The Middle East Studies Association votes to advance a BDS resolution
summary: The Middle East Studies Association (MESA) votes by an overwhelming 93% majority to advance a motion to MESA's near 2,800 members supporting the BDS movement and the academic boycott of complicit Israeli universities.

headline: City University of New York (CUNY) law students pass BDS resolution
summary: The CUNY Law School Student Government Association passes a resolution endorsing BDS. The resolution calls on the university to divest from companies that profit off of Israel's system of military occupation and apartheid, end all exchange programs with Israel, and "end its complicity in the ongoing censorship, harassment, and intimidation of Palestine solidarity activists."

headline: Artists withdraw en masse from the prestigious Sydney Festival over its acceptance of Israeli government funding
summary: Dozens of artists withdraw from the Sydney Festival, a major Australian arts festival that draws 365,000 attendees, to protest the festival's acceptance of $20,000 in funding from the Israeli embassy, and festival staff cancel shifts. The artists acting in solidarity with Palestine account for approximately one fifth of total artists participating in the festival, with Indigenous artists leading the way.

headline: HP ends contract to provide servers for Israel’s population database, but remains complicit in serving Israeli prisons and police
summary: HP Enterprise ends its contract providing servers for the computerization of Israel’s population database known as Aviv System, a pillar of apartheid. The #BoycottHP campaign continues, however, to compel it to end its ongoing complicity with Israeli police and prison services.

headline: Authors from Kuwait, Oman and Saudi Arabi withdraw from Emirates Airline Festival of Literature
summary: Authors from Kuwait, Oman and Saudi Arabi withdraw from Emirates Airline Festival of Literature in the United Arab Emirates to protest the participation of an Israeli author. Among them are Omani author Bushra Khalfan and the entire Kuwaiti delegation that was participating in the festival, including writers Muna al-Shamari and Ali Ashour al-Jaffar. The Gulf Coalition Against Normalization called on authors to withdraw to protest alliances between Israel and Gulf States brokered by the Trump administration.

headline: Amnesty International releases its report "Israel's Apartheid Against Palestinians"
summary: Following a string of reports from B’Tselem, Human Rights Watch, and other human rights organisations, Amnesty International issues a landmark report concluding "Israel imposes a system of oppression and domination against Palestinians across all areas under its control: in Israel and the OPT, and against Palestinian refugees, in order to benefit Jewish Israelis. This amounts to apartheid as prohibited in international law."

headline: 220+ scholars from Latin America commit to academic boycott
summary: More than 220 scholars from 14 countries in Latin America sign a statement pledging to refuse academic exchanges, collaboration with, or funding from complicit Israeli institutions in solidarity with Palestinians.

headline: Georgetown University students prevent tuition funds from subsidizing trip that whitewashes Israeli apartheid
summary: Graduate and undergraduate students at Georgetown University announce, "[we] are pleased to declare that we successfully blocked $30,000 of student funding from financing a trip to Israel with the pro-Israel organization, itrek, and fully cut the trip's institutional links to Georgetown University and the university's Graduate Student Government (GradGov), in line with BDS principles of academic boycott." They further explain that their opposition to using student tuition funds to subsidize the trip is based on "the nature of the partnering pro-Israel organization, itrek, whose purpose is to whitewash the Occupation of Palestine" and "the destination of the trip to an Apartheid state that enforces military rule on millions of Palestinians and occupies their land." Itrek focuses on promoting a narrative of Israel as "startup nation" to business, law, and STEM students.

headline: Australia’s Future Fund bans investment in Elbit Systems
summary: Australia’s $200 billion Future Fund, an independently managed sovereign wealth fund of the Australian government, bans investment in Elbit Systems, Israel's largest weapons company, over Elbit's association with prohibited cluster munitions.

headline: First Pan-African Anti-Apartheid Conference gathers activists from 21 African countries
summary: Civil society activists from 21 countries across Africa gather for the first pan-African anti-apartheid conference. They pledge to intensify the fight against Israel’s apartheid practices against the Palestinian people, including by supporting sanctions against Israel and "by mobilising all sectors of African society to build an effective BDS campaign against Israel that is modelled along the social justice movement that isolated and helped defeat apartheid in South Africa."

headline: Middle East Studies Association scholars vote to endorse BDS
summary: 80% of Middle East Studies Association participating members vote in favor of a resolution endorsing the Palestinian call for BDS as a way to hold the Israeli government accountable for ongoing human rights violations and in solidarity with Palestinians who are denied educational opportunities as a result of Israeli apartheid policies.

headline: United Nations investigator confirms Israel is perpetrating apartheid
summary: Michael Lynk, UN Special Rapporteur on the situation of human rights in the occupied Palestinian territories, issues a report confirming that Israel is perpetrating the crime against humanity of apartheid. Five UN human rights experts endorsed this conclusion. The report adds to growing consensus in the Palestinian and international human rights community that Israel has enacted apartheid over the Palestinian people.

headline: As sports bodies sanction Russia, athletes speak out in solidarity with Palestinians
summary: International athletes speak out in solidarity with Palestinians and call out the hypocrisy of international sporting bodies who swiftly sanctioned Russia over its illegal invasion of Ukraine, but have failed to apply the same principles in the case of Israeli apartheid. Sporting bodies governing football, tennis, swimming, judo, fencing, rugby, volleyball, athletics, basketball, cycling, rowing, boxing, gymnastics and others enacted sanctions on Russia, demonstrating their selective understanding that sport is political. Many of these same bodies, including FIFA, UEFA, UCI, and Ironman, have fined fan clubs and suspended athletes expressing solidarity with Palestinians.

headline: AFC Wimbledon chooses not to renew its kit deal with PUMA
summary: AFC Wimbledon, an English professional football club, chooses not to renew its kit deal with PUMA following more than 2,000 email messages calling on the club to end its contract with PUMA over its sponsorship of the Israel Football Association. The Israeli Football Association includes teams located in illegal Israeli settlements on stolen Palestinian land. More than 200 Palestinian sports clubs have called for a worldwide #BoycottPuma campaign.

headline: City University of New York (CUNY) law faculty unanimously endorse BDS resolution
summary: The City University of New York (CUNY) Law Faculty unanimously endorsed a BDS resolution passed by students in December 2021. The resolution was put forward by the law school's student government body and was co-sponsored by the university's chapters of Students for Justice in Palestine (SJP) and the Jewish Law Students’ Association (JLSA).

headline: Harvard Crimson editorial board endorses BDS
summary: The Harvard Crimson editorial board endorses BDS and 50 Harvard faculty members pledge their support for the editorial board's position. The editorial also emphasizes the board's support for the Harvard College Palestine Solidarity Committee's activities on campus.

headline: Argentina National Team cancels match with Israeli team
summary: The Argentina National Team, which would go on to win the 2022 World Cup, cancels a planned "friendly match" with Israel. The decision followed a  public campaign and open letter from Palestinian football team Al Khader. One of Al Khader's players, Mohammad Ghneim, was killed by Israeli forces in April. Another Palestinian footballer, Thaer Yazouri, was killed by Israeli forces in May.

headline: General Mills divests from joint venture with Israeli food company
summary: General Mills, parent company of Pillsbury, has sold its stake in its joint venture with an Israeli food company. The move comes after years of BDS pressure by activists over its manufacturing of Pillsbury products in the Atarot industrial zone, an illegal Israeli settlement on stolen Palestinian land.

headline: Delegation of South African clergy calls on Christian communities and institutions to end support to Israeli apartheid
summary: A delegation of South African clergy representing the World Council of Churches, the South African Council of Churches and The Evangelical Alliance of South Africa calls on Christian communities and institutions as well as governments to recognize and denounce Israeli policies as apartheid and to end all support to Israeli apartheid.

headline: Norway's largest trade union federation declares support for BDS
summary: Norway's largest trade union federation, LO Norge, with almost 1 million members, declares its support for a boycott of Israel and calls on Norway to endorse #UNinvestigateApartheid.

headline: Big Thief cancels concerts in Tel Aviv
summary: Grammy-nominated U.S. band Big Thief cancels two planned concerts in Tel Aviv. In a statement, they say "we oppose the illegal occupation and the systemic oppression of the Palestinian people. We believe in total freedom and self-determination for Palestinians" and explain that they made their decision after conversations with "BDS supporters and allies, Palestinians, and Israeli citizens who are committed to the fight for justice for Palestinians." The band was scheduled to play at Barby, an Israeli venue known for sending "f**k you, we're from Israel" t-shirts to Israeli forces during bombings of Gaza.

headline: Latin American Council of Social Sciences endorses BDS
summary: The Latin American Council of Social Sciences (CLACSO), with more than 800 research centers in 55 countries, unanimously passes a motion endorsing the Palestinian call to boycott Israeli institutions complicit in Israel’s regime of military occupation, settler-colonialism, and apartheid.

headline: badbadnotgood cancels concert in Tel Aviv
summary: Grammy-winning Canadian group badbadnotgood cancels an announced concert in Tel Aviv after previously performing there in 2017. The show’s cancellation followed appeals from fans and activists and came days after Big Thief canceled concerts at the same venue.

headline: Parliament of Catalonia becomes first in Europe to recognize that Israel is committing the crime of apartheid
summary: Parliament of Catalonia passes a resolution making it the first parliament in Europe to recognize Israel is committing the crime of apartheid against the Palestinian people. The resolution "commits to and asks the Government of the Generalitat de Catalunya not to support or provide help or assistance to maintain this situation. That is, to use all possible political and diplomatic tools, within the scope of their competences, to ensure that the Israeli authorities implement the recommendations made in the Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch reports."

headline: Polish political party Razem endorses BDS
summary: Ahead of its 2022 annual congress, the Polish political party Razem recognizes Israel as an apartheid state and endorses BDS.

headline: Lisbon Pride refuses participation of Israel’s ambassador
summary: The Organizing Committee of Lisbon Pride, which includes more than 20 of the most prominent Portuguese organizations working for queer and trans liberation, denies participation by Israel's ambassador in their march, saying "it would be hypocritical to allow states practicing segregation, apartheid, and colonization" to join a march celebrating "the struggle for LGBTI+ rights, human rights and equality.”

headline: French parliamentarians issue resolution on Israeli apartheid
summary: 37 members of the French parliament co-sign a resolution "condemning the institutionalization by Israel of an apartheid regime against the Palestinian people.” Resolutions are opinions issued by one of the two chambers of the French parliament, without being laws.

headline: Israeli filmmakers call on Locarno Festival to drop Israeli film
summary: Israeli filmmakers and artists including Oscar-nominated director Guy Davidi and Turner Prize co-winner Tai Shani urge the Locarno International Film Festival to cancel a screening of an Israeli film due to its funding. My Neighbor Adolf was funded by the Rabinovich Foundation’s Israel Cinema Project, Israel’s largest film fund. The fund contractually bars filmmakers from "marking Independence Day or the day of the establishment of the state as a day of mourning," a form of Nakba denial that censors Palestinians. It also prevents filmmakers from questioning Israel's status "as a Jewish and democratic state," thereby censoring discussion of Israel's apartheid policies. The action marks increasing but limited engagement by Israeli artists with boycott tactics.

headline: Rodrigo y Gabriela cancel concert in Tel Aviv
summary: After hearing from fans, fellow artists, and human rights defenders, Mexican acoustic guitar duo Rodrigo y Gabriela canceled a planned concert in Tel Aviv.

headline: University of Melbourne Student Union endorses BDS
summary: Following a thorough consultation process, the University of Melbourne Student Union, representing 30,000 students, endorsed the Palestinian BDS call, including the boycott of complicit Israeli academic institutions. UMSU thus maintained its "130-year tradition of students standing up for human rights”.

headline: 890+ Musicians pledge to boycott
summary: 890 musicians sign the 2022 Musicians for Palestine pledge to respect the Palestinian call for boycott "by declining invitations to events that are subsidised or sponsored by the Israeli state, its lobby groups or complicit cultural institutions."

headline: 250+ Israeli filmmakers pledge to boycott Shomron/Samaria Film Fund
summary: Hundreds of Israeli filmmakers pledge not to accept funds from or cooperate with the Shomron/Samaria Film Fund, established by Israeli Culture Minister Miri Regev in 2019. The fund supports Israelis living in illegal settlements in the occupied Palestinian territory, but not Palestinians whose land they colonize. Shomron/Samaria is a term used by Israeli religious nationalists to refer to the West Bank and assert Israeli control over areas subject to military occupation and apartheid.

headline: Queer and trans artists refuse work with Puma in solidarity with Palestinians
summary: Six US-based queer and trans artists refuse lucrative work with Puma for its Pride campaign in solidarity with the Palestinian call to Boycott Puma over its complicity in Israeli apartheid. The organisation these artists work with, Queer|Art, stood with them and endorsed the Palestinian BDS call. Puma sponsors the Israeli Football Association, which includes teams located in illegal Israeli settlements on stolen Palestinian land. More than 200 Palestinian sports clubs have called for a worldwide #BoycottPuma campaign.

headline: Sydney Festival Board suspends foreign government funding after boycott
summary: After Indigenous, Black and queer artists and organisations were among many others in withdrawing from the prestigious Sydney Festival over its acceptance of funding from the Israeli government, the Sydney Festival Board announces it will suspend funding from international governments and their cultural agencies.

headline: French writer Annie Ernaux, a BDS supporter, wins Nobel Prize for Literature
summary: French writer Annie Ernaux wins the 2022 Nobel Prize for Literature. Ernaux has signed onto multiple letters supportive of the BDS movement and critical of Israeli policies. In 2019, she was supportive of the call for a boycott of the Eurovision song contest hosted by Israel. In 2021, she signed "Letter against apartheid: in support of the Palestinian struggle for decolonisation."

headline: Australian Education Union Votes to Support Right to Boycott
summary: Australia’s National Tertiary Education Union votes to support the right of its 26,000 members to engage in BDS for Palestinian rights, to refuse Israeli government-sponsored tours to apartheid Israel, and to oppose adoption of policies prohibiting criticism of Israel, including the IHRA working definition of antisemitism, which equates criticism of Israel with antisemitism.

headline: Uruguay’s national football team cancels World Cup training in Israel
summary: Following a months-long campaign led by local Uruguayan groups and letters from Palestinian football teams, including those whose players have lost lives and limbs to Israeli bullets, Uruguay’s national football team cancels its World Cup training in Israel.

headline: Artists withdraw from Pop Kultur Berlin over Israeli government sponsorship
summary: Four artists withdraw from the Pop Kultur Berlin music festival over its continued acceptance of sponsorship from the Israeli government. Since 2017, at least fifteen other artists have withdrawn from the same festival in solidarity with Palestinians.

headline: Companies withdraw from Bahrain International Airshow over participation of Israeli companies
summary: Oman's Salam Air company withdraws from participating in the Bahrain International Airshow, and the Kuwait Finance House removes its logo from the list of sponsors of the exhibition, due to the participation of Israeli companies. The airshow gives Israeli companies the opportunity to promote weapons and tech "field-tested" on Palestinians.

headline: Oakland Roots Sports Club becomes first US team to drop Puma
summary: After a year of engagement with local grassroots groups and fan clubs, the Oakland Roots Sports Club becomes the first US sports team to heed the Palestinian call to drop Puma over its sponsorship of the Israeli Football Association, which includes teams located in illegal Israeli settlements on stolen Palestinian land. More than 200 Palestinian sports clubs have called for a worldwide #BoycottPuma campaign.

headline: Case Western Reserve students pass divestment motion
summary: Case Western Reserve University Undergrad Student Government passes a resolution calling on the university to divest from companies complicit in Israeli apartheid, including Elbit Systems, HP, PUMA, AXA, and G4S.

headline: Football players and fans support Palestine at 2022 FIFA World Cup
summary: Football players and fans use the world stage to showcase support for Palestinian rights at the FIFA World Cup, demonstrating that normalization agreements between Israel and Arab dictatorships do not reflect the will of the people. The widespread, visible support became the subject of Western media coverage. Many fans denounced FIFA and PUMA's complicity in Israeli apartheid through their relationship with the Israeli Football Association, which includes teams located in illegal Israeli settlements on stolen Palestinian land.

headline: First anti-apartheid Palestinian National Conference Call
summary: The PLO, the BDS movement and Palestinian civil society and human rights organizations issue a historic call to intensify global pressure to dismantle Israel's regime of settler-colonialism and apartheid.

headline: South African Rugby Union rescinds invitation to Israeli team
summary: The South African Rugby Union (SARU) heeds calls from Palestinian civil society to rescind an invitation to the Tel Aviv Heat team for the Mzansi Challenge.

headline: Mayor of Barcelona suspends institutional ties with Israel
summary: Barcelona's Mayor suspends institutional relations with Israel, including the city's twinning agreement with Tel Aviv, “until the Israeli authorities put an end to the system of violations of Palestinian human rights and fully comply with the obligations imposed on them by international law and the various United Nations resolutions.” The decision was supported by over 54 prominent figures, including Mark Ruffalo and Susan Sarandon as well as progressive Jewish groups and individuals from 15 countries.

headline: African Union suspends Israel's observer status
summary: The African Union says that Israel’s observer status at the bloc is suspended and removes Israeli ambassador Sharon Bar-li from the summit in Ethiopia.

headline: Scholar withdraws from ethics conference in Israel
summary: UK scholar Sophie Grace Chappell withdrew from an ethics conference in Israel over “the longstanding failure of the State of Israel to accord basic human rights to the Palestinian people” and the “increasingly extreme, inhumane, and violently oppressive policies currently being deployed against innocent Palestinians by the Settler movement in the West Bank and elsewhere, with the connivance and at times active support of the Israeli [occupation forces] and of members of the present Israeli government.”
target: Anti-theory in the Philosophy of Science and Ethics conference

headline: Rabinovich Foundation, a racist Israeli film fund, ends loyalty oath requirement
summary: Following intense boycott pressure, including PACBI’s call to boycott all films supported by the Rabinovich Foundation, the racist Israeli film fund says it will end its insistence that filmmakers seeking its support must sign a loyalty oath to "omit in their films any mention of Israel's system of apartheid and the ethnic cleansing inherent to its foundation.”

headline: Indonesia calls out FIFA hypocrisy, refuses to host Israeli team
summary: Indonesia announces that it will not host the Israeli football team for the 2023 FIFA Under-20 World Cup, accusing FIFA of double standards for blacklisting Russia over its invasion of Ukraine while turning a blind eye to Israel’s actions. The Israeli Football Association includes teams located in illegal Israeli settlements on stolen Palestinian land. In response, FIFA removes Indonesia as host of the event.

headline: Balkan Trafik Festival in Belgium returns funding from Israeli embassy
summary: The Balkan Trafik Festival, which promotes Balkan cultures, flavours, rhythms and sounds, announces it has returned sponsorship money from the Israeli embassy following pressure from activists, noting they have "become aware of the problems posed by associating the logo of an Israeli institution with our event, especially in the current context of rising tensions in Israel and Palestine."

headline: Palestinian trade unions issue call for solidarity
summary: Palestinian trade union bodies and professional syndicates urge all trade unions, trade union federations, and professional syndicates worldwide to contribute to the Palestinian-led anti-apartheid movement by taking meaningful action in support of the rights of Palestinian workers and the Palestinian people at large.

headline: Protesters force cancellation of "Festival of Israeli Universities" event in Brazil
summary: A mass mobilization disrupts a planned propaganda event at the University of Campinas in Brazil. Called the "Festival of Israeli Universities," the event featured several Israeli universities complicit in Israeli colonization, apartheid, and military occupation.

headline: Egyptian activists cancel Israeli music festival in Sinai
summary: Indigo Music Festival, an Israeli festival, cancels an event in the Sinai after popular pressure led by BDS Egypt.

headline: Oslo City Council announces an end to trade with goods and services produced in illegal Israeli settlements
summary: The municipality of Oslo, Norway announces that it will not trade in goods and services produced in areas that are illegally occupied in violation of international law. Its procurement policy will exclude companies that directly or indirectly contribute to Israel’s illegal settlement enterprise, a war crime under international law.

headline: Belgian city of Liège votes to end all ties with Israel
summary: The Liège City Council adopts a resolution to end all ties with Israel citing its regime of “apartheid, colonization and military occupation.”

headline: European Commission must respond to a petition on EU trade with illegal settlements
summary: The European Parliament’s committee on petitions (PETI) decides unanimously that European Commission must respond to a petition on EU trade with illegal settlements and says the European Parliament’s committee on international trade (INTA) should consider backing a ban.

headline: Finnish National Gallery accepts new ethical guidelines
summary: A strike by 220 art workers and four arts organisations draws attention to funding received by Finnish art organizations from Chaim “Poju” Zabludowicz, whose wealth is derived from decades of arms trade between Finland and Israel, and whose other investments are complicit in supporting Israeli occupation policies and human rights abuses against Palestinians. The Finnish National Gallery committed to changes to ensure that its policies regarding receiving private funding will be more ethical.

headline: Sam Smith cancels concert in Israel
summary: The Brit and Grammy award-winning artist Sam Smith cancels their performance in the Summer in the City festival in Tel Aviv, following multiple calls not to perform in apartheid Israel.

headline: Several large U.S. tech firms shut down operations in Israel
summary: Electronic Arts (EA), Dropbox, and Corning shut down operations in Israel, following the lead of Israeli tech giants that have moved abroad. Senior Israeli analysts recently said, “investments in Israel in recent months have almost disappeared…We see a poor appetite for investments on the part of foreign investors, but we also have less appetite as Israelis.”

headline: The mayor of Belém, Brazil declares the city an Apartheid Free Zone
summary: The mayor of Belém, Brazil, Edmilson Rodrigues, declares the city an Apartheid Free Zone, denouncing Isael’s “expulsion of a people from their ancestral territory, a true apartheid.” Belém, the capital of the state of Pará in the Amazonas, is renowned for bringing Indigenous and other people together in the struggle for justice and building solidarity.

headline: Belgian city of Verviers votes to end all ties with Israel
summary: The Verviers City Council votes to cut its “ties with the Israeli apartheid regime” to “strengthen its support for the Palestinian people.”

headline: G4S decides to sell remaining business in Israel
summary: Allied Universal, which acquired security giant G4S in 2019, says it will sell its remaining stake in Israel’s Policity police training academy, ending G4S’ business in Israel following over a decade of tireless BDS campaigning that cost the company millions in lost and cancelled contracts and forced them to acknowledge “reputational damage.”

headline: Canadian Union of Public Employees (CUPE Manitoba) endorses BDS
summary: The Manitoba branch of the Canadian Union of Public Employees, which represents 37,000 workers, announces its support for the BDS movement to end Israeli apartheid and oppression of Palestinians.

headline: Italy's Apartheid Free Zone campaign grows to 300 groups
summary: More than 300 businesses, cultural and sports associations, trade unions, and movements throughout Italy declare themselves Israeli Apartheid Free Zones and pledge to fight all forms of racism and discrimination.

headline: Filmmakers withdraw from Israeli film festival in Jerusalem
summary: Oscar winner Jane Campion (Best Director, 2021), and Basque filmmaker Estíbaliz Urresola Solaguren are among those to ask for their films to be withdrawn from the Jerusalem Film Festival, an Israeli film festival partnered with the Israeli ministry of culture. At least three other directors from the US and UK also did so.

headline: American Anthropological Association endorses academic boycott
summary: The American Anthropological Association (AAA), the largest and oldest scholarly body in the U.S., adopts a resolution to boycott complicit Israeli academic institutions with the support of 71% of voting members, seven years after a similar resolution failed by a narrow margin in 2016.

headline: Anthropologists in Latin America pass BDS motion
summary: Scholars gathered at the XIV Mercosur Anthropology Conference in Rio de Janeiro pass motion recognizing BDS as a counter-hegemonic tool "against regimes based on colonialism and apartheid state practices."

headline: University of Sydney Students’ Representative Council votes to support BDS
summary: The representative body for undergraduate students at the University of Sydney adopts a motion that expresses "solidarity with the Palestinian people living under an Apartheid state" and supports the Palestinian call for BDS "to achieve freedom, justice and equality for Palestinians."

headline: 250 intellectuals, writers, and cultural workers from 28 countries boycott International Book Fair honoring Israel
summary: After the International Book Fair of Santo Domingo (FILSD) dedicates their 2023 book fair to the State of Israel, over 250 participants from 28 countries sign a letter calling for non-participation. Figures such as U.S. feminist and civil rights activist Angela Davis, Dominican academic Silvio Torres Saillant, Puerto Rican writers Mayra Santos Febres and Dominican Angie Cruz, and Israeli historian Ilan Pappé were among the signatories.
target: International Book Fair of Santo Domingo (FILSD)

headline: Six year campaign disrupts Pop-Kultur Berlin's Israeli government sponsorship
summary: Six years after the first artists withdrew from Pop-Kultur Berlin over its partnership with the embassy of apartheid Israel, the festival finally ends the partnership. More than twenty artists have boycotted the festival since 2017. While it is unclear whether the festival will accept Israeli government sponsorships in the future, musicians wrote in an open letter that they “hope the festival continues its ethical stance."

headline: Argentinian singer Fito Páez cancels Israel gig
summary: Grammy- and Latin Grammy-winning singer Fito Páez's team confirms he will not appear in Israel, despite the fact that it was previously mentioned as a stop on his tour. The move came as the Argentine Committee for Solidarity with the Palestinian People and other movements called on him to boycott.

headline: Israel suspends arms export to Colombia after Colombia recognizes the genocide
Artists and organizations withdraw from comic festival over Israeli government sponsorship
summary: Numerous artists and organizations withdraw from Lucca Comics, the second biggest comics festival in the world, over the festival's acceptance of Israeli government sponsorship, including bestselling cartoonist Zerocalcare, Amnesty International Italy, Italian singer-songwriter Giancane, Italian band Gli Ultimi, Trilogia esplicita author Fumettibrutti, literary tiktoker La Biblioteca di Daphne, author of Biliardino Alessio Spataro, and the publishing house Red Star Press. Eugenio Giani, the president of the Tuscany region, said the Israeli embassy sponsorship of the comics fair was "inopportune."

headline: Belgian unions take action against arms shipments to Israel
summary: Belgian transport workers' unions call on their members to refuse to handle military equipment being sent to Israel. The ACV Puls, BTB, BBTK and ACV-Transcom unions are among those signing the joint statement, which reads, "while a genocide is under way in Palestine, workers at various airports in Belgium are seeing arms shipments in the direction of the war zone. We...call on our members not to handle any flights that ship military equipment to Palestine/Israel, like there were clear agreements and rules at the start of the conflict with Russia and Ukraine."

headline: Bolivia suspends diplomatic relations with Israel
summary: Bolivia breaks diplomatic ties with Israel "in repudiation and condemnation of the aggressive and disproportionate Israeli military offensive taking place in the Gaza Strip."

headline: Multiple countries downgrade diplomatic relations with Israel amid genocide in Gaza
summary: Chile, Colombia, Honduras, Chad, Turkey, and Jordan recall their ambassadors to Israel amid the genocide in Gaza. Chile cites “unacceptable violations of international humanitarian law committed by Israel in the Gaza Strip,” while Colombian President Gustavo Petro says, "if Israel does not stop the massacre of the Palestinian people, we cannot remain there."

headline: Barcelona port workers refuse to handle weapons shipments

headline: Italian, Turkish, Greek transport workers unions refuse to load war materiel to Israel

In a joint statement, they declared, “we reaffirm our joint decision to stop and prevent any loading and unloading of weapons, war materiel or any means that could continue to fuel the massacre of the Palestinian people.”

headline: Major Indian trade unions call for end to Indian labor deal with Israel

They also urged Indian workers to boycott Israeli products and to not handle Israeli cargo. The Centre of Indian Trade Unions (CITU), All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC), Indian National Trade Union Congress (INTUC), Hind Mazdoor Sabha (HMS), and several others are among the trade unions participating in the statement.

headline: Jordan abdondons energy and water exchange deal with Israel

The deal would have seen Jordan supply energy to Israel in exchange for water from Israel. The Israeli government controls the majority of Palestinian water resources, destroys Palestinian water infrastructure, and has created a situation of water apartheid between Palestinian communities and illegal Israeli settlements.

headline: Barcelona suspends relations with Israel for second time

Barcelona previously suspended relations with Israeli in February 2023, but these relations were restored by a new mayor in September 2023, before being suspended again in November.

headline: Queer filmmakers withdraw from Israeli film festival

Our refusal to engage with TLVFest is our contribution to this end, just as principled artists did during the apartheid rule in South Africa."
